number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2012
												An appealing dark cyberpunk FPS game that plays more like an oldschool style of shooter. There's no cover system or regenerative health, no pressing E/F to pick up items (walking over them simply grabs them.) A no nonsense, no fuss game, yet it still offers a nice array of interesting weaponary to play with & upgrade using "NANO Currency" you collect.  The game is pretty full on in the way of lots of things that can be destroyed, but mostly the fact that it can get extremely chaotic very quickly. Making sure you move around while shooting is essential. Worth noting is there isn't any quick save option, instead you get spawned back to the last checkpoint. I found this a little frustrating, but in fairness checkpoints aren't too far apart.  Campaign mode takes more or less around 8 hours to finish, but it does offer achievements and a survival mode to add further hours of gameplay.   I enjoyed the game, but unlike some other games I think Hard might be too challenging for my taste.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												This is quite a surprising game. Like if you took a solid fps from 90s, upgraded visuals/sounds to "modern" standards and threw it on the market full of easy faceroll shooters (often filled non-fps features of dubious quality). A bold move.So, what does the game do well ? It doesn't try to be something else. It's a railroad fps in the best traditions of games like unreal, quake, hexen, halflife and so on - it's a superb journey to genre sort-of forgotten. /But/ - you have to like this kind of games. Not everying is perfect either (see a few highlights below) of course, but then again - what is ?A few details (all from "insane" difficulty PoV where applicable):* difficultyI'm happy to report the game is quite challenging. This is a great refresher after many AAA titles that generally fail miserably in this department. The game will put both your hands and your head to test - and that's great.* controlsCompared to past fpses, the authors decided to ignore crouching (not a big deal tbh, though it feels strange initially) and the jump is of very limited use (think of it as something a bit more realistic, no practical use during fights).* savesNo manual saves, though the checkpoint system is mostly well made as far as pacing goes. Probably of little/no issue on easier levels, but on the hardest level you might rarely fell into some short loops skewing a bit towards Dark Souls experience ;)* storyWell, there's some stuff between chapters (in form of "moving" comic) and to lesser extent during the gameplay. No complaints, but nothing special or extensive. Then again - the game is not about the story ;)* visuals, soundPuts to shame many games few times more expensive.* optionsEverything important seems to be there. Menu animations can be mildly irritating (they are off during the gameplay though)* HP and stuffNo autoregen :). Though shield and energy reserves (ammo) regenerate automatically - you still lose some hp after taking stronger hits. TBH it works ok - though there're perhaps a bit too many supplies - and on top of that enemies often drop some ammo/hp.

												I had never even heard of this game when I gave it a try. It came with a Humble Bundle. It was a more than pleasant surprise. I think there was a story in the game, but I could care less about it. Who needs it when you have such solid shooting and breathtaking graphics.

												Hard Reset is a nice shooter. The longer I played the game the more I liked it. It's actually a good sign if you finish a game and feel like playing it all over again right away. The problem with this game is, it's not quite easy. Some say the game is too hard, even on normal difficulty. I thought it was OK on 'normal' although quite challenging. Nevertheless, if on sale, I very much recommend this game, if you don't mind a challenge.Pros:- nice graphics- good level design- interesting weapon design, your weapons can be rifle, shotgun, rocket launcher, grenade thrower and mine thrower at the same timeCons:- story- can be tough at times- impossible to survive on higher difficultiesPS: I played this game with controller so I don't know how it plays with a mouse and keyboard.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Got this after thoroughly enjoying Shadow Warrior, but unfortunately it's not up to the same standard. It's very pretty and the weapon system is interesting, but its major flaw is that it tries to emulate old-school shooters but then instead of making you as mobile as you were in those games, movement feels like it's copied from gears of war. The slow and clunky movement works in GoW because the game is designed around it and you're supposed to use cover, but that's not the case here. Imagine playing Doom with your knees (well, the protagonist's knees) taped together... not fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Played on: i5 3570k @ 4.3GHz, GTX 970 @ +100/+300, 8GB DDR3 @ 1600MHz, Samsung 850 Evo, Windows 10 64Price paid: 99pTime to finish: 5 hours 50 minutesScore: 6/10Recommended?: Yes, only when on sale thoughYeah, not bad overall. The gunplay was satisfying, the weapon upgrades were a lot of fun to use, the enemies were fairly varied and the final area was really well done and enjoyable. They didn't reinvent the wheel but the game is fun to play for the most part and it's not too long either which to me is a plus, a lot of games these days tend to overstay their welcome. I also enjoyed their comic book style cut-scenes.Hard Reset does have some major flaws though, the first is the voice acting and dialog, it's best described as cringe-worthy and amateur, there was only one major character that wasn't laughable, and sadly it wasn't the main one. I can't tell you just how bad it was, you need to experience it for yourselves. Another big problem was a surprising one, performance, I couldn't maintain 60fps on any visual preset, drops into the 40s were common on the major boss battles and even some smaller events, I can only imagine how poorly this ran on 2012 hardware. The final complaint was the constant micro-freezing whenever the game autosaved which was often enough to annoy me. So there you have it, Hard Reset is an OK shooter that does have some fun moments but suffers with performance issues and comically bad voice work, for 99p I'd say it's well worth a shot if you're bored and have run out of better games to play.

content:
Posted: February 16
												Fun and intense combat amid some pretty beautiful sci-fi landscapes, but it's all in service of the blandest and most generic kind of FPS. Even the aforementioned landscapes get a little samey after a while, as does the enemy variety. There's exploding ball, chicken saw thing, humanoid thing, biped thing, flying thing, and insect thing. I think that covers it?Say what you want about other 'old school' shooters such as Painkiller, but at least that game had a vast array of environments and enemies, every level gave you something different to look at and it never became visually stale. I guess the moral of this review is if you HAVE to play a dumb FPS, buy that instead.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												This action-packed, challenging FPS is very reminiscent of Croteam's legendary Serious Sam games where you are swarmed by dozens of enemies almost at any given time and you need to shoot through hoards and hoards of robots who are hell-bent over tearing your insides out. BUT, unlike Serious Sam games, the levels in which you fight these ever increasing number of enemies are MUCH more confined and closed when compared to the former game's large, arena like levels. This will probably lead to a lot of frustration as you barely have any room to maneuver around dozens of enemies running towards you or shooting at you. It doesn't help much that the main character runs so slow and his running dash is so short and pathetic it doesn't help at all. Therefore dodging enemy attacks becomes a game of sheer luck rather than skill.Another negative thing for me in this game was the weapons system. You have 2 main weapons that can be upgraded to embody more shooting modes for different situations (e.g. your standard assault rifle can be upgraded to also accompany a rocket luncher and a shotgun etc.) The problem arises when you are in the heat of battle and need to switch between different weapons in order to utilize their abilities in combat situations. Since this is a fast and frentic game very similar to older shooters, it becomes really awkward to switch from a weapon to another one and THEN selecting the desired shooting mode with the mouse wheel. Sometimes you barely have time to think because of all the chaos happening on screen and switching guns can lead to untimely deaths. The graphics look gorgeous albeit repetitive. The DLC included extends the base game by a few levels which look different and are a welcome addition to the abruptly ending vanilla game.Sound and music are very nicely done and fit the action perfectly. You should definitely not expect any coherent story in this game. This is a action shooter at heart and doesn't give two pennies about storyline. Make sure you use environmental explosives and traps as much as you can because they will save your life and help you defeat the baddies with more ease. All in all, I can describe this game as Serious sam in the future and with much more cramped, tight levels. It'll take around 10 hours to beat counting the Exile DLC. Base game will take around 6 hours to complete. It got a bit repetitive for me halfway through because all you are basically doing is pushing switches to get to the next area to kill more enemies. there are a couple of boss fights that are amusing if nothing else.If you know what you're going in for, then expect your adrenaline glands to pump non stop. This is a very solid shooter that knows what it wants to be and what it wants to do is take you back to the sweet haydays of golden shooters of past while relentlessly challenging you with every encounter. A casual gamer will find passing some of the levels pretty hard.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												As far as First Person Shooters go, Hard Reset is really quite generic in flavor. You traverse very linear levels and use your two guns to kill several varieties of homicidal robot. Despite this, something about it keeps charming me back for more. That "something" is more likely the difficulty. Hard Reset is exceedingly difficult, and getting through any given fight without taking a death carries a certain amount of satisfaction.The game could be described as "old school" style. Your health doesn't regenerate, requiring you to find healing pickups. The action is fast-paced and aggressive, favoring a DOOM-like method of remaining constantly mobile as you fight. Generally speaking you travel from fight to fight, with a few smaller fights in between the larger ones. However, unlike many shooters of this type, success is not tethered to reflexes because frankly, the player character has no reflexes. Although his movement speed seems fast, he is easily outran by most enemies. Sprinting increases speed by 25% at best and lasts for about 3 seconds, making it largely useless. Jumping is poor and used almost exclusively for getting over scripted obstacles. Instead the game favors strategy and planning, often requiring at least one death in the larger battles to get an idea of the better method of handling things, where to take the fight, what order to kill enemies, ideal weapons to use, and so forth. This is why it's so satisfying to survive a battle on the virgin attempt. The game seems to know this, as there's an achievement for surviving any one level other than the first without dying. Curiously, the player cannot crouch. This wouldn't be a big deal except for the large number of instances where you're told to find a way to get past an obstacle when you can plainly see that it'd be possible if your character would just bend down, slightly. It happens so frequently that at times it almost seems like the game is making fun of its own mechanics.Technically you only carry two weapons throughout the game, a more standard type and an electronic type, but each one can be upgraded in a variety of ways to give it very different functionalities. By default your regular gun is something of an assault rifle and your electronic gun is a close approximation of DOOM's plasma rifle, but as you add more bells and whistles to each gun, you'll find yourself with weapons such as a shotgun, rocket launcher, tesla cannon, railgun, and more. The electronic weapons are usually the more useful of the two types, but every weapon has its pros and cons. several weapons include a secondary fire which stuns and/or immobilizes foes which is a must if you hope to be successful, as the machines tend to be much faster and more maneuverable than the player.The level design is fairly good and atmospheric, especially if you're a fan of cyberpunk themes. I'm not, but it's still a pretty good environment, many of the stages taking on a seedy inner-city feel loaded with cheap advertisements and littering. The game includes secrets but often times, these "secrets" are nothing more than money-items hidden behind a large object. There are several instances where an item will be counted as a secret and an item hidden in an almost identical way will not be. Despite the secrets, the level layouts are very linear and don't lend themselves to much exploration. Most of the time you're heading from point A to point B, maybe stopping to check out a few nooks and crannies on the way.The story is told between levels through animated comic book-style artwork with not-so-great voice acting and swearing that almost seems forced. The story itself is, frankly, almost incomprehensible. In fact it is this seemingly impossible blend of confusingly complicated and yet entirely uncompelling. You know really know what's going on and yet, you don't really care to know. The ending creates more questions and answers and seems like it might have been meant to set up for a sequel that is probably never coming. Perhaps the story was poorly translated, but whatever the reason, it's arguably the game's weakest point and can almost entirely be ignored with little ill effect on the gameplay.But all the same, despite the game's very middle-of-the-road quality, I found myself repeatedly coming back to it in order to try and step up to the challenge. For that reason I would recommend the game to anybody looking for a fast and simple shooter with a steep challenge, though I might suggest getting it on sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I definitely recommend this game. The story makes very little sense, but the story is not important. What is important is the solid difficulty, the number and variety of enemies, the impressive sci-fi/cyberpunk setting and the weapons. The weapons are excellent, and allow you to pull-off a variety of combinations. For example you can fire a vacuum grenade to suck enemies into one group, then switch to the rocket launcher and blow them to pieces.  The graphics are smooth, and the level design has a nice combination of open areas and corridors. So much of the environment is destructible which you will need to utilise to fight off the hordes of enemies. A must play for fans of old-school shooters like Doom, Serious Sam and Duke Nukem.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Summary:An old-school shooter to the core with beautiful cyberpunk environments, challenging combat, waves of enemies and a unique weapon system. Held back by awful voice acting, awful music, cheap cutscenes and a half-hearted story that explains little. Unfortunately, you often feel powerless against the chaos because there are no effective ways of dodging, it's easy to get trapped in a corner or have one of the countless explosive hazards set off a deadly chain reaction. Defeating certain enemies is very difficult without specific weapons which you may not have bought earlier. But if you're here purely for the vintage shooter action, you won't be disappointed, as it offers plenty of challenge.The full story:Hard Reset is a real mixed bag, and certainly not for everyone. It's an old-school shooter to the core, featuring only minimal controls and no extra bells and whistles, just you and waves of robotic enemies. The enemies, even on normal difficulty, can be quite challenging and are good at dodging attacks. They love to ambush you at every turn, flank you, and can quickly whittle down your health if you don't keep moving; you must always be ready for a battle and think on your feet to survive. There are different types, some which explode in your face, others which charge at you, and some that stay at a safe distance and snipe away... with rockets. The few boss fights are challenging and old-school as well, involving glowing weak points and waves of minions, but when you learn their pattern you feel unstoppable. For the most part, combat is challenging, but fair; if you fail, you know it's your fault. On the other hand, the little guys are a lot more troublesome because they love to hide and ambush you, get right in your face and when they die, they cause damage if you're that close. Every single room in the game is filled with destructible objects which either explode or cause electrical damage, so you can imagine that one stray bullet, even from the enemy, often sets off a chain reaction of things exploding in your face. At times like these, the game feels unfair. Dodging or jumping doesn't always save you, enemies sneak up behind you with ease and it's easy to get trapped in a corner, so many situations turn into trial-and-error. Some enemies love to hang out at a distance behind cover and are difficult to destroy with anything but one or two weapon types which you can't even buy until later on. Rockets and mortar shells constantly fly at you and FPS logic tells you that if you're behind cover or sprint several feet away from its impact, you'll be safe... but not always. Enemy projectiles' splash damage has a ridiculous reach.Your own weapons are still formidable, however. You get only two (with separate ammo types), but a whopping five firemodes apiece, each of which is designed for certain situations. You have the minigun, grenade launcher, rocket launcher, railgun, shotgun, proximity mines and my favorite, the smartgun which detects enemies and shoots through walls. You can also upgrade your weapons, health and armor through seamless first-person terminals, using experience you collect from combat and finding secret areas. But even if you fully upgrade your health and shield, it's not by much; Hard Reset doesn't hold your hand and the only assurance you have is frequent checkpoints and no game over. The only guidance you have is a vague objective and the occasional voiceover communication.Speaking of which... the voice acting is awful. With the exception of one guy, it's just ingenuine and unenthusiastic. The music is also total crap, consisting of the occasional ambient pad and a bunch of random futuristic drilling noises, like a robot dentist's equipment. Apparently, the composer didn't care either, but at least it lets you know when you're entering a fight. There is actual music when action begins, but it's your average, generic attempt at sounding futuristic: lots of synths, breakbeats and the occasional guitar. Completely forgettable at best, grating at its worst.The sound on the other hand, is great. Every little object you bump into sounds real, the sound of robots exploding into piles of scrap is satisfying and the weapons sound appropriately futuristic and cool.The visuals are gorgeous. That should be obvious considering it's on the Unreal 3 engine, but the environments look amazing. The dystopian city of Bezoar stretches out around and above you, massive and intricate, triggering memories of Blade Runner or Hong Kong from Deus Ex: Human Revolution. So many scenes in this game deserve that you stop and just take a  look around. It's such a shame then, that this game is fast-moving and direct by its very nature. The models and textures are beautiful; things that anyone would be proud to put on their resume. Most props fully utilize the Havok physics engine and behave realistically, never once glitching for me. The layout of certain objects in certain places doesn't always make sense, but it's still cool to see things fly everywhere in the heat of battle.I'll mention the story last because it's not important. In fact, it's barely there at all. In between levels, what little plot there is is expounded through cutscenes which look suspiciously like rough draft cinematics; you know, a comic book of moving sketches designed to give an idea of what the finished, pre-rendered cutscene will look like. But there's a difference between stylish, comic book cutscenes (see: Beneath a Steel Sky, Max Payne 2) and a rough draft someone never finished. Anyway, the story has something to do with a network of digital personalities, the big, faceless, evil corporation that controls it and robots that want it. Very little is ever explained, leading to more confusion. But again, it's not that important because when you're playing, you only get a vague objective to strive for and the occasional voiceover telling you what to do next, very little context or exposition. And that's another thing: The environments, visuals and sound design make me want to explore this world, understand it, spend some time in it, but that just ain't gonna happen.It's a very short game too; if you spend no time collecting secrets and are better at staying alive than me (which is likely), you'll blaze through it in no time and wonder what the Hell just happened. The Exile DLC is included, although it's more like "almost half the game the developers didn't have time to finish before release". Seriously, it's a continuation of the main game, and if you don't have the DLC, it ends abruptly after a boss fight with no explanation. Still, it's free, so you can't complain too much. It also takes you outside the city, into outdoor environments like a machine scrapyard full of encroaching greenery, introducing a few new pesky and challenging foes in the process. Still, it's quite short and (at least for me) becomes a grind, repetitively blasting away, clicking a panel, walking forward, rinse and repeat. Once you complete normal, more difficulties open up along with a survival mode.But like I said, this game isn't for everyone. If you love old-school shooters but want a modern presentation, if you want a good challenge and can stomach some unforgiving mechanics and if you love cyberpunk settings but can deal with a minimal story, this should be right up your alley.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2013
												A quality single player shooter enhanced by additional levels appended onto the original base game, a.k.a. the extended edition.  Enemy variety could be more varied and the save system is based on checkpoints though they're liberal enough not to cause severe frustration though I have to admit to a couple of F-Bombs and ALT F4s.  The weapon system is based on 2 guns, each with multiple modes.  An interesting attempt to redefine the first person shooter but I think it fails as the system is needlessly clunky.  With the energy weapon in hand, selecting the rocket launcher requires a key press for the host weapon and another for the launcher mode.  Why?  In the heat of battle I felt like a circus performer.  What's worse is that I found the controls to be somewhat unresponsive, no doubt a purposeful design decision to negate any type of weapon mode key press while sprinting.   Despite the flaws, the well realized world reminded me of Blade Runner infused with a bit of Rapture.   The level design, graphics and solid shooting mechanics are enough reasons to play.  Oh did I mention the Quake like rail-gun.  My favorite weapon in the game, though like some of the other weapon modes there is a cool down so spamming anything but the base weapon modes is prohibited.  Weapon upgrades are acquired through upgrade terminals.  This mechanic does enhance the standard fps as the expenditure of the in game currency, called nano, allows for complete customization of your play-through.   The story I thought was well penned but is presented like a comic book.  There are multiple modes once your done with the game though I had little desire to partake.  One mode, called EX allows you to play the game with all weapon and defense upgrades in place.  Another mode, called Heroic allows for one save point at the beginning of the level.  The last is standard Survivor mode where the game throws waves of enemies at you.    I've read that the development team has roots in both BulletStorm and Painkiller.  The quality with which Hard Reset was constructed bears the fruit of that lineage.  It's a great shooter and worthy of your time and slot in your library.

Posted: January 15
												Story : The game takes place in a dystopian futuristic world where the machines took control over pretty much everything and you are a lone soldier who was betrayed by this organ of the government he worked for and tries to find other signs of human life in this city.  The story kinda doesn't make sense, i mean you don't know if you have a past or smth you are just a soldier who fights the machines and that's it.It isn't very long, it has like 7 levels but trust me they are INTENSE, and besides that it has a free dlc who adds 5 more levels (new enemies also) which are more intense than the vanilla game itself. You also have a new difficulty (heroic mode) which is harder than the insane difficulty, i recommend heroic for veterans in old school FPS . Finished it for the first time on hard and i gotta say i didn't went into this as easier as a knife into cheese. Graphics: tbh i don't kinda care about them but they look ok, sound : good , Gameplay : ok Length : it took for me between 15-20 hrsDo i recommend it? Yes, overall it's  a good game, a good cheap game and, like i said, if you are looking for story rich old games, this isn't the right place to look at, but if you want an intense, somewhat scarry ( at some parts ) experience which isn't eating your wallet, oh yea boy you are in the right place. Replayability: For me, yes since i didn't knew some achievments are unlocked only on the top difficulty.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												A First-Person Shooter taking place in a dystopian 24th century setting where machines have taken over much of the planet and only a few scattered, human cities remain. WASD controls with mouse targeting. There are two weapon types: a physical-based weapon for bullets, grenades and an RPG, and an energy-based weapon for plasma, electricity and laser railgun. Various alternate-weapon modes for scopes, stun and seeking rockets. Left-mouse for firing; right-mouse for alternate mode. You can also target objects in the environment to create explosions or electricity discharges that will destroy the enemies for you, but if you're too close, you'll take damage as well.Ammo is plentiful as are healing power-ups, and the machines drop them as well. Lastly, there is a 'nano' resource that you need in order to unlock and upgrade weapons, and you can improve health, shield and recovery rates as well.The enemies, of course, are the machines. They range from small anti-personnel devices with blades, saws and explosives, through human-sized robots using energy-blasts, rockets or brute-force ramming, up to huge, towering bosses with multiple, active weak-spots that need to be destroyed in order to take the thing down. The saving is automatic at checkpoints and the zones between those checkpoints are pretty small, so reloading after defeat may cost you maybe five minutes of gameplay.The graphics are good with decent explosions, discharges and flying pieces but not top-notch and no particle effects. Maxed-out, everything runs smoothly on Windows 7 with 16GB, a 990X CPU and SLI-coupled Nvidia 970's. There were no glitches, crashes, lock-ups or slow-downs.The story that underlies the game is only partially present and things go on that don't make a lot of sense, nor does the ending resolve anything presented throughout the game, but it's enough of a shell to make the activities coherent and move the game forward.It is a solid FPS, and mostly you'll be mowing waves of enemies down. You have to keep moving and using the environment for protection or you can easily be overwhelmed. Overall, it takes maybe 10 hours to complete a run-though, so it's a distraction for a single day, and there is some replayability though different weapon choices, as well as improving performance and finding all the scattered nano and secret areas. Nothing beyond nano is found in the secret areas, though.Recommended.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Questionable level design and awkward shooting. Shadow Warrior remake (by the same studio) is essentially the same game but polished. Consider that game instead; this one I cannot recommend.NOTE: I always play games on the hardest available difficulty level. PROS:-Cool voice actingNEUTRALS:-The "all in one" weapon is functionally the same as multiple weapons that simply share ammo. -There are 2 weapon types (ammo and energy) which each have 5 subtypes to them. Unfortunately, the 5 subtypes are literally identical between the two weapons....major missed opportunity and lazy design.CONS:-Some enemies simply stand there trading damage with you regardless of what weapon you hit them with or where you shoot them. This becomes especially problematic in areas against several waves of enemies as you may end up in a situation where you simply don't have enough health to kill the next wave of enemies no matter how you play it.-AWFUL level design. Far too many enemies in almost every area; areas lead to constant dead ends; areas too small for types of enemies being fought.-Most enemies take a frustratingly large number of shots to kill.-Your shots will go right through enemies quite often (I'm talking about your rockets going straight through their stomach kind of thing).

												It's a fun old-school shooter that does what it's supposed to do.You can upgrade your weapons several times, and there's a survival mode + EX mode to keep you playing the game. Graphics are good in this game, sound is okay, but could've been better. If you want to shoot things and have minldess fun or a good challenge, then get this game. If you're looking for story telling then don't get this game.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Hard Reset is a great example of a classic-styled PC shooter done right. What I like most about this game is it's setting, a cyberpunk future on earth - with added killer machines that simply want you dead. Gameplay-wise, Hard Reset is a real 'blast' to play, and by 'blast' I mean - you can pretty much blow up something around every corner! Which of course comes in handy due to how overwhelmed you can be with so many enemies trying to gut you at once.I would recommend this game to anyone who has loved either Doom, Deus Ex, System Shock or just even if you have a thing for futuristic cyberpunk world settings, such as you would see in Blade Runner.

Posted: January 29, 2016
												"Hard Reset" is hard, really hard. I don't like the so called "retro" or "old school" shooters, which this game seems to pay homage to. Despite it all, I somehow loved "Hard Reset".You're Major Fletcher, a human badass with bionics who fights all kinds of robots who want to take over the world. You've got only two weapon types - one that fires hard ammo, another with energy charges. Each of the two weapon-types can morph into different weapons. For example, the hard ammo type can become a rifle, a shotgun, a grenade launcher, an RPG, and a mine launcher. Each weapon-mode can further be enhanced to feature alternate fire modes. In short, there's actually a lot of weapons to choose from, and to survive you'll have to switch between them a lot.The enemies are BRUTAL. Even the weakest ones can kill you with little to no effort if you're not careful. The enemies come in mini waves, and each wave is very much lethal. You can get blasted to pieces in a second, if you don't dodge, run, and shoot appropriate targets with appropriate arms. There's an amount of strategy involved here, too, although the game does at rare times feel cheap due to the sheer amount of enemies it throws at you. The few boss fights are pretty damn impressive, too. "Hard Reset" will challenge you a lot; it took me 17 hours to beat it on my first run ever (on Hard), because I died a whole lot. Yet I never truly felt like quitting, because the game always made it obvious WHY you died and WHY it was entirely your fault: you backed yourself into a corner, you ignored the little enemies, you chose your weapons poorly... every time I died, it just motivated me to try once again and turn those damn machines into scrap.The game also seems to be nicely optimized, since it ran at 55+ FPS with medium-high settings on my rather weak HP laptop.Criticism goes towards kinda samey level design, and the "Secret Area" mechanic, which often felt more like an in-game glitch. One example is walking on very tiny ledges - otherwise it's not possible, but on a specific level suddenly you CAN walk those ledges, but only on this exactly pre-defined spot in the level because a secret is hidden at the end of it. That kind of thing.But overall, "Hard Reset" turned out to be a hidden gem, and a true surprise. So yeah, recommended!

Posted: June 25, 2016
												This game is an enjoyable, classic-feeling FPS. There are enough waves of enemies, boss fights, and interesting guns to evoke memories of classic shooters. The story is pretty generic for a futuristic game, but it is has entertaining enough gameplay to keep one's interest for the duration of the campaign. I wouldn't say it has a high replay value, but if you catch it while a sale is occurring, I don't think you'll be disappointed. If you enjoy classic FPS's with a modern feel, then you should consider purchasing Hard Reset. (The included extra goodies are nice too.)

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Even despite this game's age and somewhat cliche storyline, it's a wonderful buy for anyone that's a fan of the shooter genre. Plenty of bosses, weapons, gear, and anything you need as 'Fletcher' to destroy tons of bots. I mean tons of them. Literal tons. Some downsides would be the lack of cover and mobility options, but given the time Hard Reset's been out, and the familiarity that fans would have to other games like Metroid Prime, this is a must-have for any avid fan of classic, tasteful shooters.

Posted: July 13, 2014
												Overall a satisfying if brief game, set in a slightly bizarre futuristic cyberpunk world, where AI controlled machines have arisen as mankinds primary threat, fighting to gain entrance into the last bastion of human civilization.  The protagonist played is none other than a secret police type, send on missions to halt and uncover infiltrations and deal with them in a violent manner.Sound great? Sadly, the storyline is a convoluted mess bordering on incomprehensible.  Having finished the game, I'm still not sure what was accomplished and what was going on.  With that major flaw aside, Hard Reset is an absolute blast, and captures the essence of the cyberpunk genre proficiently.You're given 2 weapons from the word go, and as you progress through the game, granted fairly frequent upgrade to bolster their capabilities and fire modes, rather than replace them with completely new guns. We're not talking minor changes either. but rather unlocking things like charged blast to electro-mortar to smart-gun style upgrades, which you'll find yourself rapidly switching between mid-fight to use deadly combo's to turn otherwise difficult enemies into scrap.The game starts out relatively difficult, almost to the point of being merciless, so if you're struggling, remember that in the future, lots of the cars, terminals and other machinery are highly volatile and explore with the gentlest of encouragement from your arsenal.   While the graphics are great, and the holographic style waepon upgrade interface is pretty cool,  I find it hard to overwhelmingly recommend this game due to the poor narrative. But, if you're the type to skip cutscenes, you'll probably find this worth your while.  There's potential here in the setting, so lets hope the developers make the most of it in any sequels.

Posted: January 16
												At first I didn't expect much of this game, but it turned out to be a whole lot more fun than I expected.The game feels a bit classic fps-like (think about run&gunners like Serious Sam).You ONLY fight ROBOTS in this game, but the game still feels really dark and intense.Though the game doesn't feature the most hardware consuming graphics, the looks are REALLY good. The use of colours, lighting, shadows and other effects are done extremely well in this game, I haven't seen many games done this as good as this game.The music may not be the grooviest of music you'll ever hear, but it is used really well in a way that fits the game. As soon as a wave of enemies is gonna attack you, the combat music will start playing, and the SECOND you finish off the last enemy the music comes to an end, which really boosts the atmosphere in a positive way.The game also features an upgrade system, which allows you to unlock new weapons and suit upgrades throughout the game. Wich each upgrade point you'll unlock, you'll probably be immediately rushing to the nearest upgrade station like a crack addict who just found a penny because the upgrades help A LOT.The weapon variation is done pretty well, though there are technically only 2 different types of ammo: you have 2 guns of many guns which will form all your weapons throughout the game.The game also features secrets, though they are mostly just nano (required for upgrade points).They did NOT go easy on the invisible walls in this game. Though this is usually no big deal since they are placed in rational locations, sometimes it can make secrets "harder to find" which might leave a bad taste in your mouth.The game has a storyline, but I didn't really feel it. The cutscenes are animated comic-style, which is kinda cool.If you like run&gunning with loads of explosions, the dark cyberpunk setting of the game and fighting robots you'll definitely like this game.

												So, I've finished this precious game. I can say only one thing. It is pretty awesome game! Gameplay really dynamic, outstanding boss fights, enemies that doesn't give you a rest and pretty damn good upgrade system. I found only one CON in this game. Its pretty damn short. Only 12 levels. But it's pretty worth it.8/10, will replay it on insane difficulty <3

Posted: September 23, 2016
												It's a good shooter game. I liked the cyberpunk setting, but the world felt too static, even though you can use the environment to kill your enemies. The story was nothing special and couldn't made me care what exactly is happening. I liked the weapon mechanics and I'd probably play some more in order to see how the game feels if you decide to develop the blue weapon. The enemies were interesting (although not very diverse) and challenging enough that I couldn't pass a single level without dying. I'd recommend the game if you approach it without high expectations and just want to shoot, destroy and have some fun.

Posted: January 21, 2016
												This game was far better then expected. If you want, play the demo and get a feel for yourself. The game has some similarities to the Serious Sam and Painkiller type games. The only difference is the universe and the enemies. It's set in a cyberpunk universe with some pretty good visuals. What sets this apart are the guns and the enemies. Instead of having 15 different guns, you have 2 guns that have alternate modes that link to the 15 other weapons which makes for a different fighting experience. Also your enemies are 100% robots so figuring out how they die is tricky. Normal fleshy enemies you can figure out just how much will kill them. Not so here. Heck, there are a few enemies that are almost impossable to figure out how much will destroy them until they blow. Plus the boss fights for this game are superb and the dlcs they release are free! Those are some recipes for success in my book. The game isn't extremely long but it isn't short either. For a game I spent a few bucks on, this was a real winner in my mind. Play the demo to get your own feel then buy a fantastic no cover shooter game, you won't be disapointed.

Posted: December 30, 2016
Review:Now don't get me wrong, I'm not saying this is a bad game, it just wasnt for me. Yes, I said 'not recommended', but I'd call this a 50/50 review. I also have not finished the game yet.Hard reset is set in a heavily cyberpunk setting where robots have caused all hell to break lose. It can be related to the 'Serious Sam' franchise, and as a fan of those games I thought I'd give Hard Reset a go. There are a multitude of Pros & Cons, but it the end, it felt empty. The Cons side of the list started over-running the pros, the game was becoming too 'rinse and repeat' for me. It was like eating your Aunt's crappy fruit cake, but you don't want to make her feel bad so you keep on eating it anyway. Again, I'm not saying it's a bad game; just tiresome. The game goes by too fast too. After 2 hours of gameplay I found my self already about half-way through.Pros- - Appealing Graphics for it's time; about 4/5- Weapon Customization- Challenge: it has decent difficulty, even on easy.Cons-- Soundtrack, I can handle Techno/Dubtsep/DNB/Whateverelseyouwanttocallit music, used to love it in fact, but as a connosieur for OST's - all I can say is: "what is this trash?". I wouldn't even call it by those name as the majority of the songs sound like some pots being banged together. It's a good thing that even at max volume it's hard to hear the music.- Gameplay, it can be enjoyable to some people, but mostly iffy for me. It's a little Point-A-to-Point-B-ish and rinse and repeat on killing the same enemies- The Enemies: Lack of diversity; I think there were a total of 3 kinds of robots at the half-way point I made it to. There was: a ranged enemy. A bull vs. matador style enemy - which ends up being a big push over due to it being so easy to dodge, plus if there's more than one, you can make them damage each other. And finally these small♥♥♥♥♥exploding runts that run faster than light, making them the biggest threat in the game. They seem to never be farther away than four inches from you, meaning you're always hit by their explosion + they have razors if they make contact with you. There movement is usually predictable, so it isn't that hard to hit them, but they sometimes come in massive packs, so if you don't kill 'em fast enough you get overrun immediatly.- Balance in resources: Now this is absolutely nitpicking on my part, but I thought I'd point it out at the least. You get ammo out the♥♥♥♥♥and never run out, but health starts to become more and more uncommon the father along you go.TL;DR/EndingO.P.R.- Mixed Feelings. The game is okay. Not bad, but not good, unless you completely adore a game like Hard Reset, then I guess you'd call it good. I would give it a middle revied if I could, but personally I'm swaying a little more to 'Not Recommended'.

Posted: May 15, 2016
												It's very difficult at first enough for me to put it down twice- even on normal difficulty- but if you stick with it theres a really solid FPS here without all the dumb crap of modern military shooters, (like scripted sequences, "epic" moments, obligatory slow motion effects,  etc). It's fast and reminds me a lot of the older shooters (Doom and its sequel, Duke 3D etc) because it doesnt hold your hand the whole way through and the weapons pack a punch. Again, its difficult at first because your weapons seem a bit underpowered but after you get a few upgrades and play smart you'll be kicking♥♥♥♥♥in no time. 8/10

Posted: January 29, 2016
												"Hard Reset" is hard, really hard. I don't like the so called "retro" or "old school" shooters, which this game seems to pay homage to. Despite it all, I somehow loved "Hard Reset".You're Major Fletcher, a human badass with bionics who fights all kinds of robots who want to take over the world. You've got only two weapon types - one that fires hard ammo, another with energy charges. Each of the two weapon-types can morph into different weapons. For example, the hard ammo type can become a rifle, a shotgun, a grenade launcher, an RPG, and a mine launcher. Each weapon-mode can further be enhanced to feature alternate fire modes. In short, there's actually a lot of weapons to choose from, and to survive you'll have to switch between them a lot.The enemies are BRUTAL. Even the weakest ones can kill you with little to no effort if you're not careful. The enemies come in mini waves, and each wave is very much lethal. You can get blasted to pieces in a second, if you don't dodge, run, and shoot appropriate targets with appropriate arms. There's an amount of strategy involved here, too, although the game does at rare times feel cheap due to the sheer amount of enemies it throws at you. The few boss fights are pretty damn impressive, too. "Hard Reset" will challenge you a lot; it took me 17 hours to beat it on my first run ever (on Hard), because I died a whole lot. Yet I never truly felt like quitting, because the game always made it obvious WHY you died and WHY it was entirely your fault: you backed yourself into a corner, you ignored the little enemies, you chose your weapons poorly... every time I died, it just motivated me to try once again and turn those damn machines into scrap.The game also seems to be nicely optimized, since it ran at 55+ FPS with medium-high settings on my rather weak HP laptop.Criticism goes towards kinda samey level design, and the "Secret Area" mechanic, which often felt more like an in-game glitch. One example is walking on very tiny ledges - otherwise it's not possible, but on a specific level suddenly you CAN walk those ledges, but only on this exactly pre-defined spot in the level because a secret is hidden at the end of it. That kind of thing.But overall, "Hard Reset" turned out to be a hidden gem, and a true surprise. So yeah, recommended!

												This game is an enjoyable, classic-feeling FPS. There are enough waves of enemies, boss fights, and interesting guns to evoke memories of classic shooters. The story is pretty generic for a futuristic game, but it is has entertaining enough gameplay to keep one's interest for the duration of the campaign. If you enjoy classic FPS's with a modern feel, then you should consider purchasing Hard Reset. (The included extra goodies are nice too.)

Posted: April 6
												Quite enjoyable! Its an FPS in the same vein as Painkiller and Serious Sam, which means run-and-gunning, huge arsenals and a quantity of explosions that would make Michael Bay proud. If you like movies like Blade Runner, the cyberpunk setting will likely appeal to you. It's a nice backdrop, I'll admit, but after a while the bleak colour palette and repetitive environments might start feeling tedious. Luckily, at that point (around halfway through the game), the locations change up, and the enemy-variation and overall experience improves, in my opinion. These last five levels are part of the Exile DLC that is included for free, which is good because it also fixes one of the major problems critics had with the game at launch: the short length of the campaign. The story is a little convoluted, but it isn't especially important. For achievement-enthusiasts, this game is an utter joy: with a grand total of 115 achievements, of which the majority are obtained in tiers based on the difficulty played on, it doesn't take long to have those beautiful, grey rectangles sliding down the corner of your screen like the Star Wars opening crawl. Lastly, the gameplay is solid, and graphics hold up nicely today!8/10

Posted: April 9
												Hard Reset is one of those mindless shooters, that can be fun if you're only after some mindless FPS fun.It feels like a throwback to some games from the 90's and is simple but straight to the point.The story is pretty basic and well presented in a cyberpunk world, but overall the gameplay is enjoyable. However its one of those games that you really need to be in the mood for. Which in itself is not a bad thing.If you're looking for an old school, difficult mindless shooter then give this a go, or get the 'Redux' version with improved graphics for a little bit more dosh.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Hard Reset is a cyberpunk FPS that is labelled as "old-school". These days there are a couple of such FPS games out there, notably Shadow Warrior, a remake from the same developer team. Hard Reset really delivers the old school: you have dozens of enemies sent against you at once, countless of objects you can destroy in the surrounding area (the game counts and rewards these environmental kills). What's more, the protagonist has weapons that do not require reloading - you just press and hold the button till all your foes are eliminated.Weapon-wise Hard Reset follows an interesting concept. You have two weapons and instead of mapping them to the numbers you can switch between them with the use of Q and E which are usually for "previous" or "next" weapons in the genre. As you make progress in the game the more nanocells you can pick up - these allow you to upgrade your two best friends thereby granting them extra firing capability. This is how you turn your rifle into a shotgun, then grenade launcher, RPG etc. The number keys are now unlocked and you can easily switch between these "functions" during a battle. It is an interesting concept, certainly.Graphics-wise Hard Reset looks stunning. Some of the effects are beautiful and if you look around you can easily notice the inspiration of various sci-fi authors such as Philip K.♥♥♥♥♥♥(to give you a hint: there are shuttles in the air with huge neon advertisements). The story is somewhat mediocre - there are comic book style cutscenes between the various chapters telling you the story of a major who wages a desperate battle against machines. These "custcenes" could have been better with a more appropriate voice acting.Do note that the game is very difficult. Many of the bigger enemies can easily kill you; using environmental kills is highly recommended due to the splash damage you can do with them. Running and jumping will be your best asset sometimes and even then you'll perish several times - the creators knew this that is why they included an achievement for not dying on a level.The game is short - 5-6 hours is enough to complete it. It is commendable that the developers released a free DLC that continues the story throughout 3 extra levels. You have the usual new-enemies-new-boss-new-environment deal here.Hard Reset is a very good game. If you miss the old school style FPS games you can give this one a try as it offers you top-notch graphics, achievements and replayability in case you want to try the higher difficulty levels, too.PS: Wow! I did not know Philip K. D.I.C.K's surname would be censored! :D

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
Product received for free
												Hard Reset is a decent game where you shoot robots and♥♥♥♥♥♥ There's a pretty unimportant and uninspired storyline. The jist is that there are robots wanting to kill all humans because humans wont let them get smarter. So they go on murderous rampages and humans keep em out with massive walls. You play as a soldier fighting against these robots (essentially). The voice acting is terrible too, and the cinematics are rather dull, however the game makes up for this in its combat.If you've ever played Serious Sam, you will understand how to play this game, as it's a case of finding and killing tons of robots that love to just run up at you. You have some objectives where you have to press this button or shoot that glowy thing, but all in all the combat is pretty easy to grasp. There is an upgrade system, which you get to use by using N.A.N.O. that you find laying around, or by killing enemies. Your starting weapons feature a machine gun and an energy gun that fires balls of energy, and use their own ammo. They can receive upgrades to have new functions (for example, the machine gun can become a shotgun or a grenade launcher).I've been enjoying the game since my friend purchased it for me, it reminds me a lot of Serious Sam. I have encountered one error, in where I entered a level to find every wall/floor/ceiling etc was invisible. I could see the skybox, and i could see some♥♥♥♥♥♥here and there but It was like I was floating in space. Apart from this odd experience... everything has been smooth. It runs well on my pc, which is fairly old. (GT 630 and 2.66ghz Quad Core (core 2) ).

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												It feels like I have been dropped into the 2000AD comic series. It's like being right there.I seriously love the way this game looks. The city graphics are second to none for me, but I haven't played all the most modern games. Combat is great, if a bit tough at times. Combat with robots is extreme sublime. Although slightly short it has become one of my favourite gaming experiences. I played the demo a few times. I have played though on hard difficulty twice. My second play through took 12 hours including DLC levels. My first play through took longer partly because I was gawping at all the graphics. Really though I feel I am there in the comics, like they came to life, and I am in it. Incredible feeling. Awesome engine and concept.Hardware for max settings;A good i5 and GTX650 Ti will keep frames rates above 25fps with settings maxed. It will be well over 25fps in many places. This type of hardware will keep it smooth in the most heated battles.Hint:Make the shotgun your first upgrade. It is a game changer. Take the railgun and RPG upgrades soon, as again they are game changers. (The railgun is the only long range fast weapon. Other weapon types I did not even try.)I used these weapons and all the combat gear upgrades.Minor bad point:One or two of the checkpoints are a bit far apart.My fight with the first boss nearly stopped me playing, but youtube showed me I had to use different weapons.One particular secret I can not work out. I could look it up online.Shame it is slightly short, even with the free DLC. I just haven't had enough for such a superb concept game. (It takes longer than Crysis to play though.)

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												It's pretty.  It tries to do something interesting with the weapon system.  That's about all the good I can say about it.The game mistakes "challenge" for "swarming you with several hundred tiny enemies".  Imagine HALO if The Archive had been the only part in the game.  Every single area area has tiny holes that are very obviously meant for the two tiny enemy types (walking tiny screwdriver, walking tiny chainsaw).  Attempts to create tension by having something run by just out of sight fall flat on its face and just make you groan, "goddammit not this♥♥♥♥♥♥again."  Literally every room has this happen.The offering of choice in weapon upgrades is purely illusory; if you don't take the specific upgrade paths intended by the designers, you are hilariously incapable of dealing with anything.  -EVERYTHING- is a bullet sponge.  There is very little variety in either location or enemies, and any rare moment of uniqueness is immediately spoiled by yet another uninspired slog through a sea of tiny screwdrivers and micro-chainsaws.  Many of the enemies are supposedly maintenence/industrial robots gone haywire, but the designs for the most part make no sense for their setting.  What in the world are all these bipedal chainsaws supposed to be used for?!  Speaking of things with no use, apparently everything in the future explodes in horriffically dangerous ways with the slightest provocation.  Not only that, you are expected to make use of all these wacky exploding background bits despite initially working for the city.The game tries desperately to invoke the difficulty of "old school" shooters almost as a badge of honor.  It fails miserably.  I can, to this day, pick up and play Doom 1 & 2 and other old shooters that Hard Reset claims to strive to be.  I really tried to give this game a chance, but it just falls flat.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												What to say about this title. I enjoyed it a lot but overall it fell short in my opinion. The weapons, even though there are only two base units, are very varied and enjoyable to use. The gameplay was not bad, but it was not outstanding either. It is fairly monotonous and very repetitive. The enemies are so so, they are all the same and do the same things. That being said the true enjoyment in the title is that it is a real challenge, like not even fair sometimes challenging. If you do not like games that kick you when you are down and steal your lunch money you will not like this. The world is very interesting; I loved the design of everything. I would have liked more enemy varieties but that is personal preference. But where this fell flat for me was in the story… there is none. Where there was any it didn’t make too much sense and the ending has an “Ok where is the rest of it” feel.I can’t recommend this at full price as in my opinion it has too many flaws, but the beauty of the  aesthetics and the joy of overcoming the challenge may well be worth it to some people. Either that or the unbelievable frustration will make you want to set something on fire.Well worth a play but don’t feel the need to finish it, seriously it's not worth it. It left me feeling hollow.Have fun? ^_^

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												Hard Reset is a great game to spend time and beat. It has loads of secrets and achievements for completionists. Very fluid combat system as well, for the FPS-junkies. Good story if you want to follow the plot. The weapons are basic when you start out- A kinetic rifle and an energy rifle. Both have 4 different uprades (same with your defensive items) and 3 sub-upgrades, so each playthrough can be a little different from the last. Every level has a lot of enemies which always makes you feel like 'OH SH!T' every time you see a large group, and they always know you're there, so no super-sneaky type stuff either. *tip* invest in the railgun/shotgun early on to help out with tougher enemies.The only complaint is that the game is far too short, even with the DLC. Not to mention they left the ending in a cliffhanger type deal, leaving the player to imagine what happens next.But overall, 8.9/10

												What infuriates me about this game is how it tries to force you to use the environment. Weapons are deliberatly dumbed down to peashooter damage, goodluck trying to kill anything with them, even the smaller enemies are bullet sponges. This along with some god awful level design means its a pretty mediocre experience. The game often puts you in very awkward situations where you're cornered by several enemies at once in sometimes very tight spots. The smaller enemies shred through your HP regardless of difficulty mode along with their bulle and on top of that, the game uses checkpoints and no save option, I've had to replay through the same annoying section time and time again, it did not feel enjoyable in any way. This is only 2 hours in but honestly, I can't keep going through it. Please developers, learn how to make your levels evenly spaced out if you're going to litter them with enemies, DONT put me in a corridor shooter situation. Doom's levels can teach you a thing or two about the importance of open space. Admitidly  I was fascinated by its aesthetic choice, the art style is very appealing to me and it looked interesting but the gameplay just doesn't cut it.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Hard Reset is a classical FPS wrapped in new clothing, and it does indeed rock the new outfit.Pros: - me likes the graphics, serving the atmosphere well and having one or two pretty cool effects to offer - slight RPG elements, but nothing to slow down the pace - straight forward strafing and shooting - awesome enemies, a bit dumb, but that hyasn't stopped Serious Sam from being great ;) - comic book cutscenes with above par voice over - there definitely went some thought into the level designCons: - absolutely nothing new in terms of story or gameplayVerdict:Hard Reset is a shooter for those melancholic about the old school of FPS. Bringing the classic gun handling and mobility from the 90s back, all nonsense is thrown overboard for a clean and fast paced action FPS that can surely hold its own.While it never excels in any one aspect, it does manage to keep you playing thanks to smooth gameplay and satisfying action, accounting to an overall very pleasant, some times Dark Soulsesque, game experience.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												As others have mentioned, Hard Reset is something of a throwback to older FPS titles. While this isn't entirely accurate, it mostly is. There are some modern FPS trappings like invisible walls and the checkpoint save system. Challenge-wise it is definitely more like the older games. There is no arrow pointing you in the correct direction, or lengthy tutorial. It more or less throws you right into the action. There is a storyline along the way, which plays out in some very nice comic book-style cutscenes between levels and in-game dialogue via your radio. The cut scenes play while the game is loading, and you can skip them once the next level is done loading. You aren't forced to sit through them every time you play. One other thing about this is that the voice acting is pretty awful, even cringe-worthy at times. This is one of my main drawbacks and by far the worst part of the presentation, which, along with the graphic style, is otherwise one of the high points of the game.The game is still relatively linear but there are still some things left to figure out on your own. There are numerous secret areas and uncovering some of them can take some time. This is a nice touch that is missing from modern FPS games. One thing that is missing is quality puzzles. There just isn't much to speak of as far as puzzle solving goes. Aside from the secret areas, for the most part it never gets more complex than "find and hit a switch". That's not to say that's a bad thing, but it's missing that element of old school FPS games. The combat generally takes place in one of two settings: long narrow corridors with groups of enemies rushing at you from one end, and wider open areas where larger encounters take place. The enemies, which comprise of a variety of robots, tend come at you in waves, kind of like how Serious Sam works. Hard Reset doesn't throw nearly as many enemies at you though. There is a fair amount of enemies and each one tends to come in several varieties. Along with the game's 10 different weapon types, there is enough variety in the enemies and the ways to take them out that combat never becomes boring.There are multiple boss encounters along the way and they can be quite challenging. I played through it on the hard difficulty setting and most bosses I had to do multiple times. You can't just focus on the boss, as most of them spawn groups of the smaller enemies that kill you pretty quickly. The bosses typically have a glowing points that you have to blow up, so you have to pay attention and aim carefully (unless you acquire a certain weapon that will lock in and fire homing projectiles).You'll unlock multiple new weapons as well as upgrades to your health, armor and other attributes along the way. New weapons and upgrades are purchased spending at upgrade stations you find periodically throughout the levels. The game's currency, known as Nano, is earned by killing enemies and by finding it hidden in secret around the levels. I feel like a couple of the weapons and upgrades aren't very useful, and towards the end of the game you'll probably find yourself upgrading certain weapons or abilities just because you have upgrades to burn rather than because you need them. The new content unfortunately didn't add anything new to your arsenal. I feel like that's a wasted opportunity to add even just a few new upgrades. Overall I enjoyed my time with Hard Reset. I actually plan on going back and playing it again at some point down the road. That's rare for an FPS game. There is plenty to do, with multiple game modes and difficulties. There is also an achievement system if that's your thing. This is the best FPS game I've played since FEAR, and you'd be hard-pressed to find a better FPS to spend your money on.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												This is a very enjoyable shooter with lots of action, amazing graphics and a wonderfully authentic cyberpunk-atmosphere, but it's somewhat let down by an erratic difficulty and a relatively short campaign.I am left with the feeling that Hard Reset's title is not a reference to the game's plot or gameplay, but to the videogame industry as a whole. The developers are applying a "reset" to the entire FPS genre, stripping away or outright mocking several modern shooter staples.Hard Reset isn't a bad game, but it's rote old school sensibility has passed me by. I don't have the same kind of reflexes I did 5 or 10 years ago to properly appreciate the twitch elements, so maybe I have to take some responsibility on that front. For me, Hard Reset is unremarkable because it seems about 5 years too late for me.Overall, this is a game that does exactly what it sets out to do: be an oldschool manshoot, but with modern elements in the mix that make it more enjoyable, and a suitably wild Cyberpunk plot (albeit without any real hacking... ah, well, can't have everything).

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Hard Reset is a classical FPS wrapped in new clothing, and it does indeed rock the new outfit.Pros: - me likes the graphics, serving the atmosphere well and having one or two pretty cool effects to offer - slight RPG elements, but nothing to slow down the pace - straight forward strafing and shooting - awesome enemies, a bit dumb, but that hyasn't stopped Serious Sam from being great ;) - comic book cutscenes with above par voice over - there definitely went some thought into the level designCons: - absolutely nothing new in terms of story or gameplayVerdict:Hard Reset is a shooter for those melancholic about the old school of FPS. Bringing the classic gun handling and mobility from the 90s back, all nonsense is thrown overboard for a clean and fast paced action FPS that can surely hold its own.While it never excels in any one aspect, it does manage to keep you playing thanks to smooth gameplay and satisfying action, accounting to an overall very pleasant, some times Dark Soulsesque, game experience.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
TL;DR at BottomIf you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!A Throwback to rememberRecommended Purchase


Hard Reset 
A Screenshot of Hard Reset
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




Hard reset is a morbid and gritty first person shooter set in a decrepit world that seems to have been taken over by soldiers made from a fusion of man and metal. The story is so incredibly vague and Hard Reset gives you so little to go on that the whole way it feels like you're being teased with what could have been an amazing story of a dangerous trek through a volatile and almost dystopian city. Instead you're left wondering about the context of some of the character exchanges and even in some cases, who these characters are. Seeing as there's no introduction to most of these characters you don't know whats going on half the time and the other half you're still trying to understand the last cutscene. A very important aspect of Hard Reset is that the developers took a very heavy inspiration from old style FPS games such as Shadow Warior, DOOM, and Duke Nukem and it really shows all throughout.


Boom 
A Screenshot of Hard Reset
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




As I mentioned before the story is pretty sparse and when you end up being given story segments they're pretty lackluster and hard to understand. This means that Hard Reset essentially has little to no story or character development throughout the whole game. In this case however, I personally would say that Hard Reset is better with no story since that isn't what the game is focused on. Instead, since Hard Reset is essentially an old-school shooter from the 90's, the games main focus is on gameplay and mechanics rather than story and character development. Speaking of game mechanics, Hard Reset really feels like a classic FPS that's taken that genre and fine tuned it with modern game mechanics that are implemented in such a way that they subtly enhance gameplay without driving away the classic feeling. A huge downside to the game is that the level design is absolutely horrendous for a classic FPS since every level is incredibly linear with only a handful of side areas to explore and most of those aren't even side areas but instead are secret rooms with loot in them. This was incredibly disappointing since the environments the game lets you explore are absolutely gorgeous and would have been absolutlely stunning to explore. All the levels feel like you're window shopping at your favorite store; you see all the cool stuff but you have to just stay outside and look.


Away we go 
A Screenshot of Hard Reset
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




A critical mechanic in old-school shooters is gunplay and that's something that Hard Reset has absolutely nailed. You're only weapons are a futuristic plasma rifle and a run of the mill machine gun but both of the guns can change into one of many different forms. The plasma rifle can change into a rail gun or can let you see through walls and the machine gun can change into a shotgun or a rocket launcher. This unique take on gun mechanics makes Hard Reset very memorable and since you have to unlock every different firing mode, each one feels like an achievement to unlock and a powerhouse to use. The enemies you fight, as I mentioned earlier, are these macabre robot-human fusion monstrosities that range from being normal foot soldiers all the way to being giant mechs that are ten stories tall. Each different enemy type has different weaknesses to various different guns and you have to find those weaknesses and really push them to your advantage if you want to survive the later levels. My main problem with the enemies of Hard Reset is that there's only three or four different types of them and they start to get repetitive very quickly. Hard Reset could have been so much better if they just would have had a few more enemy types and made the game much less linear.TL;DRHard Reset creates an immersive world dominated by abominations of flesh and machine and throws you into it with nothing but guns and an attitude.If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to join my Steam Curator Group at  Mudkips Gaming

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												A very unbalanced game design that will often have you killed because you were kicked in a corner and unable to move away, or enemies will spawn behind you without warning, and the enemies are boring. But the weapons are really fun.To be a bit more honest, that game suffers from 4 very bad problems :- the enemies are all faster than you. You can sprint to bypass that peculiar issue, but given that you can only sprint forward, that the levels are quite small, and that you can't shoot while sprinting, it's basically useless,- the levels are very beautiful, but sadly, they are filled with invisible walls. Graphically, you're moving in a futuristic town, but in fact, the game could just be a bunch of rooms and corridors,- I do not know how explosions are programmed, but a wall will never protect you from an explosion. I did the test of hiding myself in a container (three walls and a roofs) and yet I still took damage from explosions,- and the most annoying problem : that blur each time you get hit. No matter if that missile took 75HP or one, your screen will get blurred, making it impossible to see how your health is. And if you're ganged up on by enemies, you're done for. They'll constantly knockback you and kill you extremely quickly.Otherwise, enemies are fairly challenging, with a very decent tracking (that's a nice way to say "you'll fail almost every evade and get charged by that giant angry robot"), but your weapons are diverse and powerful enough to not turn the fights into a chore.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Great little first person shooter that combines fun old-school gameplay with strong enemy design (gameplay wise), strategic use of environmental damage, crisp graphics and an addictive weapon-update system that builds towards a very nice arsenal of weapons. The story is simple and complicated at the same time, it doesn't do much more than setting an atmosphere and showing some nice hand-drawn pictures. There isn't much variety in scenery other than a welcome switch halfway through and even the gameplay can be somewhat repetitive. However... it really is "lots of fun to play for an hour a day". The game is hard from the beginning (but luckily has well-placed checkpoints), forcing you to make maximum use of the hazards in your environment, save for upgrades, switch up your weapons and run around like crazy, resulting in a very satisfying payoff when you get through a tough fight. The perfect way to start or end your day.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												This is a very enjoyable shooter with lots of action, amazing graphics and a wonderfully authentic cyberpunk-atmosphere, but it's somewhat let down by an erratic difficulty and a relatively short campaign.I am left with the feeling that Hard Reset's title is not a reference to the game's plot or gameplay, but to the videogame industry as a whole. The developers are applying a "reset" to the entire FPS genre, stripping away or outright mocking several modern shooter staples.Hard Reset isn't a bad game, but it's rote old school sensibility has passed me by. I don't have the same kind of reflexes I did 5 or 10 years ago to properly appreciate the twitch elements, so maybe I have to take some responsibility on that front. For me, Hard Reset is unremarkable because it seems about 5 years too late for me.Overall, this is a game that does exactly what it sets out to do: be an oldschool manshoot, but with modern elements in the mix that make it more enjoyable, and a suitably wild Cyberpunk plot (albeit without any real hacking... ah, well, can't have everything).

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												As others have mentioned, Hard Reset is something of a throwback to older FPS titles. While this isn't entirely accurate, it mostly is. There are some modern FPS trappings like invisible walls and the checkpoint save system. Challenge-wise it is definitely more like the older games. There is no arrow pointing you in the correct direction, or lengthy tutorial. It more or less throws you right into the action. There is a storyline along the way, which plays out in some very nice comic book-style cutscenes between levels and in-game dialogue via your radio. The cut scenes play while the game is loading, and you can skip them once the next level is done loading. You aren't forced to sit through them every time you play. One other thing about this is that the voice acting is pretty awful, even cringe-worthy at times. This is one of my main drawbacks and by far the worst part of the presentation, which, along with the graphic style, is otherwise one of the high points of the game.The game is still relatively linear but there are still some things left to figure out on your own. There are numerous secret areas and uncovering some of them can take some time. This is a nice touch that is missing from modern FPS games. One thing that is missing is quality puzzles. There just isn't much to speak of as far as puzzle solving goes. Aside from the secret areas, for the most part it never gets more complex than "find and hit a switch". That's not to say that's a bad thing, but it's missing that element of old school FPS games. The combat generally takes place in one of two settings: long narrow corridors with groups of enemies rushing at you from one end, and wider open areas where larger encounters take place. The enemies, which comprise of a variety of robots, tend come at you in waves, kind of like how Serious Sam works. Hard Reset doesn't throw nearly as many enemies at you though. There is a fair amount of enemies and each one tends to come in several varieties. Along with the game's 10 different weapon types, there is enough variety in the enemies and the ways to take them out that combat never becomes boring.There are multiple boss encounters along the way and they can be quite challenging. I played through it on the hard difficulty setting and most bosses I had to do multiple times. You can't just focus on the boss, as most of them spawn groups of the smaller enemies that kill you pretty quickly. The bosses typically have a glowing points that you have to blow up, so you have to pay attention and aim carefully (unless you acquire a certain weapon that will lock in and fire homing projectiles).You'll unlock multiple new weapons as well as upgrades to your health, armor and other attributes along the way. New weapons and upgrades are purchased spending at upgrade stations you find periodically throughout the levels. The game's currency, known as Nano, is earned by killing enemies and by finding it hidden in secret around the levels. I feel like a couple of the weapons and upgrades aren't very useful, and towards the end of the game you'll probably find yourself upgrading certain weapons or abilities just because you have upgrades to burn rather than because you need them. The new content unfortunately didn't add anything new to your arsenal. I feel like that's a wasted opportunity to add even just a few new upgrades. Overall I enjoyed my time with Hard Reset. I actually plan on going back and playing it again at some point down the road. That's rare for an FPS game. There is plenty to do, with multiple game modes and difficulties. There is also an achievement system if that's your thing. This is the best FPS game I've played since FEAR, and you'd be hard-pressed to find a better FPS to spend your money on.
