Posted: March 7, 2013
												A great shooter by a Polish indie developer. Story is a throwaway, but its shooting bits are just plain fun. Its visuals are stunning and dont shy away when compared to AAA titles. The (amazing looking) cyberpunk setting can get a bit same-y after a while, but the free DLC "Exile" adds outdoor levels that just even better. Said DLC also prolongs the story and on a difficulty mode other than easy, the game can be very challenging. Given its a PC-only title, graphics options are aplenty, and you should be able to tailor it to your computer specs well. My concerns with HR originally was only the fact that its checkpoint-based, but you can now quicksave (with a .ini file edit, yes, but at least you can).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												This game is somehow clean and classic, in the way that I remember early FPS campaigns to be.  It's got a ridiculous hard-boiled cyborg protagonist and a simple character progression system that rewards light exploration.  The lighting is pretty slick; the writing acceptable if you're nostalgic for 90's cyberpunk absurdism.  I love it.  It plays well, and the length is about right.  Few games are so purely focused on the gaming experience - there was little wrapper, because little was needed.  It has all the comforts of a modern title (checkpoints, minor regen of ammo/health), with all the punishing action of the oldschool spazfests that kept me up in high school.  Buy it.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2012
												A simple single player FPS without much depth or story, but enough mindless fun to keep you running from checkpoint to checkpoint shootin' robots, blowin' stuff up and using environmental hazards to your advantage. You get to buy a nice array of guns and upgrades and they really have a nice feel of power behind them.Enemy variety is extremely limited, but the campaign is short enough that it won't matter. The DLC is now included free and introduces a few new enemy types, another boss battle and extends the game by a couple of hours. I thought it was better than the original campaign, and easily wins best boss battle.Leaderboards, nice graphics with lots of settings, great gamepad support & over 100 Steam achievements. Solid experience but brings nothing new to the table.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												If you can look past the completely incomprehensible storyline and horrendous voice acting, there's an enjoyable game to be had here. The game looks, feels, sounds, and plays like something straight out of the Unreal franchise, especially Unreal Tournament 3, despite using a propriety engine (not UE3). In terms of gameplay, it's more along the lines of a Serious Sam game, eschewing cover, weapon reloading, and regenerating health for a more classic corridor shooter style. The gameplay can get extremely hectic once the waves of enemies start flowing -- this fun and frantic gamplay is Hard Reset's strong point, and is executed well.

												Some highs but many lows. First off the level design is cool at first but all stages seem the exact same after a bit. You only fight robots and while some are inventine, it throws so many of the same at you in waves you get sick of them and want more variety. The weapons are underpowered and even on normal difficulty one robot takes more damage than you. It sends 10 guys at you at once and it takes 3 shotgun blasts to kill one. Do the math and you realized you have to restart many parts which makes it very annoying. Most of the upgrades don't help that much. The story is muddled and uninteresting told in comic book form. The graphics and physics are good as well as using the environment to get kills. I tried it on hard but the difficult is impossible and is more frustrating than fun so I switched to medium. I would give it a  6.5/10

content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												One ofthe worst fps games I've ever played.Great setting, cool combat, etc....love the destructible environment....but fails on so many basic design levels its disgusting.I don't understand how these people managed to make shadow warrior a decent game because it sure doesn't show for this game.1. God awful maneuvering, you can't quick jump/dash away from a charging enemy.  All you have is a sprint, so if you want to strafe quickly you need to turn and sprint to the left or right.2. The scenarios are generally garbage....There are tons of explosives everywhere you'd think at some point they would say "Hey, maybe we should give our player some room to move around?",  Nope...you are always finding yourself in crowded environments full of boxes, crates, pipes, indestructible fences, etc.I got to one boss fight so far....was the most cringeworthy thing I've seen. At no point in time do you EVER have never ending enemies spawning in an FPS.  Thats absolutely lazy design.3. Every battle scenario is accompanied by cutting off your escape route....no running back, pacing yourself, etc.4. At no point in the time does the game teach you what or how the guns are used. I still don't understand and I'm just guessing that you work off their armor with one gun, then plasma blast them...but consistency isn't easy to find.5. No crouch....seriously....they added jumping but no crouch.6. Invisible walls everywhere to the point where the enviroment is very misleading and causes you to waste tons of time trying to jump around on things.7. Minor complaint, but the story is awkward.  You are not properly introduced to anyone or anything, its like literally jumping into the middle of a book.8. Terrible hit and collision detection.  Those gorrilabot things will still hit you with their charge despite them never physcially colliding with you.I'll commend them on the cutscenes, the compromise on a regenerating shield instead of health, decent voice acting, graphics, and destructible environment, and even cool combat when the game isn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on you...but the general battle scenarios suck.It gets very tiresome constantly being stuck in a crowded environment, with enemies swarming you because they seemingly pop out of nowhere.  If you are going to buy it, make sure you get it on sale.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Hard Reset Exteneded Edition (otherwise known as the finished product) is a sci-fi first-person shooter developed by Flying Wild Hog; a team consisting of a few members who worked on Painkiller. This was their first published title and you can tell that some aspects of the game were experimental or not fleshed out as well as it could be. Gameplay : The primary focus of the game is its gunplay. The game revolves around a kinetic weapon and a energy weapon with each having five separate forms and each form having an alternate fire function. The kinetic weapon functions as a rifle, a shotgun, a grenade launcher, a rocket launcher, and a proximity mine deployer. The energy weapon functions as a rapid-fire pulse rifle, a close-range lightning arc, an EMP grenade launcher, a sniper rifle, and a homing weapon. The weapon models look great, but it can get confusing in-game knowing which weapon is in what mode which can lead to some unwanted splash damage. Enemy variety is sub-par up until the later levels, where it upgrades to servicable. Another problem is that the enemy models, all of them robots, don't stand out against the environment often enough. The health system involves a non-regenerating health bar which can be replenished with medkits (some enemies can drop small medkits upon their defeat) and a shield system that regenerates when you're not under fire. The game also boasts a light RPG element where you spend currency to upgrade your armaments as well as your combat suit. There are also environmental hazards littered throughout the levels which you can employ to take out enemies. The few bosses in the game are a delightful distraction from the masses of robots you destroy as you progress through the stages. On a sidenote, the in-game interface is cleverly done since everything in the game is mouse-driven. Overall, the gameplay can keep you engaged through completion.The story is easily the weakest part of the game, with voice actors phoning it in and the plot convulutes itself to a lackluster ending. The level design is cyberpunkish buildings through two-thirds of the game until it changes it up with a more varied environment at the final third. However, the design is also very linear with "secrets" that can be found by turning the other corner before going down the beaten path. Technically, the game runs smoothly with a benchmark inside the extras menu of the game.I would recommend picking this one up if you want a shooter that doesn't adhere to the modern military standard. At time of writing, the developers have made plans to release a Hard Reset Redux Edition which would upgrade the game engine to its latest version, add a melee weapon, spruce up enemy variety, and change the overall pace and balance. It's up to you if you want to plomp down some spare change to play this game now or wait it out until they release the Redux Edition.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2012
												Mix Bladerunner with Quake 3 and you have Hard Reset. No multiplayer, no co-op option - just an out-and-out gun blazing FPS of killing multiple foes as quickly as possible.I very, very rarely say this - but Hard Reset is simply too difficult for its own good. The clue should be in the title - and that's when the game is set to Normal. Your arsenal of weapons is woefully underpowered (even, with upgrades too) and the opposing enemies are super-accurate - even over distance.FPS Gods will no doubt blitz through level after level without dying 4 or 5 times like I usually do. But for mainstream gamers - be warned. It will test the limits of your patience! :)That said, it is a good looking game and enjoyable too when you've had enough of online FPSs for a while.7/10

												Fun and pretty looking, its worth it's price tag. it can be completed relatively quickly, but its very entertaining. + Graphics are beautiful+ Envirnments are very well designed and (once again) beautiful+ gameplay is fun.+ Very tight controls+ glitch free+ lots of secrets to find+ interesting weapons split into two archetypes. + Large upgrade tree+ Weapons visibily change with each weapon mod. = Linear, but it works considering the gameplay- Some enemies are just frustrating to fight (like the charging ones, whom are stupidly difficult to dodge) - Money is rare, so choose your upgrades wisely. I can't even remember half their names.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												For guys craving a twitch shooter akin to Serious Sam and 3D versions of old school Duke Nukem and Shadow Warrior, this would be your jam. But for casual players looking to dabble in everything or just plain like shooters, there's so much wrong with it. There are no truly innovative ways to kill AI, some just soak up more bullets than others. I don't quite understand it. The story in itself is warped and beyond fixing. The characters are bland extrapolations of stereotypes in the countless games you've played before or movies you've seen. Objectives can be mundane and keep you confused as to what you're all really playing this game for aside from its stellar level and weapon upgrade design. It also relies on the gimmick of red barrels, which wears off after the first 2 levels. They fixed some of the issues (a CQC weapon & dodge mechanics) in the redux, and I would recommend that if you haven't gotten the Redux yet. Is it worth it after you upgrade it? No. The core gameplay and mechanics will be just as boring the first time you played it. You just get to dodge charges and get a sword that's only useful on Easy difficulty. It doesn't have a skill tree, so it feels like they just threw it in there. That, and the graphics look identical to its 2011 counterpark. Total cash grab.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Here's the problem with Hard Reset, plain and simple.  Is it hard?  Yep.  Is it a good or a fun hard?  No, it's really not.  It's cheap as all get out, and that's really not that much fun if you're into this kind of game.  Even if you're not it's not gonna be a bundle of joy.  Yeah, I know there's lots of reviews gushing over it - only conclusion I can come to is we have either a lot of people that are masochists or haven't played that much of it.1.  Cheap hitscan nonsense:  Yep, when they said oldschool they meant hitscan crap.  I.E. they're gonna shoot your♥♥♥♥♥♥off, and you can do nothing about it.  If they can remotely see you, they can hit you.  If they can't see you, they can still hit your half the time with homing missiles.  Dodging?  Lol no - it fires you get shredded, sorry man you shoulda taken cover!  Oh wait, there pretty much isn't any that works worth a damn as all the arenas are tiny and all the robots are 27 times faster than you are.  Awesome!2.  Does there really need to be a 2?  'Cause 1 made me TRY to refund this long ago, and get refused on it.  And yes, I played a good pile of hours on it trying to gut through.  Until I realized it wasn't fun - and it hadn't been since about the first half hour.  Oh... have I mentioned no saves, and some of the stupidest places for checkpoints I've ever seen?  Beyond awful placement.  Be prepared to redo ages of fighting, hope you enjoy that - cause it will happen - all the time.  Don't care if it can be hacked to be saved, that just means you can put a bandaid on their god-awful game design.  Yeah, great.3.  Seriously, this is just plain stacking unfair game advantage on you to simulate difficulty.  Difficulty is not giving the player junk tools and enemies that make the player feel about as effective as a toddler with a pellet gun.  Guns don't hit worth a darn, enemies will soak vast amounts of your ammo store barring specific guns.  This game is a good idea that either they got lazy on or just couldn't test with non-"I am leetzor I WILL PUT UP WITH ANY NONSENSE TO PROVE HOW BIG MY DIGITAL REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS ARE RRARR!" people. 4.  Before the usual "Git gud scrub" crowd starts in, games I do like and handle just fine are things like Serious Sam.  I tend to play my shooters on hard - and I've been playing this kind of thing since Doom.  But back in those days we had hitscan because it was all the tech could handle, and monsters and placement were carefully balanced to account for this.  In this case... not even close.  Not even a handwaved attempt at getting close.  Just "We're gonna overwhelm you with stuff everywhere that is stronger than anything you could ever manage, roflcopterbbq. "   This is a failed attempt at reproducing oldschool unless you want oldschool complete with all the bad elements the tech difference required added to a complete lack of care in level design beyond "Swarm them with stuff.  No, 10X the stuff with 50X the hitpoints.  That'll teach 'em!"5.  Unfortunately, the problems with this game remind unpleasantly of Fear 3 - another shooter I refunded pretty quickly for many of the same reasons.  Hitscan, unfair numbers and placements, bulletsoaking enemies beyond the point of laughability even, and a near complete lack of level design - replaced with sheer overpowered enemies and numbers of mobs well beyond any sense of fun.  Sorry about the length of this, but the level of disappointment here was vast - this coulda been interesting.  Instead, once you get past the shiny at the start you've pretty much got a travesty.  This just digs up oldschool's corpse, sticks a party hat on it, and poses it for some Weekend At Bernie's style action.*If the language in this review sounds like Ned Flanders getting irked at a game, blame the Steam censoring.  I've learned to type that way on here so my reviews don't become incomprehensible strings of hearts seperating the occaisonal and or the.  ;p

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												I honestly can't get into this game. Maybe I spent my nano on the wrong upgrades, maybe I'm just too old for frantic action, but it's just not working for me. I'd probably kick major butt fifteen years ago, but y'know, middle age and FPS don't go so well together.The main weapon - the assault rifle - might as well be shooting paper bullets, even upgraded with faster RoF. The shotgun seemed quite useless, and I stopped using the grenade launcher the moment I realized the grenade actually takes several seconds to explode. What I was aiming at was no longer there. The reload time is huge, so you can't even spam grenades for some carnage.I went for the mortar on the energy weapon, and while that did work on swarms of tiny robots, I have no idea if it's capable of doing ANY damage to bigger robots. It sure doesn't feel like it. I probably damaged myself more with it than I damaged them.There's probably a combination of weapons needed for certain enemy types. Like, shoot this with that weapon, use the other one upgraded to something to kill that thing, and then use a different upgrade for other weapon to do this and then finish the enemy off with that. This and that, here and there, it just didn't click with me. The weapons in general seem to lack "oomph". Note that I haven't played the game for a long amount of time, so maybe it gets better later.As far as level design is concerned, this is a linear corridor shooter, which isn't a bad thing by itself, but since there's lots of environmental debris and objects, I found myself getting stuck on things and quickly cornered. Since the enemies are very powerful even at the start, that means immediate death and then reloading from the checkpoint.Some things are very much rigged, and not in a good way; for example, you go down to a small room to pick up some nano, and then you get a swarm of robots spawning behind you. If you don't know they're coming, you're dead. When you reload from checkpoint, you're dead again, and maybe once more, until you realize that you need to use the energy mortar to shoot 2-3 points on the floor so it kills the little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s before they get to you.Then you go out and you're swarmed by more robots. Rinse and repeat.Then you enter a parking garage and die to another swarm of tiny robots.You reload, do the same thing again and again, kill everything, and suddenly you're swarmed by MEDIUM robots which the energy mortar won't do anything to, and everywhere you turn, you get stuck on a parked car and can't escape. Therefore, you die again, quit the game, go to Steam to write this review, uninstall the game and move it to a "Done" category in your Steam library.

												This is pretty decent for a obscure FPS game. It is pretty innovative. Your two weapons do everything. When you switch weapons, it spins and uses a different attachment and is pretty cool. The energy weapons though are the highlight of the game: put your upgrades into them for the most fun. It has some crazy awesome weapons but only a few enemy types and the graphics are really kick♥♥♥♥♥awesome. It has some of the best effects I've seen in a game, although not coded perfectly so there is some slowdown sometimes with some effects but it is not that bad if you have a powerful gpu. It also provides a good challenge compared to most other fps games. Pick this up for some solid fun if you dig FPS games that break away from the norm and do it well. 7.5/10

Posted: December 20, 2015
This game is really good technically.  But is it actually fun to play?It looks great, controls easily, and runs super-smoth.  This game reminds me a lot of Serious Sam packed into Doom 3 levels.  If that sounds like fun, go for it.  For me, an hour was about the extent of my enjoyment before it just felt like more and more of the same.So do I recommend the game?  If you like this genre, I think it's really well made.  However, I felt like I had pretty much seen what the game had to offer after about an hour.  The levels are uninteresting.  The hordes of robots were boring.  It had none of the horror of Doom 3 but certainly the drab.  I don't think I am going to recommend this game, but it's not a bad offering for the genre.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2012
												Overall 7/10. It's a fun game, if a little difficult at times, and rather repetitive. Seems like a futuristic Serious Sam game to me. The graphics are gorgeous, and the gameplay is fast and frantic, but there's no duck or quick-save, and the beginning weapons are thoroughly useless by the end of the game, so don't waste upgrade pods on them. Environmental kills are fun, but not implemented very well. Campaign is 5ish hours total, and there is no multiplayer, so I'm glad I got it on sale.If you like your shooters fast-paced and frantic, give it a try. It's made by a new game studio, so I'm happy to support them. They will go far.

												Pros:- Graphics- Sound- Atmosphere- Demo availableCons:- Everything else- Gunplay is weak; guns feel like peashooters and thus you're basically forced to use the environment to kill enemies or invest into upgrades which feel rather gimmicky such as bullet time when you're low on health and secondary weapon fire for crowd control.- Physics are horrible; player feels floaty and gets stuck at pretty much everything when trying to jump over or get around something.Rating: 5/10I really wanted to like the game but even at a 90% discount I'm still sorely disappointed. In any case, try out the demo if you're interested.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Has a really nice game engine (presumably an advanced version of this was used to better effect in the later Shadow Warrior remake) but this game is dull, with enemies that blend in too much with the gunmetal grey / blue scenery. The plot (such as it is) is badly translated to the point of being incomprehensible and it's far too repetative in general.That said, the DLC chapters (the last five or so maps) improve significantly with more interesting environments but you'll struggle not to get bored before reaching them.Also, Technically I never managed to complete it, because beating the final boss caused my game to CTD every time. Not great.I'd avoid and instead maybe take a look at the developers more recent game, Shadow Warrior, which is a lot more interesting.Two C-beams glittering in the dark near Tanhauser Gate out of five.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												Red barrels - the videogame.Eh... I picked it up for 2 euros, so I can recommend it at the pricetag, but honestly, compared to Shadow Warrior (2013) this game is not very good for the most part.Especially if you get the wrong upgrades. Some weapons are useless even after you get the upgrades (looking at you, assault rifle). It wasn't until I painfully played through half the game when I realized, that the way to go here is to permastun enemies. Get all the CC upgrades, use RPG and railgun for dealing big damage, shotgun for wave clearing.There's not a lot of enemy variety either. You got the little annoying ones, you've got the big charging ones, the rocket spammers and the scarabs. They do have a varied look based on how much armor they are packing, but at the end of the day they have the same abilities with a different paintjob.The enemies are bullet sponges as well. UNLESS, you use the red barrels to kill them. The game puts a lot of emphasis on that, rather than the gunplay, which is a shame. 1-2 red barrels can kill the bigges enemies, but if you try to do the same with your guns, it will take a long while. There are plenty of red barrels in the first few chapters, but later they get more scarce and therefore the fights are needlessly prolonged, because you are waiting for the day the spongy enemies will finally die.I also noticed a lot of inconsistency in this game. Sometimes the little sawblade enemies deal only like 20 damage, sometimes up to 80. I have no idea wtf going on whatsoever. Is it because of my shield? But even if my shield are full, I still lose HP when I'm hit. Is it proportional? Is the damage only halved? Are shields only protecting from ranged attacks? I have no idea what's going on.This game does one thing pretty damn well though, and that's the boss fights. The boss fights with Atlas and the Overseer from the Exile DLC are particularly well done. I really liked how I had to get the Overseer to suck in the barrels. That was a bit creative and unusual. Really good boss fight, that one. The parts of the game between the boss fights are really not enjoyable though.In conclusion you can very much tell that this is the studios 1st game. It was an experiment. I'd say play Shadow Warrior instead, if you haven't played already. That's a much much more polished version of all the ideas this game experimented with and therefore a thoroughly enjoyable game. Get this game only at a huge discount and only if you are very bored.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
Originally, i didn't like Hard Reset, and stopped after less than an hour.I didn't understand why there were only two weapons, nor why there was a separate command to select each. I didn't understand why i was moving from area to area, killing hordes of robots and i didn't understand why i was so bad at it...For the next few months, Hard Reset sat in my games list, with just 1 achievement, mocking me.Recently, I’ve been aiming for perfect games (a 100% achievement score), trying to increase my average completion rate. So with only one achievement, the time came back around to re-install Hard Reset, and try to bump my rating back up.After it was re-installed, i had the option to continue my last save, so i clicked the resume button, and in i went. Still on the first level, i continued my desperate struggle against the machines, and again, trying to make sense of the area to area robot horde killing gameplay.This is probably the point that changed the game for me. My next challenge was to fight one of the bigger robots (the kind that charges at you), and i hadn’t realised that i was being awarded points for destroying the enemies, as well as collecting the orange pickups. “A new upgrade is available” flashed on the screen, and having already seen an upgrade terminal, i quickly found the next one. I took a grenade launcher on the CLG Firearm.The controls need explaining. It’s Q to select the CLG Firearm and E to select the NRG Weapon, after you add a new function to each one, you’ll be able to select that function with a number, so for example, i would have the CLG firearm selected with Q, then to select the normal machine gun mode, you would press 1, the shotgun function would be 2, and for my newly acquired grenade launcher, i would have to press 3.Now i had an incentive to carry on. To become more powerful, i would have to continue, and the achievements had already started popping up in the corner. Then, i think i started to like Hard Reset, i was looking forward to getting past the next section, getting my next upgrade, and finding all of those delicious secrets.Currently, i’m playing it through on hard mode, which involves many re-tries. Every section is a case of trial and error. You go in, get horded, die, then retry, positioning yourself in a better place, to get past the first spawn. The second and third hordes of the area, will no doubt kill you again and again. Forcing you to retry, each time, remembering where the enemies come from, and to be ready, bottlenecking them with the scenery, and using the environment to your advantage.Hard Reset would probably describe itself as an environmental shooter, as half of the scenery is either explosive, or has electronics wired so badly that a light kick would force it to short out and electrocute everything in a 2 metre radius.So, my advice would be, to sit it out, play the first level to the end, try not to give up immediately. I understand now, why there are only two weapons, and generally how the game is compiled together giving the player individual challenges, and i understand why i struggled at first.The only thing i don’t understand now, is why i like this game so much.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Pretty good FPS! Old-school in the sense of Painkiller and Serious Sam, rather than DOOM and DukeNukem.The level design isn't as interesting as the latter, but the game still has room for a few secrets for you to uncover. Each weapon is unique, with various uses, although the slow upgrade system doesn't encourage experimentation with the weapons (it's balanced for you to have 80-85% of the upgrades by the end of the game).Still, even though it may take a while, each weapon is pretty satisfying. Wave uponh wave of enemies. The big problem is how resilient they are to damage. Even a rocket launcher is rather inneffective... Then again, I played on Hard mode. It's... really hard. Sometimes frustrating, putting high damage enemies with you into very small spaces. But, despite that big flaw, the game is still a hell of a lot of fun!Visually, it's nothing short of impressive, with a huge, cyberpunk city. The lighting system is pretty good as well.Then, there's the physic's system. It's a big part of what makes this game awesome to play! Everything explodes and breaks apart, and you can basically shoot everything long after they're dead. It gets a bit too resource intensive, but it's worth it.The levels are a bit too long to my taste (usually 40minutes +), seeing how much you die. Checkpoints are really unforgiving as well, with the game lacking a "quicksave" feature.But hey, if you're looking for a game that is purely about the shooting, with little other distractions, definitely check this out!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												The good:The graphics are very nice.The bad:Everything else.The writting is awful.The levels are very linear and telegraph what is about to happen.  IE: There is an area where you can enter and there is a short ledge you can jump down into (you can't get back).  What do you think is about to happen?  Yes, some kind of ambush / boss fight.  It is just very generic FPS game.  It offers nothing new or original.   The first big fight they throw at you is just waves of bots and followed by a few waves of bigger bots.  If these bots hit you, they take your shields down and hurt you somehwat (from a single hit).  The solution is obvious:  Stand on a car and just shoot the hell out of them. DOH!Anway, I am glad I picked this up at a super-discount on the winter sale.  Its not worth the download, let alone any price you would pay for it.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												I like this game. It looks great, sounds good, has a great atmosphere, and it's fun to blow up robots.But I don't recommend it, because it's hampered by a bunch of bad design decisions. There are lots of "Gotcha!" moments where enemies will spawn behind you, or you'll get locked into a closed space with a bunch of buzzsaw-bots. The checkpoints are way too far apart in places, and the game won't let you save without them.At first glance, this seems like a classic-style twitch shooter, but it's actually more about cycling through the cooldowns on your weapons efficiently and keeping dangerous enemies stun-locked while you whittle down their huge health pools. Your character doesn't dodge very quickly, and the environments have a ton of junk to get caught up on, which is frustrating.If you have a high tolerance for frustration, this game is worth your time.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2011
												The mechanics and graphics of the game are solid, with the 2 weapon upgrade system especially notable. However, this game often fails to let you go where you want to go, with no jumping while sprinting, and randomly placed invisible walls preventing you from deviating from the desired path, including to some secrets where you have to progress further before you're meant to come backtrack and then find them on that walk through. It also is unnecessarily punishing, with trips into dead ends for secrets (upgrade points) spawning waves from nowhere that mob the culdesac, with doors randomly locking behind you with a wave bearing down so you have nowhere to hide, and sometimes with enemies spawning in areas with no cover so you just have to pray your way through.I was playing on the hardest setting, so my fragility was probably enhanced, but little to no cover in some areas and the inability to jump things that you should be able to jump over, just ruined the game for me.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Ooh Hard Reset, how I love you. This game is great. Follows a semi-oldschool formula for level design and health managment. Difficulty is great, you can and will die.Graphics are beautiful, controls/settings are all good. Not everybody will be able to deal with actually dying in a FPS singleplayer nowadays but that's kinda why stuff like this has to exist. To remind us that you actually need to know how to play and understand you need to be efficient. Not every game needs to hold your♥♥♥♥♥♥into every fight.The only gripes I have for this game are some of the weapon upgrades are kinda bad (not worthless) compared to others and there are too few enemies. The same problem with flying wild hog's other game Shadow Warrior. They need to make about 5-10 more enemy types each game to avoid it getting repetitive. But the DLC area adds a few, and some amazingly pretty levels.8.5(+1/-1)/10 Must-play if you like real PC FPS games.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Just awesome!! I hated FPS's for the longest time; mostly this was due to me being a console gamer by whole life and I never understood the draw. But, Far Cry 3 changed all that for me and now its my favorite catergory. Hard Reset has only helped strengthen my opinion of the genre. The gameplay is so smooth that it is virtually flawless. If every FPS used Hard Reset's formula there would never be another bad FPS again. It also sets a very high bar for the game's developers. They now have to always make soemthing a little better than this. And I have to say that I wouldn't be surprised if they found that extremely challenging. I purchased the game on sale for 4.99 and I played it immediately (as opposed to the 5-6 games on Steam I have not yet played that I owned before this). I was blown away from the start. The only part of this game that is just ok are the cut-scenes' voice acting. The cutscenes animation is nice and stays true to the abstractness  and sci-fi feel of the story, but the writing and the voices could be better. However, you can skip the cutscenes after a sceond or two; the next levels/scenes load very fast!

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Incredibly great game, still don't know why it is so unknown. But think it may be these reasons:-The movement feels awkward.-The combat feels awkward.-Enemies have way more health than they should.-My guns doesn't feel powerful, i feel like i am using techno-peashooters.-The upgrade menu is counter intuitive, yes if you read carefully no mistakes are made, but you need to mouse over each item to show all information. (i spent half of the game using default "weapon mode" just upgrading "armor/ammo" before realizing that the first of each upgrade area were the actual weapons, i thought the "weapon mode" were going to be unlocked at some point, not manually)-Explosive attacks goes through walls, I seriously kept dying by enemy missiles BEHIND COVER.-Still have no idea what the ♥♥♥♥ i am fighting against. (Edit3: Robots i guess? characters just kept talking about external internal AI and technobabble)-Ambience noises that tear my auditory system apart. When these ambience sounds start i take my headphone off for a moment. (edit: these appear to be level specific)-When i was about to complain that enemies have too much health and weapons are weak, i got the energy area of effect gun and it is op, it stuns? or slows small enemies and then explode in an area, upgrade with ammo regen and you are op as hell. (edit: it still op as hell if enemies are all coming after you in a single corridor)-Besides these points the game is actually really great. I'm actually enjoying it so far.Edit1:I just beat the first boss, more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t unavoidable explosives, i just beat him because the xray gun told me the target to shoot.-I forgot to mention, the graphics are Sanctum 2 level of quality and polish, very beaultiful game.-It also has a comic book style of storytelling while loading like Sanctum 2. But this one is animated and voice acted.Edit2:-Also forgot to mention, the level design is mixed, seems good, but every enemy encounter follows this:1: Arrive in an area.2: The passage is closed behind you. cannot retreat.3: Enemies overwhelm you, just a clusterf uck from everywhere.4: If you manage to survive, collect loot and advance level.Goto 1 (AKA rinse and repeat)Edit3: I just beaten the game.-It is actually very well polished. lots of props plants and debris around.-Lots of detail everywhere. Very beautiful overall.-Very atmospheric.-Just the movement, combat and enemy that are awkward and feel unpolished.-The last boss was interesting and lame at the same time, i think my strategy was too good for it.-I am not even gonna try another playthrough, i can already predict that higher difficulty is the same but with less pickups and/or more enemy health.I'm talking bad about this game but i feel it is worth playing it.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												8/10Holy Crap this  is prolly the most action packed game I've ever played in my life. It's also a complete breath of fresh air for it reminds me of the good ol' days of first person shooters. Complete balls to the wall action , in your face,, tongue waging . bullet fueled Blood Fest.(ok there are no humans to kill only robots but you get the picture. I truly did enjoy this game. The Pros:Visuals: The game looks fantastic , awesome cyberpunk settingGameplay: God Damn is this game fun to play. Its incredibly relentless in its face melting greatness. Seriously it's like the most intense game I've played in forever . A++++++. Upgrades: you only have 2 weapons, you can upgrade the snot out of them . You want a rifle that can be upgraded to ihave shotgun/ rocket launcher/ seeker missile/ grenade launcher enhancements? well by all means sir help your self! Once this aspect comes into play, you'll find yourself using different techniques in battle by switching between these enhancements to your advantage. the price: at its full price of 15 dollars on steam it is VERY worth it, i can't say that often but in this case it is.Giant Bosses: Its to see a game where a boss can be 200 feet tall and make your jaw dropTHe Cons:Story: Now mind you, the story is not bad by any means, it just kind of gets loss in all the mayhemMusic: its kind of silly at times, but even so it makes obliterating waves of robots kind of funnyIn Conclusion, this game rocks and deserves your attention if you like playing videogames. Even the negative aspects i pointed out are very minor and can still be enjoyed to some extent. I Enjoyed my time in Hard Reset, and i know you will too.

												A fairly enjoyable game. I'm not a fan of old school fps gameplay, but this game refreshes the genre very well. content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												A fun, short little old school style FPS with real fast shooting and circle strafing, made by the same guys who made Shadow Warrior 2013. May not be the most polished or fancy game on the market, but still worth your time. The weapons are all varied and fun to use, and come with upgradeable characteristics that you can use to specialize your arsenal.The storyline is also surprisingly interesting, although it won't win any awards. Graphics are beautiful and the world is a mish mash of every single cyberpunk world you can think of. However, my main complaint is that the game doesn't have a HUGE amount of enemy variety and the level design can feel kinda boring and stale at times. However, this game is often on sale really cheap and totally worth it! I play it to warm my fingers up before CS.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												Excellent value for money on a sale! The story does end abruptly (even with the exile DLC), so here's hoping a sequel comes along.It starts off in a similar vein to Painkiller - waves of mobs, and you just have to mow them down. But it quickly morphs into a pretty decent sci-fi shoorter. Great cyberpunk atmosphere, gorgeous textures, and a somewhat interesting story (at least, it's better than Painkiller's excuse of a story...).It's a pity it ends as it does, but it's still a solid 5-10 hours of great FPS fun.Note that the exile DLC is just added on to the main campaign - so you won't realise you're playing the DLC. I was confused and thought there would be a seperate menu option to start the DLC, but no, it just seamlessly continues on from the main story.

												8/10Holy Crap this  is prolly the most action packed game I've ever played in my life. It's also a complete breath of fresh air for it reminds me of the good ol' days of first person shooters. Complete balls to the wall action , in your face,, tongue waging . bullet fueled Blood Fest.(ok there are no humans to kill only robots but you get the picture. I truly did enjoy this game. The Pros:Visuals: The game looks fantastic , awesome cyberpunk settingGameplay: God Damn is this game fun to play. Its incredibly relentless in its face melting greatness. Seriously it's like the most intense game I've played in forever . A++++++. Upgrades: you only have 2 weapons, you can upgrade the snot out of them . You want a rifle that can be upgraded to ihave shotgun/ rocket launcher/ seeker missile/ grenade launcher enhancements? well by all means sir help your self! Once this aspect comes into play, you'll find yourself using different techniques in battle by switching between these enhancements to your advantage. the price: at its full price of 15 dollars on steam it is VERY worth it, i can't say that often but in this case it is.Giant Bosses: Its to see a game where a boss can be 200 feet tall and make your jaw dropTHe Cons:Story: Now mind you, the story is not bad by any means, it just kind of gets loss in all the mayhemMusic: its kind of silly at times, but even so it makes obliterating waves of robots kind of funnyIn Conclusion, this game rocks and deserves your attention if you like playing videogames. Even the negative aspects i pointed out are very minor and can still be enjoyed to some extent. I Enjoyed my time in Hard Reset, and i know you will too.

												My expectations were pretty low when I bought this last month. Why did I buy it anyway ? I don't know why, I guess it's because of my love for games. Anyway, the game didn't disappoint. Not entirely, that is. First the good stuff; the graphics are of extremely high quality, especially for a downloadable game. I'm sorry to say, though, that there are the occasional framedrops during hectic firefights and explosions. The shooting works like a shooter should (see what I did there ?). Enemies come from all directions so you have to be careful at all times. The weapons and the upgrades are cool as well. The energy weapon I haven't used during the entire game, which is, by the way, about 3,5 hours long, so in my opinion they should've removed it. The controls are fine and the sounds are excellent, but the voice acting and story were weak. And the game ended when I actually thought I was about halfway, which is a shame. Worth the full price ? Nope. Wait for a 50% price drop.[Rating: 78/100]

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Hard Reset is an FPS in the vein of the genesis of FPS. Combat is quick and based around movement and lots of guns rather than cover and patience.Unfortunately it feels a bit clunky, you have a jump but it's basically useless and there is no crouch. Sprinting is fairly limited and the screen distorts so much you can't really see anything, leading you to often rush headlong into enemies. As expected you can unlock a plethora of weapons to help you along the way. There are 10 guns in total, each with an alternate fire. The weapons are split into two classes, one firing physical ammo the other firing energy. While I didn't use a number of the weapons or firing modes it was enjoyable to work out the best gun/mode combos for each enemy type. The weapons feel decent and some are pretty fun to use, but the swap time is agonizingly slow.The level design is that of a corridor shooter but the fact that it is essentially linear is a bit of departure from the days of yore. There are plenty of secrets tucked into corners or behind destructible walls but it's not like you'll be exploring vast open levels to find them. The world is heavily cyberpunk and takes place almost entirely at night in the rain. It looks pretty good for what I suspect is a pretty minimal budget. It's an interesting world that is severely undersold by the story. Mostly told between levels by clunky animated, poorly voice acted "cut scenes" done in a graphic novel style, the story is underdeveloped and poorly explained. I wanted to to care about the story and the world but I just couldn't get drawn in. It just feels like there was supposed to be so much more.The included DLC, Exile (previously Path to Exile or Extended Edition) is essentially more if the same. There are a couple new enemy types but one of the guns completely removes them as a threat. Partly through Exile I realized I was just grinding and going through the paces.In the end Hard Reset is just a bit shallow. The potential is there for a much more engaging experience but it just doesn't deliver. If you're a fan of circle strafing this is probably a must have but for generalists or people looking for a deeper cyberpunk world this is a bargain bin/bundle pick up.


YouTube™ Video: Cheap & Cheerful - Hard Reset 

			Views: 26		

			This week a modern game with old-school roots. Dev Link: http://www.hardresetgame.com/ Steam Link: http://store.steampowered.com/app/98400/ All music is in game music.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												A very fun game with many of the FPS tropes like being in an empty room, hit the objective, and suddenly a fight for your life. Environmental kills abound since the level designers use them as props as well.You have 2 main weapons, a bullet-gun, and an energy-gun. You can upgrade them to have up to 5 "modes" with each mode having an alternate ability. I only used the energy gun twice when the bullet gun ran out of ammo, so I can't say how it works fully.The bullet gun has a machine gun mode (alternate zoom), shotgun mode (alternate EMG mini-grenades that stun whatever they hit), grenade launcher (alternate gravity well that sucks enemies in and traps them in a small space), RPG (alternate laser guided), and proximity mine (alternate manual detonation).The ammo system is a shared pool, in that all of the bullet gun modes use bullet ammo, just in varying quantities based on the strength of the mode. RPG using the most and machine gun using the least. So no running around for machine gun ammo when you have 40 grenades lying around.You start with just the machine gun mode on the bullet gun mode, and the default energy gun mode, and collect orange upgrade packs lying around called 'N.A.N.O.' which come in large or small sizes. Once you have enough of them, you can upgrade your gun for an additional mode, add an alternate fire, or pimp the primary fire out more. Small N.A.N.O. packs are all over the place and are like a trail of breadcrumbs in some otherwise hard to navigate areas. The larger N.A.N.O. packs are usually hidden behind crates, breakable walls, or areas you have to parkour to.There are some really OP combinations with the guns, like using the gravity grenade to hold trash mobs together in a bottleneck, then kill all of them with one grenade. Because the explosion from the grenade breaks the gravity well, for a larger charging mob, you hold them with the gravity grenade, then hit them with an RPG for a one-hit-kill. I would recommend getting the shotgun, grenade launcher, grenade alternate fire, RPG, then the laser guided alternate. Towards the end of the game you will pretty much need the RPG to take out some really annoying flying mobs. Proximity mines are fairly lackluster and use ~40 of your maximum 240 ammo for one proximity mine.As for the story, it uses a graphic novel format between levels, with basically no story told during gunplay. The ending doesn't really feel like one. Kinda like the ending to Half-Life 2: Episode 2, the devs called it an ending, but they player is left wanting more.All in all, it's a fun game if you just wanna shoot a bunch of robots in a future dystopia setting.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												Woefully underrated, Hard Reset could be considered a cyberpunk version of Painkiller. While not as fluid as Painkiller, the combat in HR is still enjoyable. Environmental kills are plentiful, the enemies have unique visual styles, the graphics are pretty, and the weapons are fairly cool.The story is forgettable; I've played through HR twice and still don't know what it was about. Which is fine because the combat is what kept me entertained. The levels are confusing at times, and the art style sometimes obscures the route forward. But, at the same time the art style is pretty enough that taking time to check stuff out can be a nice break from the combat.Overall, Hard Reset is great for people who enjoy run and gun action, but may not appeal to many others. It can seem difficult at times, but if you're resourceful, you'll usually find a way to use the environment to your advantage.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												This game is so bad...It tries to copy Serious Sam but in a totally BAD and annoying way. It wants you to shoot 50K enemies per level, but all of the fights/encounters lack the fun element thats been replaced by the annyoing element. Once the fighting starts, you dont really understand much thats going on on the screen, as it immediatelly fills up with a gazillion effects that would normaly add to a game, but in this case, its WAY too much and that is causing the exact opposite effect. It also almost forces you to use the environment to kill off the hordes of enemies, but because of a lack of imagination, its counter- productive and intuitive. They tried to fill it up with everything that was good in other shooters, but ended up with a bad stew. You cant just take all the good things from other shooters (or whatever other genre) and throw them together into your game, thinking its gonna be perfect. All those elements need to have a certain sinergy and that sinergy is influenced by the creative mind of the developer where he uses various bridges to link those elements together.I could go on for another half an hour about why this game is bad, but its one of those things that no matter how many of the flaws you mention, they are just to many to overlook or to fix thru patches or DLCs.The only nice thing about the game is the graphics... but as Indie games have proven time and time again, you dont need Crysis/Battlefield/CoD/etc type of graphics to build an encredibly fun game.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Edit: Also, there's a Redux out now that apparently fixes basically every issue I had with this game aside from the attempt at a story, so you should really just get that instead.The game looks great, has a neat concept with the evolving guns, and the core gameplay is doom/quake/sam style arena/horde shooting on a solid engine. However, this is all hampered by a slew of bad level design, especially since, despite having evolving guns that often leave you geared for specific approaches depending on how you build them up, many areas are built around a specific approach that you may have no real way of accomplishing (The most notable coming to mind being that you can gear yourself specifically for a run-up-and-blast-em sort of approach, only for one level to consist entirely of enemies on unreachable platforms 100-200 feet away.)Likewise, enemies dip far too into the bullet sponge variety. The game is also incredibly short, barely 5 hours even with the expansion, and rather than going the smart route of "Here's an opening cutscene briefly setting up a premise, now go shoot things.", there's a story that barely makes any sense scattered across cutscenes throughout the game that only serves to unnecessarily break the action.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Hard Reset is a laudable independent attempt at capturing the feel of classic-inspired "horde" first person shooters like Painkiller and Serious Sam. The early sensations are great, with a lush-looking Blade-Runner inspired aesthetic and a combat based on detonating strategically placed environmental hazards that will help you stop the hordes of robots running in your direction.Unfortunately, that initial interest doesn´t last much longer. The gameplay turns up extremely shallow and repetitive by the third level, with the same hazards, enemies and pacing (get stuck in arena, kill all enemies, walk until next arena) over and over until the end of the game. The storytelling is dull, the extremely noisy and constrasty visuals full of flashing lights make almost impossible to realize what's happening on screen during the chaotic battles, so you just shoot randomly at moving things. There is barely anything during the game that will surprise you, so whereas the controls are comfortable and the game feels quite polished, the experience will be the exact same from the first to the last minute. "Hard Reset" is a clear example of a one-trick-pony of a game.I'd recommend you to play the demo, but I wouldn't spend any money on the full game, since the game deflates almost since the beginning. A somewhat short game that will feel like takes too long to end out of the sheer repetition you'll feel along the journey.

												A graphical tour de force, a playability tour de suck...Checkpoint-based save system; 10 confusingly-accessed, visually indistinct weapons, mostly of the "too weak" variety; an "enhanced vision" mode that kicks in when you're about to die, and makes it 10x harder to see anything (...and that's *besides* the "strawberry jam" effect that appears with equal intensity, whether you are hit for 95% of your health, or 5% of your health!); and a pompous, annoying narrator riding you the whole way -- this game has it all!YMMV and there's certainly worse games out there for ~$5, but ... as cool as it is, it's far from perfect.Gaming press made it sound like the 2nd coming of "old school", but it ain't all that, either. content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Hard Reset is an fps in the Serious Sam/Painkiller style of shoot everything around/in front of you. Though it doesn't nearly do it as well as those games sadly. It has really nice visuals in the first levels reminiscent of Blade Runner and has some really nice sound design to go with it. The cons begin with the gameplay leading into a limit of 2 weapons with a strange upgrade system, with upgrades sharing the same ammo for some reason. If one gets the awkward weapon system down, the gameplay gets pretty straightforward and while this game is on the lower end of my recommendation spectrum, I still did have a little bit of fun with this title.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2013
												A graphical tour de force, a playability tour de suck...Checkpoint-based save system; 10 confusingly-accessed, visually indistinct weapons, mostly of the "too weak" variety; an "enhanced vision" mode that kicks in when you're about to die, and makes it 10x harder to see anything (...and that's *besides* the "strawberry jam" effect that appears with equal intensity, whether you are hit for 95% of your health, or 5% of your health!); and a pompous, annoying narrator riding you the whole way -- this game has it all!YMMV and there's certainly worse games out there for ~$5, but ... as cool as it is, it's far from perfect.Gaming press made it sound like the 2nd coming of "old school", but it ain't all that, either.  Sometimes, I'm just like ... "what school did these guys go to?!"  Seems like it was probably abusive...

												A first person shooter against robots in a tremendously pretty Cyberpunk world.  The gameplay itself involves an awful lot of running backwards, akin to Serious Sam; there is not the first person bullet hell sort of dodging of Doom, nor the super-speed running and flanking of Painkiller.  But the setting is absolutely breathtaking, and the explosions satisfying and explodey.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Hard Reset is a slick, unforgiving FPS that feels ripped from the genre's roots. Were it not for the updated graphics and more responsive controls, you'd swear this direct was kin to Wolfenstein, Doom, and Quake. Coat it in a lusciously dystopian cyberpunk coat of paint and you've got me by the sensitive bits; just be aware that Hard Reset is liable to kick you in those bits just as readily.Pulling no punches, Hard Reset puts you in the shoes of Fletcher, hands you a strange energy weapon full of upgrade potential, and then starts lobbing wave after wave of robotic foes at you with little time to breathe in between. Action becomes stick-and-move most of the time as you work your way around each level, avoiding fire more than taking cover from it and taking as much advantage as you can of the environment. That environmental element was probably my favorite aspect of the game, as traditional exploding barrels are joined by things such as electrical boxes that can short out your opponents, and just natural-feeling static elements like barriers and columns that can, to some degree, help control enemy direction and flow.Unless you've been maintaining your twitch reflexes since FPS' toddler days or you're gifted with ungodly reaction time, Hard Reset is likely to kick you around quite a bit at first. Stick with it, though, and explore your upgrade options for your weapon. Once you've gotten the feel for the game's flow and found a setup that suits your needs, things start thrumming like, well, machinery.

Weapons aren't great, but they are fun.  Bougtht this game during the steam sale .. and have no regrets.  I wish there was co-op multiplayer and better weapons.  If hard reset and borderlands had a baby it'd be awesome!!!

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Hard Reset is a laudable independent attempt at capturing the feel of classic-inspired "horde" first person shooters like Painkiller and Serious Sam. The early sensations are great, with a lush-looking Blade-Runner inspired aesthetic and a combat based on detonating strategically placed environmental hazards that will help you stop the hordes of robots running in your direction.Unfortunately, that initial interest doesn´t last much longer. The gameplay turns up extremely shallow and repetitive by the third level, with the same hazards, enemies and pacing (get stuck in arena, kill all enemies, walk until next arena) over and over until the end of the game. The storytelling is dull, the extremely noisy and constrasty visuals full of flashing lights make almost impossible to realize what's happening on screen during the chaotic battles, so you just shoot randomly at moving things. There is barely anything during the game that will surprise you, so whereas the controls are comfortable and the game feels quite polished, the experience will be the exact same from the first to the last minute. "Hard Reset" is a clear example of a one-trick-pony of a game.I'd recommend you to play the demo, but I wouldn't spend any money on the full game, since the game deflates almost since the beginning. A somewhat short game that will feel like takes too long to end out of the sheer repetition you'll feel along the journey.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2013
												It's obviously not the 90's throwback we were promessed, but for a modern FPS, I don't think you can have a more oldschool gameplay.The weapon system is confusing at first but once you get used to it, it's a lot of fun.Don't miss the free DLC as well, it's 3 hours long but is overall better than the original game.The only bad points for me are that, even if the action does feel more 90's, the level design is still very linear, and a few secret rooms here and there can't make up for that. Also all the visual effects can get annoying and can make it hard to see what's going on in the middle of a fight, I recommend tuning them down as much as possible in the settings.Good game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												It's a first-person shooter, set in the future, with secret places, exploding barrels, hordes of enemies increasing in difficulty from start to finish, and a grading system at the end of each level. You also get to upgrade things periodically. If that sounds really generic, and like a bunch of other video games have done it already, then that's because it is generic, and a bunch of other video games really have done it already. Quake 4 comes to mind as the next closest thing, because Doom 3 at least plays with darkness and balancing the flashlight and the other weapons and Red Faction: Armageddon at least has vehicles you can drive. Even Painkiller, which has the same linear gameplay and horde battles as Hard Reset, has you turn into a demon and get instant kills (not to mention it has much more imaginative weapons). In summary, if you've played a sci-fi FPS before, you are prepared enough for the things to which Hard Reset will expose you, and if you liked the other games you played along those lines, you'll probably like Hard Reset, too. Get it while it's on sale.

												SO I'm giving this a no as in "would I recommend this to myself".As a shoot em up, this is ok.  If you like Painkiller I guess you might like this.  Mindless shooting, barely a thread of story etc.  The boss enemies were cool.  Graphics were pretty yummy. However the mechanics of this game.  Press button, kill enemies, try to press button, kill more enemies.  There are about 6 enemies in game total, they just throw more and more at you. I guess if you had never played Quake 2, and wanted something similar, this would be it.  Bearing in mind, Quake 2 is over 15 years old, and is a better game with better AI.Oh, yeah, it's less than 4 hours gameplay, with in my opinion zero replayability (i.e. I'm deleting it as soon as I close this review)

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game had great promise, an oldschool style FPS with some modern twists, but ultimately I felt it falls short. The game is does manage to execute one or two of the oldschool elements, but after multiple levels of the same secret room and enemy popping out of a wall it really wears thin.I started on medium difficulty but due to how long it took to actually kill the enemies I lowered it just to speed things up. The game has about 6 different types of enemies that amount to nothing more than bullet sponges. Which would be fine if the guns were any fun to fire. The upgrade system was a good idea, but you end up only using 1 or 2 of the weapons which makes the reset of the upgrades worthless in the end. I did manage to finish the game, which says soemthing, but really I would say your time is better spent on a different FPS.

number of helpful: 12 of 26 people (46%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												The good news is that I really like the art style and visual design of the game (it looks great, with lots of little details hidden in the levels on posters and signs and so on, and the cyberpunk theme is a lot of fun), and it mostly feels good to play, like an old school shooter. If that's all there were to it, it would be great, but there were a few things that added up to stop me from finishing the game.It's a "hard" game, which in itself can be a good thing, except it's not really hard because it's challenging but because there are situations where you can quickly end up dying for what almost seems to be no reason your first time through because you don't know where the enemies are going to spawn or where the environmental hazards are until you've already seen them. Once you know where everything is, it's suddenly very easy to avoid them all and lead the enemies into traps instead (because they're quite dumb), but it leads to more trial and error than I'd like. Yeah, it's true to the old school spirit of the game, I guess, but I suppose that's not really what I'm feeling up for right now.Combined with that, it doesn't help that you can kind of paint yourself into a corner with the weapon upgrades if you don't choose well. Hint: AoE/splash damage is your friend.Something else I haven't heard other people mention, so it may just be me, is that a couple times I got stuck going in circles for maybe ten minutes, completely unable to tell where I was supposed to go next. I wasn't lost or anything; I just couldn't find any door to go through or button to push or anything because it didn't stand out from the rest of the environment enough, which I haven't really had happen with other games much. I will chalk it up to either my partial color blindness or possibly just me being a dumbass.Anyway, I really wanted to like it, and there were some things about it that I genuinely did think were rather well done, but I had enough frustrating moments that I think I'm going to go back to playing Tower of Guns for my 90s-style FPS needs for the time being.

number of helpful: 11 of 24 people (46%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												I bought this game in the hopes of further supporting the developers, Flying Wild Hog as I enjoyed their title that they released after this game, Shadow Warrior, however the negative reviews that I kept seeing about this game were and are correct in every regard. This game is sold as Old School but it is not, I grew up playing Wolfenstine, Doom, Doom 2, Quake and so on those were old school, this game is simply a pretender that is unable to put forth even the most BASIC of FPS action and gameplay.  If you hear or read anyone speak of this title and Doom/Wolfenstine in the same breath immediately ignore them as they clearly have never played any of the true older titles as they are nothing alike and that is not a good thing.  Flying Wild Hog used the “old school” phrase as a marketing tool, it is an excuse to use that phrase to get people like me who've grown up playing the real old school shooters into thinking that this game will be ANYWHERE close to the caliber that those titles were and continue to be. Everything in those games was always paced properly, always fair; you never felt like you consistently hit a wall and it didn’t feel like luck to get to the next point. This game, regardless of these “upgrades” feels nothing but a shallow shell of what it tired to do and attempts to hype itself up in order to get unsuspecting buyers. Within 20 minutes, I knew that this game had none of what I found enjoyable in Shadow Warrior, clearly the developers learned many of their lessons from this title, as it is beyond inferior or substandard even for a basic FPS game. So far I have gotten zero enjoyment out of the experience, the weapons, much like the ballistic weapons in SW, are liken to a toy and do almost nothing to enemies. Enemies that this game's universe has KNOWN about so therefore they should actually do more then just oh annoy them a little which would make you think that humans would have developed weapons to fight beings that are basically computers. With regards to weapon damage and how they work, there appears so far to be no real way to determine if a one weapon is favored for a particular enemy over the other. Part of this is because every single enemy in this title is a damage sponge making combat experience difficult at best let alone figuring out this game’s mechanics, if one can say that it has any. The smallest of enemies do 50 times more damage then they should to the player and take 100 times more damage then they should given how frequently they put the player into the closest of close quarters with these mostly melee driven enemies and their size. I do still see some of this game’s poisonous form spilling out into their work on SW, as the enemies hit you when you clearly put some distance between you and their attack impact point or enemies that have some kind of city sized hitbox for their attack that will hit you not matter where you are in relation to the unit. In this day and age it is absolutely inexcusable that this kind of programming and blatantly unfair gameplay would be tolerated in ANY development studio. The character you play as seems to be made of paper, thus making enemy attacks even more deadly, dare I say you could right off the bat buy all of starting medical upgrades and STILL not have enough HP to take these unending waves and low amounts of health given. Speaking of your character, he has the lung capacity of a sick new born, he can sprint for exactly 1 meter then becomes haggard, yet we are lead to believe that he is some kind of PMC solder so one would think that he would have some kind of psychical training on top of whatever cybernetics or whatever he may have in him. This lack of stamina will constantly get you killed as enemies will swarm you almost instantly unless you sprint, even though the sprint is rather slow and it barely counts, adding to that the horrible visual effect that portrays the visual of sprinting. Unlike Shadow Warrior, you do not have the ability to dodge, which in this game’s case is a seriously negative omission because it is made by the same people the enemy types or attack types are roughly the same and need to be dodged. Your character however moves as such a slow pace on top of having almost zero stamina makes for even WALKING out of the way or trying to side step an enemy’s attack nearly impossible if not inconsistent. You my notice that I have yet to talk about the “story line” I have chosen to omit that because as MANY others have talked about that aspect of the game I have really nothing more to add.  The only thing that I will add is that I agree with their sentiment, the story is miniscule it would seem as if someone saw a bunch of science fiction movies and told their 10 year old to write a script while keeping those scenes in mind.  It is confusing only because it does so little to explain anything, this includes the game’s universe, this means the characters and their interactions, this means the locations and their significance, and this means the protagonist and his goals.  All the items that are essential to a proper story and the game provide none of that.  The sad part is that there is a lot of atmosphere within this universe which is obviously taken almost directly from Blade Runner.  The checkpoint system is absolute garbage and the developers felt it necessary to steal away the game’s quick save feature which is in almost Every PC game.  Especially given this game’s insane difficulty this is a crime and there are zero reasons as to why the developers choose to take out the quick save/quick load function or why they made the checkpoints so spread out other then to give the game yet another layer of fake, artificial difficulty. I really do not know how the developers slept at night knowing they made such horrible game design choices and then had the gall to market it as an old school shooter. I honestly should have just listened to the negative reviews of this game and just stayed playing or liking Flying Wild Hogs for making SW because now my opinion of them is soured by this experience. I wanted to support them by buying their other title but now I really am unsure if I will ever bother subjecting myself to this…Experience. Which is a damn shame because visually it’s a nice universe and a semi-possible interesting story, but it is all hampered by overly punishing gameplay mechanics, claustrophobic level design and bad mechanics, I was really hoping that the other reviewers were wrong, but I see that that was not the case. This title is not a game, or what I would consider a game, a game is supposed to be fun, an enjoyable experience that keeps you coming back, this game has failed to carry with it any of the most basic FPS ideas and put them to use, for that it fails as a game and a title.I wanted so much to like this game, or at the very least like more then 50% of it so that I could come away with at least some fond memories of my time in game.  I even pressed forward and beat the game in order to satisfy my completionist side and to confirm for myself that there was nothing positive about this game worth remembering or noting.  Beating the entire title with its added extra content DLC (which confuses the “story” even more) I feel that I have seen all that there is to see about this title and that no amount of extra time within this title’s universe will change my mind.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game feels like a rushed copy of Quake. I would recommend it for killing some time if it wasn't for the following issues:- Low variety of enemies and attack patterns- Dumb AI. Enemies only follow you horizontally and don't try to cut your escape, just keep following.- Weird HitBoxes: Your HitBox appears to be bigger than it should. Dodging is dodgy. Hitting too.- Invisible walls everywhere, probaby to make up for the enemy AI.- Cliché story, characters and weapons. I don't mind a bit of cliché, but this much.... some creativity wouldn't hurt.- The jump mechanic doesn't really help at all.- Linear, boring, not compelling, repetitive to kingdom come.- The skill system, or whatever that thing is.... doesn't add anything to the game, doesn't allow you to "biuld your own character" or "play your own way" at all. It's more like a way to not to give you everything at the beginning. Doesn't add up anything to the game. - The music is generic and uninspired, just like the rest of the gameOn the good side:-Graphics are nice- Cyberpunk sci-fi setting- You get to blow stuff up- Main character curses way more than the dialogue requires.- You get to blow a lot of stuff up- Secrets often show up right under your nose. You can cheat yourself into thinking you're really good at finding them.- You'll appreciate much more the next game you pick up.- You get to.... yeah, right.So, if you feel like killing some time with some mindless (really mindless) straight-forwarded shooter, get it, it's your money after all, just try to wait for a sale if you're not in a rush. Oh, and get a rpg with laser tracking device before you end the main story. You'll thank me later.
