number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I hate to say this.... ...but I cannot recommend this game. I would love to do it, because the game tries to do everything in the right way, but I simply can't, because this time it just doesn't work. It's a shame, because Flying Wild Hog did a bunch of things right. Hell, they nearly headed the perfect direction, but there are a few bad development decisions that have a significant impact in the final result. As I don't want to give the impression that this is an awful game or anything like that, I will start telling what does this game do right, because it does a couple of things right. This game is an amazingly beautiful game. It invites to just stop and look at everything. Graphical fidelity is great (really impressive for an Indie tittle), artistic design is UNBELIEVABLE, and it runs like charm (at least on my HD7970). The hand drawn cinematic, similar to those in Mirror's Edge, are really cool and hide the loading times pretty well. This is maybe the strongest feature of the game, it's technical side is amazing. Way better than expected. The game then wants you to run. Its action it's extremely fast paced, demanding you to aim fast, shoot fast and think fast. It also demands you to search for health, to use objects in the map to cover from fire (sometimes there are so many enemies shooting at you that otherwise is impossible) while enemies moving to get you out of your cover without the regular magical mechanics of AAA shooters which regenerate health and let you stay there for ages. In 2013 all I can say is Hooray for Flying Wild Hog! Even AI is better than usual. It isn't smart, but it's very very aggressive. Even the weapons, which seem to be a bit lackluster at the beginning, are pretty good once you start upgrading them. And there's a huge difference between every weapon, making each of them good or bad depending on the situation. Again, well done. So, if the game does so much things right, why does it fail? Because there are two important things that it does wrong. First one is the level design. Even if I love all the chances it gives to use map elements to kill the enemies, every level ends up being a corridor with some arenas in between and some secrets here and there. It's very Serious Sam-esque, but the design of every zone (specially in big arenas) is much worse. Sometimes really dull. It's not enough to leave me in an empty place with some objects and throw a bunch of enemies at me. To do that right you need a place that is awesome. For example, the town fight in one of the last levels of Serious Sam 3, or the different fights in the Egyptian ruins, are leagues beyond anything this game achieve. But is not only the level design what is flawed, but the enemy design. I'm not only talking about aesthetics, but behavior. Some robots are cool (the one that charges on you), but some other are just dull and the game relies too much in throwing lots of them at you. Again, this works in Serious Sam because every enemy presents a different and well balanced threat. Here it doesn't. Also doesn't help that some of them, if they are a bit far from you, look a lot like the environment, making them difficult to be seen. This two things lead to some very uninteresting fights, which considering this is a shooter is like a capital flaw. Talking about the story... well, there's not too much to say. It doesn't help the game, neither kills it. Just an average one which is never very important for the enjoyment of the game. Considering all of this, I cannot recommend it. And it's a shame, because it's a game I wanted to like, but I just don't enjoy it too much. That doesn't mean some other people won't enjoy it, because it still gets many things right, but here the scale is just a binary yes/no, so this one gets a no. Anyway, Flying Wild Hog looks like a very promising studio. I'll take a look sooner or later at their Shadow Warrior, and I'll definitely wait for their next projects.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												Hard reset is a game that tries very hard to be like the old school shooters like Serious Sam, Pain killer, Duke and Shadow Warrior, unfortunately it falls very flat.The story and writing are beyond awful, I can only assume it wasn't written by a English speaker as quite a lot of the dialogue is incorrect in English, getting an English localisation for your game is a very easy process, how that wasn't accomplished here is confusing to say the least.The visual idenity of the game is confused, the style of props and materials don't fit well together at all, the enemy visual design blurs them into the background, the scale of the world is completely off and the FX are massively overdone to a point where sometimes you can't see. Not ideal for a game such as this.The level design is attrocious, invisible walls everywhere, random elevators and doors everywhere that can't be opened till you eliminate the enemies (this can be grounded into the game in a much better way, the new Shadow warrior does exactly that).On the plus side, the approach to physics and destruction is nice to see and the computer interfaces are pretty cool tech that isn't in enough games.How this has a positive rating is beyond me, if you want to play a game like this that is actually good, go get Shadow Warrior (on further viewing, Shadow Waarrior is by the same developer, so definately skip this and just get Shadow Warrior)

content:
Posted: March 4
												I bought this game on sale for 3 euros. Not worth my money.PROS-The gameplay is funny at first hour-The ambientation is good-The graphic is decent (the game is really fast-paced, so it's improbable that you will stop for looking at the texture or other details)-It's short (and now let's see why it's a pro)CONS-Repetitive Gameplay-Only few type of enemy-Decent number of weapon but some are completely useles-The story is bad (I know that in this kind of FPS the story is only marginal, but they could have done much better)-The Boss fight are really stupid. Just kill all the normal enemy protected behind a wall, than shoot the week point of the boss. Then repeat five or six times. No skill needed.-The final. Yeah. Because there isn't even a final. Only a boss fight and a silly dialogue.-Difficulty is very unbalanced and the shield system doesn't work properly-Music is really forgettable. Damn, i've finished the game two hours ago and I don't remember the soundtrak-Shooting system is not sufficient for this time of FPS, not accurate enough. And the aiming system with the rifle...oh god! Terrible.These six hours were really boring and frustrating. Now you understand why the shortness is a pro?Mark: 5

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												Personal Rating: 4/10I want to cringe every time I play this game, even if I've only played ten minutes of it. It's just another gritty, brown shooter like Call of Duty or Gears of War. The levels are simplistic, walk from A to B, destroying enemies as you go in the grey background. The guns are weak, the standard, stock machine gun and the blue flame gun? I haven't got a clue what it is but that doesn't matter right? As long as it kills things, which is a bit of a laugh because the enemies are either incredibly weak or incredibly strong. I was playing on easy because I was tired and I was quite surprised by how much damage some of the enemies did. I finished the first mission and could handle no more, I got tired of doing the same thing over and over. Kill enemies, blow up fuse box, kill enemies etc. It was a grind. The only nice thing I can say about this game is that it isn't as♥♥♥♥♥♥as Deadfall Adventures which is an acheivement in it's own rights.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												There's the spirit of a fun game inside there, somewhere, but there are so many problems i'd suggest you don't bother with it.For starters, the weapon system is awful. There are two weapons (bullet and plasma) and each have 5 firing modes. Despite the fact that this means that to switch from a plasma weapon to say, a shotgun, you have to switch weapon and then switch mode, the two weapons and their modes are really too similar, and there doesn't seem to be any advantage over using one or the other (ammo is everywhere for both, they seem to deal the same amount of damage, etc)Both the enviroment and the enemies are so murky you can't tell them apart, and the lack of color is a strain on the eyes and a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥But what i think is the worst part is that it seems to be an arena shooter, for the incredibly large amount of enemies that spawn from nowhere and the "variety" of weapons. but there's no autorun and a limited sprint, the jump is ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and there are no armor pickups, the armor regenerates painfully slow. It seems they couldn't decide if they wanted to make a military shooter or an arena shooter, and they decided to present this mess.In shory, i can't reccomend Hard Reset. Blowing robots up is fun, but it's issues after a while become well too irritating.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Just played a few minutes, cannot quite say whether I recommend it or not. But here are my first few thoughts:* Cutscenes as comic is cheap. I will let them get away with it if the story is any good. But the opened does not promise much in that regard.* Destructible walls seem over-done. Nothing new, but I still like it. But having destroyed a little bit short of 10 walls in the few minues I play seems excessive.* Restrictive pathing! This is the biggest annoyance for me. You can't jump over certain objects because the game decides you shouldn't. Even if you character could physically make the jump. This is really annoying.* Motion blur while running is overdone and annoying. You seem to be able to switch it off in the settings. I will do so when I lauch the game for the next time.* I've been running around quite a lot, but so far have only seen 3 variants of enemies... in increasing numbers. I hope this will improve soon.* Moving objects around seems to only take into account the distance you moved before bumping into it. So you cannot push objects an indefinite distance and you and up bumping into it, stepping back, bumping into it again, stepping back again, and so on...So far for my first impression...

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												I tried to like this game.  I really did.  I booted this game up on three seperate occasions in an attempt to get through it, but why bother if it's not fun?  The whole ordeal was a slog through slow paced shooting sections.  There is obviously an attention to to detail here, but the core elements of the game are just fundamentally broken.  The story is delivered through minimal character voice overs during gameplay and short comic strip-like segments between loading screens.  The voice is acting is...decent, and the comic style of the cutscenes is interesting.  But beyond an interesting comic style and a neo-future cyberpunk setting, this game falls flat.There is an attempt at interest, but the cyberpunk setting is washed out by a spew of browns and grays in a variety of dark and blue-tinted areas.  The setting never really feels different between two locations: street level and underground.  The enemies are all bulletsponges and their design are both from an aesthetic standpoint, and a gameplay standpoint, uninspired.  Every enemy is a one trick pony, repeatedly attempting to kill with it's one attack mechanism.  For most enemies, you simply dodge while holding down the trigger until either they blow up, or you run out of ammo.  The topic of dodging leads me to my next point that the level design is awful.  I would expect this kind of design from a student project, not a full release game.  The areas are excessively linear with obvious tells for every single ambush of enemy robots.  Environmental hazards play a large role in the combat, but everything is incredibly played out.  If there is going to be a wave of enemies to ambush you, there will also be a series of explosive barrels or electrical spouting conduits to fry them up.  Most enemy encounters are simply there to pad the experience.  Many times enemies seemed to just appear in an area because the game said so.  Most combat was either myself against a large charging enemy in an open area, or myself against many small enemies in a closed area.  When you are required to dodge many small enemies in a closed off corridor like area with minimal movement, it's not fun, it's not a challenge, it's frustrating.  In one instance, an ambush blew through a wall, but upon inspection of their entrance point, it was a closed concrete block in a hole.You only get two weapons in the game.  Each one has it's own twist, and the weapon variety is accomplished through allowing upgrades for each of these two weapons.  Through the usage of upgrades, your bullet based weapon and your plasma based weapon can each turn into 4 other weapons, totalling 10 different guns.  However, these guns feels the same.  None of your attacks seem to have presence.  Accuracy is abyssmal, and when combined with the fact that all enemies have massive amounts of health (or you simply don't deal any damage) any combat interacting is simply tedious.The movement is a joke too.  For a game that so heavily relies on dodging telegraphed enemy attacks, movement is stagnant and stale feeling.  Your characters jaunts around at a slightly sluggish speed.  You have the ability to sprint - if I could even call it that - but it really just makes your character move slightly faster for only a few seconds and makes your screen and HUD shake a lot.  The jump is floaty, as if your character lacks weight, and you also can't jump while sprinting.  There was a speed puzzle where a lift needed to be activated by a button across the room.  You then had to run down a staircase and across the room before it went back up.  With the sluggish controls, it was tedious and took multiple attempts before realizing that to get there faster, I should not sprint, so that I could jump into the lift as it was going up.There are definitely some cool concepts here.  Floating UIs for upgrade panels and actual interaction screens for devices in the game are interesting and function very well.  The visuals themselves are very good.  Everything is for the most part impressively rendered and the visual effects are nice to look at.  But the art style, the sluggish controls, unvaried weapons, and completely uninteresting and uninspired combat really sink this game.  I tried to like it, but I can't and shouldn't have to force myself to clear a game out of my backlog.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2012
												I tried to like this game.  I really did.Normally I write out longer reviews, but I'm going to try to mimic the game by being short and totally underwhelming: this game will do nothing original, but it's not cookie cutter.  It isn't fun, but you won't be bored.  The gun-play is bland, though you've likely never seen a gun like the one in this game.I'd say it's safe to avoid, even if you are looking for an old-school shooter (like I was).  It's not the worst 4-5 hours you could use, but you'll walk away scratching your head at the ending. (True story: I didn't know I had beaten the game until a day after the fact when I tried to play some more.  And it doesn't even build up to anything.  It's almost like a slice of life...of a failing, futuristic robot-infested city.)

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												This looked like an interesting game and it was an indie shooter, so I picked it up. First impression was really good. It was a simple, yet challenging game that felt promising. Unfornately, after that, it became quite dull. Its exactly the same. All the enemies and the -heavily reused- levels feel exactly the same. Combat is fun and consists of overwhelming enemies forcing you to constantly dodge and backpedal.This game was fun, but could have been so much better. Oh and the graphics are absolutely brilliant.Pick it up if it's like $2 or $3.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Got this cheap in a sale. For that price, it's a decent enough game, but there are a few things holding it back. Some of the times I died, I wasn't sure what killed me, or you could get jammed into the corner by enemies and then meleed quickly to death. In some places you're deliberately shoved into tiny areas with large monsters... which I tend to find irritating rather than a fair challenge. The upgrade system was kinda fun, though I'm not sure what the point of having two guns was - in this game 1 gun can have 5 functions, which are all the different weapon types you need. Seems a better prospect to use just one of the gun types rather than both... I stuck with the mechanical gun throughout. Played through on Normal mode... though if the harder modes requrie more ammo, you may want to have rocket launcher/shotgun/machinegun combo on both. The enemy HUD upgrade I think should've been a default feature rather than an upgrade tbh. The game is pretty short, but if you're buying this in a sale, the length doesn't matter as much... but the ending is definitely cliffhanger'd, which was disapponting for me. I think they could have written a bit more on it, even if they left a challenge open at the end of it, just to add to the sense of completion. In general, the plot could do with a little more beefing up, just to get a better sense of the world and what the heck is going on. You're not going to find a groundbreaking plot here, but I don't think it's the kind of game that needs a unique plot.As far as technical problems go, I didn't experience any bugs ingame that I noticed, but I did have the game crash twice, and unsure why. Did knock my progress back a bit, but not too far. Played the game on ultra, got the odd bit of slowdown when things were really busy (2-3 times), but definitely playable on my rig... so I regard it as a decently performing game. In general, I wouldn't recommend this game to people, but if you're a big fan of shooters, you may have some fun with it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Mostly spent hours pushing boxes and trashcans epic distances to try to reach secrets, only to find it was reachable at the next area.  Don't really care for arbitrary boundries that look just as jumpoverable as spots that don't have them, and how you can't go back to an area after clearing it. Bosses can be unforgiving or crazy easy depending on position. It's a lot of kiting around/destroying but fun. Story isn't anything special and is pretty vague, but the levels look nice and aren't completely linear. Some of the gun upgrades make it too easy but ofc don't have to use them. As expected, lots of challenging rushes involved and don't expect much else.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2012
												Bred from the same stones as Painkiller, Hard Reset fosters old school shooter gameplay by throwing large quantities of enemies at you with quick-switching weapons that provide a variety of functionality.  Of rare not is that Hard Reset is a PC EXCLUSIVE; the textures are phenomenal, all lighting is done realtime, the interface is entirely designed around pointing devices and the weapons offer boons to those with pinpoint accuracy.For it's price, assuming you're one of the pedigree, it doesn't get any better than Hard Reset.  Forgive the lack of multiplayer, terrible story and muted movement for the chaos and enjoyment that comes from the combat.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												I wish I could "hard reset" this purchase.  thumbs down/10PROS:impressive graphics with beautiful environments and level design.awesome detail to the visual and audio fx.CONS:this game is difficult, REAL difficult, but not in a fun challenging way.  you will die, often. it's basically an ambush simulator where it's only sense of reward is "oh, I just happened to survive this time..."the story for this game is garbage, and the further I got into the game the less I knew what it was supposed to be about.  plot and character dialogue feels like it was scripted by a 10 year old: incoherent techno-babble peppered with an unnecessary usage of f-bombs.  terrible voice acting atop of comic book stylized cutscenes doesn't provide any aide in taking this story seriously.the weapons system is flawed.  there are only 2 weapons each with a set of modes, and selecting modes is done through cycling - incredibly frustrating when trying to dispatch an onslaught of enemies properly.  switching between weapons/modes isn't responsive either, and you'll often jump into fights with something you didn't want.  it feels like the game wants you to know how to approach each battle beforehand.enemy AI is OP as f***!  each enemy, large and small, requires a 1-2 (and sometimes 3-4) hit combo, and is a variable nightmare when they're all thrown into a small arena together.  you'll have to treat each enemy like a mini-boss and each mini-boss like a boss.  actual boss fights are plenty challenging, but then they'll throw in every enemy type from that stage as a way to "supply" you with more ammo and health.you have a jump button, but the only times you actually need it are to make running jumps - which cannot be performed easily.replay value for this game is nonexistent.  I made the mistake of investing too much time into it early on that I just had to see it through - mostly because I was trying to give it a fair chance - but it just turned out to be yet another polished turd.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2012
												Upgrade and weapon systems are cool, but basically everything else about the game is flawed in some degree ranging from "irritating" to "♥♥♥♥ing unforgivable". Enemies are bullet-sinks (and I was only playing on Normal, there are two levels beyond that... how bad must THOSE be?), taking way too long to kill. Let's not even go into how ludicrous the bosses near the game's end are. If you want to go secret-hunting, have fun getting irritated by the lack of a crouch button (which would let you collect half of them with ease, as they're visible beside a hole in a fence or broken wall). Instead you'll need to solve a jumping puzzle somewhere nearby... and jumps are floaty as♥♥♥♥♥♥ Real fun when they become required in the endgame to progress on the last levels.The devs did good by releasing "Exile" for free to Steam owners (an expansion/epilogue) but it's still based on the same game and no extra upgrades, kind of a letdown. Maybe their next game will be excellent.

												This is a very fun FPS that is made like a classic FPS. You have two weapons, but they each have 5 types so you technically have 10 weapons, all with different upgrades. number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Another customer suckered in by the demo.  Seemed like a cookie cutter shooter, which is what I was looking for.In today's age of "gittin' gud", I just can't be bothered with this one.  People yelled and spat about Bioshock Infinite having bullet sponge enemies, and yet, 1,600+ positive reviews for this game??  Gamers today are ♥♥♥♥ed in the head.  But I digress.Look up any Negative review, and I pretty much agree with all.  Only positive thing to come out of this is the futuristic setting if you like that sort of thing -- which is another reason I wanted to try my hand at it.-Weapons AND upgrades are practically useless.-Enemies never stun until they're half or 3/4 dead, and in which case you're still getting swarmed.-The weapon switch is HORRIBLY slow.  If you want to sell your typical fast-paced FPS, MAKE THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ SWITCH FASTER.  My god, you're almost forced to constantly switch in dire situations, and yet the developers thought it'd be a good idea to make the rifle/energy switch slow as♥♥♥♥♥♥  Doesn't add challenge, just adds annoyance.-Closed environments with enemies meant to be blown up by the cars/tanks/etc?  BAD IDEA.  But what do I know.  Gamers today will cut their wrists open just to say they beat somthing hard.  I just don't have the time or patience for games like this anymore where the developers purposely make one aspect good, but another point doubly, and glaringly, worse just to make the NEET MLG kids gloat about it on forums.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												This is a pretty average game that doesn't earn my recommendation I'm afraid. The environment is kind of Bladerunner meets Borderlands with the "old skool" play style of Doom. The game has two weapons, each of which has a series of modes.. nice but too complicated to switch between in the heat of battle. When you are taking hits, you have no real feel for how badly you are being hit and the difficulty curve is well, more rollercoaster than curve. The game also teases you with openings beneath fences etc, but the lack of a crouch or pick up ability serve to frustrate. Similarly, jumping is flawed... you cannot jump over balustrades or ledges that you might otherwise expect to, instead our action hero has to walk to the stairs.... You spend a lot of time fighting multiple enemies at once, but their surprise appearances are entirely predictable. The art style is quite nice and the engine smooth, but the levels are all pretty samey and it gets tired quickly. There also seem to be a lot of fork lift trucks blocking the way, hardly puzzling, and the game quite frequently tells you where to go with a hint system before you even have a chance to figure it out (if indeed you could). So in summary, it's an ok game, but not really recommended.  It tries to be old skool but doesn't quite pull it off and fire fights tend to be a case of holding down the fire button whilst strafing around for health and pickups.If you can manage to persevere and grind through the monotony of the first 2 hours or so, there are some epic boss battles to be had but the surprise spam attacks continue throughout. There ain't no sneaking up on enemies in this game, they prefer the magician's approach.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												SHORT REVIEW:The developers have no idea how to make a videogame.LONG REVIEW:I have no idea where to begin on how bad this game is. As a fan of mindless shooter, I can't fathom how flawed the game is in its core.The character's movement does not feel the player is in control entirely to compensate the chaotic situations that the game constantly puts the player in, as sprinting and jumping are not very fluid. You cannot jump freely while sprinting, you lose a bit of handling while at it, and sprinting lasts for a very short period of time.All of the enemies (and I mean all of them), have faster movement speed, usually 2 to 3 times faster than the character so the player is forced to be constantly moving with the game's awful controls.The game seriously lacks variety of enemy types, but it also suffers from their flawed designs. Enemies should be very exciting to fight, but they are incredibly annoying to deal with. There are self-destructive bots that move in an incredible speed whose explosion radius is massive, shockwave emitting crawlers which lock on you (for the most of the time you cannot avoid them easily) when charging at an accelerated speed, ranged gunners whose projectiles travel as fast as bullets, fast-moving rollers who charge at you to saw your limbs off, and other varieties of the said enemy types.What's worse is that the game tends to put all of these annoying enemies in a single wave at once in which the player has to rely on variety of lucks or stupid AIs doing funky things to beat.The game features about 3 different enemy types with different armor levels and different weapons on them. Some of these types have no weaknesses on how to kill them without almost dying. The game still gives you enough regen after a wave to restore back to perfect health, but it is no excuse to design a game where the player is meant to be hurt to almost death situations after every wave. This is the most frustrating part of the game. I died the average of 3 times per chapter, and  after those deaths I didn’t bother changing a strategy and was still able to beat the level I had trouble with, because the enemy AIs were so unpredictable and had no counter-strategy to work with. It was all just luck for the most part. Explosion radius is bigger than the usual player’s predictions in the game’s FOV (and the game basically feeds on explosions), most of projectiles are semi-homing and they also explode dealing damage to the player around even though it misses, small enemies charge at you while you are dealing with bigger enemies and vice versa, and most of them don’t have any counter-strategies to work with. One of my favorite mindless shooter is the Serious Sam series, and the game had enemies that were simply very fun to play against, so I can tell you that mindless shooter does not mean mindless design.The level design is nothing of stellar, and sometimes makes no sense at all. The game has a hint system telling the player what to do, only when they reach a point. Here's why the hint system is completely useless: There are points that emit green lights where the player has to go and interact with to advance in the level and it's ALWAYS just as simple as clicking on the button when they reach the point. However, the developers think the players lack brain so it tells them to “click on the button to ... (insert any unnecessary information)”. The problem is that the levels aren’t designed well enough to sometimes let player know where to go in the dark environment, and the game does nothing to assist the player with. It tells the player to click on the button once they reach the only green-lit interactive interfaces which is completely useless. Later in the game, the levels have so many map decorations that are lit green with interfaces that cannot be interacted with. The players are accustomed to click on whatever that has an interface screen and green-lit, and the final levels of the game break this one rule that they’ve been training their players with. Often there will be times where it damages the player for absolutely no reason with some pre-scripted moving objects. There is no way to avoid them, and the game gives you a regen shortly after. Why were these put in the sequence in the first place?The game looks pretty nice, but it is nothing of amazing. If the game was released on the consoles I doubt it would look as decent as any other average titles. I was playing this on my 780 Ti and I still experienced frame drops on chaotic situations, which the most of the game is in except when the player is walking to point A from point B. I can only assume the game is terribly optimized at best.The game is the definition of frustration. There were so many flawed designs with no sense of innovation being found from the game, so I had to look up who in the world developed this terrible game. Flying Wild hog, as stupid as their name sounds, had no experience as it was their first game in the market. I will make sure to avoid any games from them in the future and so should anyone who wants to have fun with videogames.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												At the start this game got off on the right foot. Corporation run lifestyle with robots sabotaging things? Sweet, right up my alley. After the first few kills I was still having fun. Upgrades for weaponry with a slick UI that was built into the game so it felt extremely fluid. The world felt, albeit deserted, lived in in a way.Seconds later I started to notice the glaring flaws with the game. While attempting to sprint away from a horde of enemies, I found out that sprint only lasts for maybe a second or two, quickly giving me false hope of getting out of the situation unharmed while I sought better cover. I noticed that the two guns, an EMP rifle and a standard assault rifle, had no real difference other than looks. I upgraded said weapons to allow one to give me an area effect and one with a grenade. The area effect was useful, but still allowed enemies far too close for comfort, and the grenades were just...useless. "Oh well, maybe they need more upgrades." I lied to myself as I pressed on. Soon I found myself becoming irritated by the obvious pickups just out of reach in a crouch-able area. I tried every button then went into my key bindings, low and behold there was no crouch button. Soon after these flaws arose, thinking I was lucky, I attempted to jump on a few crates to hurdle a barrier to get a secret pickup. Right as I reached the top, I was met with an invisible wall. I groaned and moved on, and within a few short moments I was met with the irritation that caused me to quit the game: "This barrier is self-powered, you've got to find a way around it." I walked up to the barrier, and just to the right was a tunnel through some scaffolding. I moved towards it quickly as the robots surrounded me. It was about a foot too short, and here I am, a cybernetic soldier with permanently fixed knees and apparently a spine as well. I couldn't duck under to get through, and the robot army behind me quickly ripped me to pieces.tl;dr: If you are a sadist with games that give you plenty of false hope, buy it now, don't even wait for a sale. If you are anything else, please let my experience be enough for you.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Hard Reset is a game with great high-level ideas and infuriating moment-to-moment gameplay experiences. I am generally so busy asking myself questions like "Why am I getting hurt?", "Why can't I jump over this foot-high railing?", "Why is it so hard to switch to the right weapon/mode combination when I'm getting swarmed by sawblade-bots?", "Why can't I jump over this foot-high brick?", "Why do I have to turn on a generator to turn off that energy barrier?", "Why did that energy barrier randomly turn back on after I went through so much trouble to turn it off?", or "Why can I jump onto this two-foot high box, but then once on it can't jump over the three-foot high wall next to it?" that I can't really appreciate the strategic depth of the upgrade system, the old school nonlinear level design, or the treasure hunt for all the secret caches. Those are things that generally excite me, but the experience of the game for me is mostly fumbling with weapon controls and slamming into invisible walls.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												I'm a big fan of Shadow Warrior 2013 and could feel a lot of the same in Hard Reset but ultimately I think Flying Wild Hog missed the mark here.The old school shooter vibe they were going for was fine and dandy but they really dropped the ball with the movement. It just wasn't fluid enough movement for the style of game. You feel bogged down in what is otherwise an endless assault of great action and eye-candy. And things were rather flat. Jumping was clunky and thus underutilized in general. You remained on one plane despite some vertical level designs. And jumping was never involved in battles, just strafe til things are dead. Then your character just feels half a step too slow for a game where you need to constantly be moving. By the halfway point the movement was begging me to call it quits but I ultimately stuck it out thanks to some highlights like the boss battles.There's a lot of other bad aspects though. All of them I would've forgiven if the movement had been smoother! But instead, they stick out. Like how much of bullet sponges the enemies really are. it isn't a valid complaint on it's own because, well, they're suppose to be! But when it feels like you're strafing through mud it gets tiresome. Another annoyance was the slight bit of RNG "dodge" or "miss" involved on top of them being those bullet sponges. Enemies had dodge animation that would only show half the time you missed an on target shot... The other half of the "dodges"? Well... I'm left guessing, but I will; I think the animations just don't kick in. And this leaves your shots literally going through the enemies with no effect. It was quite odd and visually off putting. Again though, something I would overlook if I had smoother control of my movement and things were just faster overall.Regular enemies just come in waves and you strafe and shoot hoping you can absorb more shots than they can. Weapons didn't need to be elaborate or varied and they aren't. Plenty of secret areas to be found during downtime. Extremely sparsely sprinkled platforming jumps that are just out of place. All sectioned off by absolutely awesome boss battles. And all packaged in underrated good looks, honestly don't get the need for the Redux as far as the visuals go. But supposedly there's a little more to it than window dressing. But I do believe I will be passing on Redux nonetheless. I had hints of fun and appreciate Flying Wild Hog's approach, but was one of those games that becomes a chore to finish rather than a thrill. And really really odd abrupt ending by the way. I mean I felt it coming but just weird.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												A largely forgetable game with *horrible* writing and pretty bad voice acting. The story makes basically no sense, the plot hardly advances at all except in one or two places, and the main character uses "the f-word" and "the s-word" and other expletives so often that they lose all meaning. The game looks great, and the combat is actually quite well done, but after the 3rd or 4th variation of the same npc coming at you, and the predictability of enemy enounters, it all gets old very fast. There's also only one "combat music" track that you hear throughout the entire game. It smacks of being the first game of a new crew, written by someone without a firm grasp of English or experience in how to tell a story. PROTIP: When writing dialogue, "the f-word" is not an acceptable replacement for "very", "damn", "ouch", "huh", or "oh look, that's an interesting thing on the horizon." By the mid-point of the game I was utterly bored, and just grabbed a trainer from GameCopyWorld so I could blow through the rest of it, which I did. The ending sucked. I've heard FWH's Shadow Warrior remake is quite good, but after playing this, I find those reports dubious. I'll still play it, though. I can't recommend this to anyone, except as an example of how NOT to tell a story.Edit: I've just learned that Steam censors "curse words", which is a load of crap, so I've made some changes.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												The basic Hard Reset experience is arcade-shooting action in a nutshell. You have only two guns, a gun that uses bullets and one that uses energy. However, the base guns (basicly rifles) have additional shotgun, gernade, mine-throwing, and various single power-shot modes that can be unlocked with points earned from kills and from scavenging yellow-glowing-box-things scattered throughout the levels. The varitions between similier modes for each gun are minor (the bullet-gun shotgun is slow and single-shot, the energy version is a wide spray of electricity for as long as you hold down the trigger), but the differences do add up.Your only enemies are machines, which is good and bad. It's good if you like watching your target's armored body fall apart, but bad if you don't like bullet-spongy enemy. Several large foes take forever to kill. However, the degree of bullet sponge was acceptable to me, as per the enemies. The enemies themselves are limited for the first part of the game, which I liked because it made it easier to learn patterns, especially for large groups of enemies (there are several). The Enhanced content adds some new foes, however, and a flying version is both very deadly (it shoots back) and extremely annoying.The combat in Hard Reset is the meat of the game, and is intense and demanding (many enemies focus on melee, meaning they throw themselves at you in large masses). Impediments to progess are all extremely basic keypad interacts that are thankfully less annoying than keycards. There is an extensive story, but I got sick of it early, and when the extended content shows up I'm pretty sure the whole thing stops making much sense, anyway.If you like the momentum and skill required by games that utilize healthpacks over regenerating health, you will probably like this game.Video!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2012
												This one came out of left field.The game is visually fantastic and solid, featuring the benefits of modern FPS and Classic FPS design. The setting is especially well crafted with good voice acting and comic book style cutscenes telling the story. It definitely derives influence from '80's and 90's science fiction such as Blade Runner and The Fifth Element. There's even a dash of Film Noir with the player character portrayed as a cynical authority figure.Check this one out, it's more than worth it. Die-hards of the '90's online Arena shooters will appreciate it's run-and-gun gameplay and new players will enjoy the scalable and fair difficult curve as well as the entertaining narrative.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												I wanted this game to be good, I really did.  It looked really cool and had a lot of promise, but it just didn't deliver.  It's very pretty, yes, but that doesn't make a game any good. The best analogy I can make for the problem is that the character is grossly overweight, because these are some issues:A) He can't sprint more than 10 feet before having to catch his breath in between stuffing his face with mashed potatoes.B) He can't crouch down because then all of his bacon cheeseburgers will fall out of his trenchcoat.C) He can't stand on sloped surfaces without falling off, because he insists on carrying sticks of butter in his shoes for when the moment is right.D) He scrambles to pick up his donuts every time an explosion goes off next to him, causing significant screen shakingThis, on top of extremely confusing map design and enemies whose animations are erratic and jump from pose to pose, as well as frustrating enemies that can often kill you before you realize what's even going on, the game was really not enjoyable to play.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												Hated this game.What ultimately breaks it is the checkpoint system and lack of quick saves. As a PC-only game, it has no excuses...Checkpoints are positioned far and wide, after 5, maybe more waves of enemies. Downgrading difficulty results in warnings about losing progress on difficult badges, etc... This also means that if you find a secret, then die before checkpoint, which is almost certain, you will lose secret and will have to re-get it. Terrible design idea, as some secrets are hard to get! And, some areas have 3 secrets before a checkpoint, so you actually have to get all 3 then fight some goons, before next checkpoint hits. Everything about it is just awful.Other more minor points: gun upgrades are not interesting, bad. The graphics are not spectacular, but not horrible... Sounds are generic. Story is told through 2D drawings, which are bad. There are some voices/dialogue in the game, but it is generic. Go find this, we have to find that, chase this guy... Story is not compelling.This is one of the only games I haven't bothered to finish and was aggravated playing! All thanks to the lousy checkpoint system and lack of quick save.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												PROS:- Slick story presentation with comic book cutscenes and decent voice-acting.- Environmental kills.- Plenty of destructible props.- Decent optimization.CONS:- Visually bland.- Underwhelming unlockable arsenal.- Painkiller-like gameplay with regenerating ammo.- Sloppy level design that often revolves around narrow corridors and invisible walls.- Enemies are all fast and resilient.- Hard-to-dodge enemy attacks.- Confusing story with an anticlimactic ending.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												I might have been impressed by Hard Reset ten years ago, but it doesn’t hold up to today’s shooters. This is an extremely generic first person shooter that lacks many expected features of the genre. You can’t even duck, which should tell you something about how the game is meant to be played. It’s all mindless run and gun action. I wouldn’t mind so much if the game wasn’t so uninteresting. Blowing up wave after wave of the same robots is, simply put, boring. The cyberpunk environments are dull and repetitive, and the weapon loadout is quite limited. There is an upgrade system for the weapons and armor, but it’s a pain to navigate. Some of the upgrades are fun for a while, but they still don’t provide enough variety to hold my interest. The story is expectedly poor and primarily told through comic book style cutscenes. These cutscenes help hide the otherwise lengthy load times, but that means you can’t skip them. With a multitude of quality first person shooters to choose from, there’s no reason to waste any time with a game as simple and predictable as Hard Reset.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												The inspired art design can't make up for the repetitive and unengaging gameplay.The level design (geometry, textures, effects) is frequently beautiful, very Blade Runner, at times, very original, although strangely low-poly.  The advertisements in particular are great: an original take that preserves a very cyberpunk feel.  But that's the end of what's good about Hard Reset.There is little variety in enemies; what variety exists is largely about the size of their hitbox and what kind of weapon they use.  Every combat area is a predictably-sized arena with artificial sawtooths to prevent retreat, and doors that prevent continuing until all the bad guys are dead.  Many of the enemies have a lot more health than I personally find enjoyable.The protagonist's weapons lack a certain oomph, maybe because all ten(?) of them are supposed to be flavors of only two transforming weapons-- so for instance, your proximity mine uses effects that look an awful lot like your plasma gun.  An experience point system unlocks new weapons and upgrades, but of course encourages upgrades, which in turn discourages variety; meanwhile, the fact that there's only two kinds of ammunition prevents the authors from meaningfully using ammunition to prompt weapon switching.A lot of factors conspire to limit engagement with the game.  The voice acting sounds like the friends-and-family-of-the-devs style.  The story isn't the focus, of course, but what little exists doesn't help anything.  Occasional  trace-the-pipe puzzles and poor signposting wreak havoc with the pace.Overall, this plays like a very very high-quality mod for a game ten or fifteen years old.  Which is a little like, "Excellent cinemetography, considering that it's made for public access cable."  Might be of some interest for its take on cyberpunk, but it's not very engaging as a game.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												So this is the "tribute to old school shooters", eh? This is more of an insult if anything. This shooter got nothing on the classics. It has huge balance issues. Enemies on the difficulty level "Insane" are bulletsponges. All of them. That's right, the smallest robots with ♥♥♥♥tons of HP come in big numbers and swarm your♥♥♥♥♥and all you can do is retreat & shoot. You might think that one can try to run ahead and use a better route? Too bad, the character you play with is extremely slow, the sprinting is useless, you only sprint for 2 seconds, WTF?! It's even worse than Call of Duty and I thought that was not possible. If you run towards the enemy, they slaughter you in seconds. Upgrades are way too important for a shooter like this, pick the wrong things and you won't get far. But how are you supposed to know what's ahead of you if you play it for the first time? By watching a Let's Play beforehand? Also, there are explosives EVERYWHERE. Those you use for the most part to kill enemies. But what if you shot something explosive and it destroyed everything else in a chain reaction and you got nothing left for the next wave of enemies? Yup, you are ♥♥♥♥ed. Also you gotta love the level architecture. There is a fence blocking your path. You can clearly see that all it would take to get past it is simply to crouch. But here comes another "extra-challenge": there is no crouch. Instead, he goes around and kills another ♥♥♥♥ton of enemies JUST TO GET TO THIS ONE ROOM AND PRESS A BUTTON. Lovely, that really is very oldschool. There is no feedback from your guns, enemies are much faster than you, they have better weapons than you and they can hit you from every angle possible. You are basically a tank with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ armor and weak weapons. Somewhat I don't remember anything similiar in the shooter genre from back then. Short version: it's not oldschool, it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game with extremely good looks. Flying Wild Hog somewhat learned from their mistakes by making Shadow Warrior 2013 a more enjoyable game, but they still kept the bulletsponges. Not a big deal there since you have a sword.

												In the only remaining human city of Bezoar, Major Fletcher, an Army Combat Veteran and soldier of the CLN, is dragged into a conflict between two of mankind's greatest enemies. He is to discover that nothing is what it seems to be.Hard Reset is an action-packed, single-player shooter for the PC. With over-the-top destruction, loads of enemies, great weapon variety and a beautifully realized cyberpunk setting, Hard Reset is sure to shake up the shooter scene.

Posted: June 2, 2014
												Hard Reset is an intense first-person shooter that takes place in a futuristic cyberpunk envoirnment and city. To play it, you're going to want at least three things: A desire to shoot countless hordes of robots, patience of iron, and a pretty powerful graphics card. If you don't have one or more of these things, Hard Reset probably isn't for you.This game has a really awesome art style, both the beautiful enviornments that you play in, and the cutscenes that play at the beginning of a level. The cutscenes themselves play like a sci-fi comic book, which I think is really neat, though most of the time it doesn't feel like there's much story involved. The gameplay itself is oldschool right down to the bare bones, sort of a hybrid of painkiller, doom and serious sam. You'll engage in plenty of hardcore combat with all sorts of robots that appear throughout the levels and try to kill them by any means necessary, whether it be mowing them down with your weapons, or blowing up enviornmental hazards around them, ranging from barrels, electrical machines, cars...you get the idea.Probably one of the coolest features of Hard Reset is that, unlike most oldschool shooters, you don't actually collect new guns. Instead, you get to power up the weapons and gear the game starts you out with by collecting Nanos, then going to upgrade machines to select the upgrades you desire. For example, you can upgrade your assault rifle to be things like a shotgun and an rpg, and you can improve the quality of your armor and health, to name a few things. Nanos can be collected by killing enemies, looking throughout the levels, and finding secrets by looking high and low for them and blowing up walls.Even though I really like Hard Reset, I'll admit it's not for everyone---it can get rather frustrating at times, since enemies often appear in swarms really quickly and can often result in stupid deaths (though to be fair, I AM playing on insane difficulty), and the game does have very little story (mostly just kill machines and complete objectives). Very highly recommended for those who love intense oldschool gameplay and cyberpunk/sci-fi games, though. 3.5/5.0

Posted: June 2, 2014
												Oh to go back to the days of just wasting through baddies moving from checkpoint to checkpoint. This game has done wonders  to bring that feeling back, only now with a new coat of paint of todays tech to sweeten the deal. I suppose there is a story but i did not pay to much attention to it, I seemed to pay more attention to the surroundings. There are holo-ad signs( which can be used offensivly by shooting them) which give you a glimps of what might the inhabitants might have filled there days with. You run through city scapes filled with parked( or abandoned) cars ( which can be destroyed hurting you or enemies) , many nooks and crannies to root around in to find secrets, blimps and other air vehicles flying over head, and announcments looped through loud speakers further adding to the meat of the world. You have two weapons , or should i say weapon types; being that either one can be upgraded to have an added mode to it. the types are solid rounds and energy munitions; bothe can be upgraded to fill the rolls of straight shooter( solid : assault rifle with zoom secondary/ energy : pulse rifle with charge blaster secondary) close range crowd control ( solid : shot gun with multy shot burst secondary / energy : multi arc electricity emiter with stun burst for secondary). All can be upgraded at stations that are littered about levels, you must spend an upgrade point( gained by filling an upgrade bar to full by picking up packets from either downing baddies or finding them in secret areas) on either of the 2 gun types to unlock each of their modes and some slight upgrades for each of the modes, or a point on your armor un locking many bonuses like more health , more damage soak, or faster regen of sprint. even the upgrade stations do not take you out of the world, the staton's menu is diplayed as a holographic projection, and your cross hair turns into a curser for making selctions. If you want to back out of the upgrade menu just walk away from the station and continue mayhem. All in all this is some great adreniline pumping action with a very fleshed out world to blow stuff up in.

												This game is a total blast to play.  It's smooth, sleek, and provides a fantastic light show of sparks, robot parts, explosions, and dazzling particle effects.  Many will criticize the story, but that's not what a game like this is about.  It's about moving fast, shooting constantly, and picking up shiny power-ups so that you can do it again in a few seconds.  It's that same addictive rush that we got from Doom and Duke Nukem 3D in the 90s, with the added polish that says "This was made in 2013."   For the price, you can't beat it.  10/10

Posted: December 5, 2011
												While it's not a Duke3D or Doom 2 sort of "old school" Hard Reset definitely harkens back to Serious Sam, Painkiller, and even Quake 4. Beautiful environments, brutal enemies, and exotic upgradable weaponry system combine to deliver a very solid shooter. Health packs, skippable inbetween-level cutscenes and spawn triggers will bring you back to a different age of PC gaming. Personally, I purchased Hard Reset on sale and after finishing the game, feel guilty I didn't pre-order it. If you are looking for a challenge, play through this on Insane - while it feels impossible at times, the feeling of triumph you have after completing difficult sections of the game is uplifting. Secrets are abound in this game, some tougher to find than others, but each one gives you currency used to upgrade your weapons or unlock new ones.While it ends a bit abruptly, the ride there is full of gunplay. Some of the AI is simplistic, but the volume and strength of the enemies provide difficulty. Loved it.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												Forget sniping or cover (there is no crouch key) mobility is the key in this run and gun linear shooter. With a checkpoint system that opens the new area while sealing the last the levels feel more like a series of confined arena's packed with a mixture of heavily scripted spawns making for a very hectic style of arcade gameplay.With old school secret areas dotted around containing power ups, and intermittent upgrade points players can spend any nanites (experience) they're collected to upgrade different aspects of defense or offense. Such customisation will alter difficulty and play style allowing some longevity for re-runs.The graphics are nice and with an environment full of destructibles the game encourages the use of stategic misses to take out the enemy hordes in a more imaginative manner then simply clicking on them repeatedly. Another nice touch is the hit zone allocation to enemy allowing the player to strategically cripple or desperately reduce enemy constructs 1 part at a time, resulting in different animations and behaviour.The comic book style interludes add atmosphere and story to an otherwise shallow in-game experience.Summary: Good looking frantic fun with short bursts of fast and reflexive gameplay between bouts of leasurely safety.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Almost instantly Hard Reset brought to mind all those great late-90's FPS games. With a modern touch and great attention to detail, especially with the level design and enemy types, this game is truly both a blast from the past and a blast of fresh air. It is a shame that an amazing game like this has gone so unnoticed. I certainly am very glad that I decided to give it a go. Cool noir-ish style in its story, some very intriguing sci-fi concepts, fantastic gunplay and a gun-focused progression system, this game doesn't really lack anything. The gun system is interesting, you have two guns which have multiple modes of firing and you upgrade them as you go, also unlocking more fire modes, I think this system works very well combined with all the different enemies you'll face. I especially liked shooting the bigger enemies with a shotgun or a railgun, and seeing all the armor plating fly away, yet the buggers kept coming - so many thrilling fights! The boss fights are very enjoyable, the levels have lots of destructible environment and last but not least; this game has a lot of secret places - just like good old FPS games used to have. If you are a FPS fan, you should definitely play this one through.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												This is an interesting game with a cool art style. The soundtrack is a cool Techno inspired sound, the graphics are a bit neon sporting bright red, blue, and green. In between fighting the story unfolds through comic book pages, similar to how Max Payne worked. It has a bit of a learning curve with some depth to the upgrade options between your weapons and character. Boss fights are a little tedious as they are the "new, old school" as I call it with a throw back to old console games where you shoot the glowing bit until it falls off. All in all not a bad game, worth $5 or $10 bucks.Tips: Play on Normal, this game is brutal on Hard...I played on Hard and got super frusterated a bunch of times.Upgrade your CLN and NRG weapons. Learn to switch between the CLN #1 (Rifle), CLN #2 (Shotgun), NRG #1 (forget the name) and NRG #3 (Mortar), and CLN #4 (RPG). I found that a combo of CLN #3 and NRG #3 was my best way to take down most things quickly.

												It's a classic FPS game, something like Serious Sam or Duke Nukem. Posted: December 21, 2013
												A couple of hours playing this and I am having a great time. A really nice cyberpunk setting and despite the fact that I am using a 3 year old graphics card at the moment and there is a hell of a lot going on visually it is running beautifully.I very much get the impresion this is a game that knows what it is and is not trying to be something it isn't. It is basically a twitch shooter with loads of bad guys. ok robots, and loads of shooting. Yes it is a corridoor shooter but that is not always a bad thing and unlike a lot of games it is not pretending to be anything else.I love big open world sandpit games like Farcry and Skyrim and first person rpg shooters being a huge Deus Ex fan (I refuse to acknowledge the second one as a Deus Ex game it would be too painfull ). However I also like a good old style shooter where I can just dive in for an hour or two and blow the hell out of everything that moves and to me that is exactly what this is.  They are not east to do well, just look at the abomination that was Duke Nukem Forever,  and this one has been done well and is fun.If you want great story and character development forget it there isn't either. However if you want a good fun fps with a great graphical feel that knows exactly what it is and does it well buy and have fun. If you look at what this developer has gone on to do since with the new Shadow Warrior you can see they have a real understanding of the genre.Playing this takes me back to the likes of Duke Nukem 3D, the origional Shadow Warrior and Serious Sam with his BFG (We all know the F stood for Friendly, honest...) So lock and load, hold down the trigger and send those bots to that great scrapyard beyond the mechanical veil.

Posted: December 27, 2013
Hard Reset was one of those games I didn't like at first. But then I loved it.I tried the game out back when it was released and it just didn't click with me. But I went back to it and I must say it is a very enjoyable old-school shooter with some new Ideas that may not be revolutionary but keep the game from getting boring.The Weapons are fun and the upgrade system is rewarding since you get a new "function" for your multipurpose weapons almost every few minutes throughout the entire game. There are many weapons to choose from so everyone should find something to their liking. You bascially have two wepons, a standard rifle/shotgun/missile launcher etc. and an energy weapon with a bunch of different modes ranging from plasma blaster to railgun. You can switch between these two wepons at anytime by pressing Q/E and switch between the modes using the mouswheel. It can however be a little bit difficult to switch between all these different weapons on the fly, and modes on the same weapon don't differentiate themselves from eachother much. This can lead to frustration sometimes. I really have to give the game credit for it's level design though. Every new environment looks different from the last and the levels are constructed in a way that's challenging, but you never really get lost. The levels are also stuffed with details, most of which are also destructible. The vistas in this game are stunning and even the skyboxes are a filled with details. It's also got some nice lighting effects going on. I played it with the DLC and must say the game probably would have been a bit short without it, and sadly even with the DLC the story feels very lackluster and doesn't really come to any sort of conclusion, so don't expect a great story. Other than that though I feel Hard Reset is well worth it's money if you're looking for a straight up shooter with a nice cyber-punk esthetic.

Posted: May 8, 2014
												The people at "Flying Wild Hog" studios set out to make a cyber-punk shooter with fun gun-play mechanics....and they did it! 1)The overall experience: it's fast, action packed and simply fun. A person, who's childhood was based in the 90s, will notice that this game is heavily inspired by the old-school classics like Doom, Quake, Duke Nukem 3D and Shadow Warrior - your health is displayed on your lower left corner along with your ammo and shield capacity. If you are not careful those attributes will get depleted and you'll simply die with no ammo or health.  2)Digging a little deeper into the game - the game's story takes a backseat to it's gameplay. You are equipped with two guns which transform into several types and they can be upgraded throughout the game. This is the only modern mechanic implamented into the game. The game is powered by RoadHog Engine - there are impressive lighting effects, physics and decent textures, but the areas that you will visit are not verried. You'll visit the same industrial cyber-punk vistas, but from different angles. 3) Final Verdict - Hard Reset dosen't set out to re-imagine the genre. It is a familiar shooter, that brings back good memories of the fun I used to have while playing the shooters of the 90s! A great nostalgia trip and challenge for the modern gamer! I give Hard Reset a 8/10! :)

Posted: January 9, 2014
												Without a doubt, if you are a fan of old school first person shooters, Hard Reset will hit you right in the nostalgia. Side-scrolling galore, straight-up bullet storms (no pun intended), and huge, monsterous bosses. The game has an awesome sci-fi/dystopian set piece. And man - this game is challenging. You are often pitted against an army of robots in corriders - relegating strafing to mere slamming against walls.Despite the strong points of the game, I feel that the makers did not adequately fill the environment. Enemy-types are sparse despite the add-on: You basically face (1) two-legged robots with 3 variations, (2) foot soldier robots with 3 variations, and (3) two "gorilla-type" robots with two variations. There is no variety of weapons per say, but rather weapon-alternative fires. The greatest downfall of this game is the story: Despite googling it and reading the message boards, it appears no one has a firm grasp of what is going on. Comic-esque cut scenes do their best to present something that resembles a plot but fall short of cohesiveness.I am really on the wall about whether or not I would recommend this game. If you are inclined towards old school FPS's, get it. If you fall in to lulls really quick due to repetitive enemy types and an abscence of a story , I'd avoid this game.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												What can I say about Hard Reset: Extended Edition?Its a great throwback to the 'run and gun' games of the past, I personally think Serious Sam's latest effort does a better job in that regard but Hard Reset has something Serious Sam doesn't... Upgrades. New weapons can be unlocked and upgraded by finding 'Nanites' that are scattered around a level, of course most of the high value amounts are found in secret areas.I greatly enjoyed playing through the game and was really enjoying the plot, right up to the point where it just cuts off abruptly. There is potential for a sequel but who knows if thats even in the works. Take a look at Rage for a great example of wasted potential in regards to a continued story.Between some of the levels (I was going to say all but thats not the case) you're treated to a semi-animated comic book to explain the plot. This is a touch that I loved because it gives the game a greater feeling of depth and you want to explore the world this story is set in. Sadly this is where the game falls flat, while playing I found my character getting stuck on invisible walls and not being able to jump over or climb on things that I really should have been able to. It broke the immersion of the game quite badly especially since finding the aforementioned secrets quite often means having to explore the world around you, increasing the likelihood of running into these issues.I would recommend this game, for some nice 'run and gun' fun. But don't expect anything too deep and try not to be upset by the abrupt ending. I really hope that Flying Wild Hog create a sequel to this rather than let it die off.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												I recommend this game for those who are interested in finding a Quake-like game. This game was extremely fun, if not challenging. A lot of people can't keep up with how challenging it is, but for those looking for a hard shoot em up, this is your game. The gameplay is extremely fun, where you collect nano machines to upgrade your weapons/combat capabilities as you continue on your way through Bezoar City. The way you switch weapons on the fly is also pretty convenient, without having to go through a weapon wheel to find what weapon you're looking for... your weapons carry ALL the modifications you upgrade. The storyline is a bit lackluster.. tons of potential to be had, but not executed as well as i would have hoped. The graphics are amazing and really put you in the world... very atmospheric and the ambience fits just right in the cyberpunk universe. The music is hit and miss, where the battle music got heavily annoying after a few hours.. but the overall scores being played as you traversed the robotic wasteland were wonderful and verily eery during some parts. I loved the experience and i definitely recommend it to anyone in the market for such a title.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Edit: I am doing something I meant to take care of a long time ago, and that is revisit my rating of this game. In the end the game does what it sets out to do well and I ended up going back and giving it a THIRD chance and....third time is the charm. The game is a little clunky (not in controls just some odd mechanics and level layout) a little basic, but old school run and gun is what it does very well. Some of the game challenge is a little bit of cheap design but, looking back, that is pretty old school ha. Below is my negative review for the sake of honestly. Considering how much I loved Shadow Warrior by the same studio I was thrilled to see this go on Flash Sale here on Steam. Well. I'm certainly not thrilled anymore and deleted the game from my library. The entire strategy of level design found in Hard Reset can be summarized through "put em' in a tiny room with a bunch of bad guys, ya, that would be hard right?". Sure. It's tough but not because the people that made the game are clever. An entire game like this wouldn't have been tolerated as a gamers oh so sacred and nostalgia protected classic and they shouldn't be tolerated in modern games either. Nothing about this game is a throwback honestly and is just fairly inept. Besides the pretty graphics, man they sure are pretty. But it's just over all pretty terrible and a major let down. For 3.74 I'm not angry, just disappointed. Pick up Shadow Warrior instead if you're looking for a "retro FPS with a touch of modern design".

Posted: December 7, 2015
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine  PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this game Hard Reset is developed by Flying Wild Hog, the people behind Shadow Warrior and its upcoming sequel. Hard Reset was developed before Shadow Warrior and you can tell that the company did not have as much of a bigger budget as Shadow Warrior didThe story basically follows a dystopian world where robots have taken over by a sophisticated A.I., you play a major known as Fletcher, throughout the story you have to try and find out the reasons why the robots have turned against the humans and stop those who are responsible. The story is very cliche and does follow what many other sci-fi films back in the day managed to achieveThe environments are absolutely stunning, and the lighting effects in particular really make the enviornments come alive. The explosions also play a big role in Hard Reset and really make the game more explosive in its action, however, even though I have a PC that can run it on ultra settings, I did suffer with some minor frame rate drops when there was a lot of action going about. Now, I don't know what the developers where trying to go through the environments, but the game really reminded me of Blade Runner, a sci-fi thriller classic. The high rise buildings, the flying cars and that Chinese/Japanese (sorry can't tell the difference) adevertising on large blimps, I think the developers where heavily inspired by Blade Runner when they were designing Hard ResetTalking about game performance, this game does suffer with poor game performance. Sometimes the game freezes monetarily even in heavy combat areas, this may be due to the high amounts of enemies and explosive effects taking placeThe A.I., the game's difficulty changes drastically, especially in the last bit of the main story and then the rest of the DLC story, I first played on Normal difficulty and it was so annoying that I died so many times that I had to lower it to the Easy difficulty which lowered the amount of times I died and these robots sure do have precision aim shooting, because in Hard Reset they have precision aim shooting!The music and sound effects were okay but what really made me happy was that whilst playing, it did remind me of Blade Runner quite a lot!Like previously said, you will die, a lot, thankfully there is a fair checkpoint system in the game. The voice acting was bad and I mean really bad. You can tell that in Shadow Warrior they had a bigger budget because at least in that game the voice acting was good, in Hard Reset, they were really bad. The only good performance I would say was from the professor, nobody elseThe gunplay is okay, nothing special though. I think the game was also heavily inspired by old shooters like DOOM, as it does try to bring in that same formula to Hard ResetLastly, what really made me not want to continue playing was the re-use of the enemies. I don't know how many times I saw the same enemies over and over again every single time through my whole playthrough. It really made me not want to continue playing... Plus, what is up with the endings!? The main story's ending is really bad and ends on a huge cliffhanger leaving you helpless as to what has just happened and what will happen, thankfully Flying Wild Hog made an extended edition which includes the Exile DLC for free which continues the main game. But even that ending, it has that ending of, "Oh, don't worry, everything will be explained in due time", and just ends like that...I had fun playing Hard Reset, even though it did have its fair share of problems here and there, but on the whole, it was a really good action game. I wouldn't recommend Hard Reset for its full asking price as I feel it does not satisfy me to pay full price, but if it is in a sale, price drop, etc... I would definitely recommend you buying it, if you love sci-fi or Blade Runner or both like me RECOMMENDED :)
