Posted: December 8, 2015
IntroductionI wanted to play a shooter again, it had been a while. And here came Hard Reset on a sale, looking like a shooter with cool weapons, retro-gameplay and fancy graphics in a dark megacity setting. Sounded like something I would enjoy.Gameplay and DifficultyI completed the game on Hard and when this game says Hard, it means HARD. I rarely finished a level with under 2-5 deaths, some arenas cost me close to 10 deaths, because I either didn't choose the right weapon upgrades and consequently struggled, or I simply got overwhelmed by a surprise wave of enemies. Hard Reset is pretty simple in terms of game mechanics, the gameplay could be summarized like this:Enter arena. Run around in circles, relentlessly firing, dodging and switching between your poorly performing weapons, while trying to run from hordes of almost endlessly spawning mobs until you run out of ammo and powerups. Die. Try again. Finally beat arena. Proceed through corridor. Get ambushed. Enter next arena. Repeat. Occasionally you have to press buttons to proceed, that's really all there is to it.I'm usually the type for deep and rich gameplay, thinking up clever solutions, progressing tactically. I like games that make you think. This game is nothing like that and I'm aware this sounds like a full-fledged rant so far, BUT: what it does, it does well. The mechanics in place are well balanced, sprinting, jumping, shooting, environment damage, powerup placement and strength, enemy strength vs. weapon damage. It all was balanced with the grand scheme of gameplay in mind. Some arenas feel a bit overdone, the developers just love to throw in waves and waves of mobs, probably to extend the playtime a little more. However, once you learn what enemy types to expect in which quantities and where the powerups are, things get more manageable. And still, each mob does crazy damage, there is little room for mistakes. Mobs also have tons of health and the big boys take quite a bit ammo to take down. Smaller enemies come in larger quantities regularly and still each have quite a bit of health, so you're often better off using the big calibers with AoE for small enemies as well. Enemies mostly feel like bullet sponges - and that's okay to make the game work as it is designed, given the design of arenas and the circumstances of powerups etc. The problem is that the game just doesn't give you the feeling of real weapon impact which is a big factor of fun in most shooters. Not so much here.What's fun on the other hand is the management of space to run, retreating into the right corners, using the right weapons, dodging in the right moments, leaving powerups on the ground until you actually need them, it's all enough to consider to keep the game interesting.Boss battles are well done as a combination of getting swarmed by waves of distractive mobs and having to hit special zones on the boss's body that need to be destroyed to take the boss down.I like the AI in this game because mobs seem to cooperate to take you down. Mobs often run around you through adjacent corridors in order to attack you from all sides. Other than that, the AI is reasonably predictable once you've observed each mob's behaviour.Level designThe level design overall is pretty linear and one-dimensional. Visually most of the game takes place in a dark Blade Runner'esque megacity, most of which is beautifully built. Unfortunately it gets repetitive after a while and leaves you longing for a change. It's not until the Exile DLC expansion that the overall setting changes to a brighter scrapyard wasteland, which to me was a welcome change at that point.Many level elements return quite often, like forklifts blocking paths, while lifting the fork allows you to progess, or optionally powering up or down button panels to open doors. A little more variety wouldn't have hurt here.Quite often you'd bump into invisible walls blocking progress or keeping you from jumping over obstacles. This can be quite tedious when there's only one supposed way to get to a secret, but there's no way to tell where there's a hole in the invisible wall.VerdictSo how does that add up? Let's take a look at the pros and cons:*Pros*+ Graphics are really good, performance is sublime for the visual quality+ Sound is amazing+ Good soundtrack (with a few exceptions)+ Immersive dark and gritty atmosphere+ Fast-paced non-stop action, bug- and glitch-free+ Smooth user interface+ Motivating upgrade system (at least until midgame, in endgame all the necessary weapons and defensive stats are maxed out and there's no more need to upgrade)+ Interesting and tough boss battles, really gets you on your toes+ Good AI - enemy groups split up and try to attack from all sides, even sometimes taking the longer path around an obstacles to sneak at you from behind*Cons*- Often repetitive and easily predictable level design- Few enemy types- Weak weapons (or too tanky enemies)- Often unnecessarily prolonged battles - too many waves of mobs- Some weapons are useless - I almost exclusively used the RPG, Mortar and Railgun and did just fine. Assault Rifle and Plasma Rifle never got used anymore when other weapons were unlocked- Weapon switch times. This game requires frequent weapon switches and there are a few occasions where you just don't have the time to switch weapons. So if you're not prepared, you getting swarmed and you die.- Less than stellar German translation and synchronization- Some annoying songs in the soundtrack- Invisible walls, often annoying placement of N.A.N.O. (currency) requiring you to make fiddly jumps. I sometimes couldn't be bothered.So, do I recommend this game? Overall, yes! Buy it if you don't mind the simplistic gameplay and if you have a high-ish frustration tolerance. Do not buy it if you don't like arena battles and the circumstance of being constantly ambushed, surrounded and swarmed.Overall rating: 79/100

Posted: July 28, 2015
												I got Hard Reset on sale. I purchased it because I liked the Blade Runner vibe in the screenshots and trailers. Having just finished it, I can honestly say I would not have been disappointed even if I had purchased it at full price. Hard Reset is a run and gun that does not reinvent the wheel, but what it does, it does very well. The graphics and level design were great. The difficulty level, while at times frustrating, was neither too easy nor too difficult.  When it seemed like I had died 10 times in the same fight, I would step away from the game, but its fun, and I always came back for more. The weapons system is very simple - two highly upgradable guns. The upgrades were great - some of them more than others (smart gun and RPG were my favorites.) You can also upgrade the health system in a variety of ways. Its not overly complex, but it mixes things up a bit.Some people have complained about the repetitive look of things and the recycling of enemies. I actually really loved the art design of the game (the more human than human signs were a nice touch), especially in the Exile portion of the game, which has a completely different color palette than the main section. I didn't think the number of varying enemies was any less interesting than in say, Doom or Half-Life. I learned, as the game went on, how to handle different kinds of enemies with the weapons at my disposal.Another complaint I have seen is that Hard Reset is "story lite." This is true, but not to the extent I feared. The story/ concept is delivered in a format that mimics a comic book (which I thought was kind of cool), and while it isn't overly deep and doesn't have much in the way of character development, it compliments the game sufficiently to keep my interest. More than anything it serves to break up the "chapters/ levels" of the game and give context to the environment. This is NOT Deus Ex: Human Revolution, but its not just an arcade shoot-em-up either. I clocked about 29 hours before I was done with the main game and Exile DLC, but I went back a few times to try to find the "secrets" and to raise my level scores. These small elements give the game some limited replayability, and the overall length of the game is fantastic for the price. I have seen some say that it seems to drag on, but honestly, for my money, I would rather have a longer game than a shorter one, especially these days. Best of all, I had zero issues with this game - no crashes, no freezes, nothing. It just played right away and worked straight through to the end. When I would get swamped with enemies at times, my frame rate would drop, but given the sheer amount of activity on the screen this never suprised me or inhibited my play. Its relatively rare these days to find a game that isn't half broken on release, but Hard Reset is on that short list for me. So, all in all, kudos to the developers for making a GREAT run and gun game. I was thoroughly entertained and definitely recommend Hard Reset.

Posted: May 13, 2016
												After 3 hours of playing, and managing to get to the fourth level, I can say that this game is definitely not an average shooter. It is difficult and requires swift movement and weapon switching for the situation at hand. It is well-optimized, only losing FPS on cramped areas with lots of explosives. It also features a brutal checkpoint system that CAN and WILL punish you for failing to observe your surroundings and dying stupid deaths. It is also king enough to save right before encountering a new enemy type so you can learn the strategy without needing to wade through robots again.Secrets are scattered throughout the levels and can require out of the box thinking, platforming, and use of environmental hazards to reach.Gameplay: 8/10Visuals: 9.7/10Replay-Value: 5/10Overall: 8.7/10

Posted: May 12, 2016
												This is a really fantastic game, imo.  I love the sci-fi setting - environments, robotic enemies, weapon selection, etc.  The upgrade system is pretty cool and you can get upgrades fairly quickly if you spend a little time searching for hidden loot.  It's mechanically a very solid and smooth FPS - easy to control with no noticable bugs that I've seen.  The graphics still look beautiful even though I had to turn the settings down a bit.  In terms of difficulty, I would say it's a bit harder than most games I've played in the genre.  I'm not great at FPS games - I generally play on normal difficulty but I found myself having to play this one on easy, which I consider to be about right for me.While I think the retail price of $15 is totally fair, I got it on sale for $2.24 so I would recommend waiting for another sale.  Overall, a great game that I highly recommend to FPS fans, especially if you like the dystopian sci-fi setting.  That being said, there is an updated version, Hard Reset Redux, in the works.  No word on a release date or price but you may want to wait for it, especially if you have a system that can fully take advantage of the improved graphics.

Posted: April 30, 2015
												Hard Reset caught some flack for being a relatively short game with a small variety of enemies that don't do anything more than the one or two actions they make.HOWEVER!  These are the only real problems these reviewers actually have with the title.  To them, I say "Phooey".  Hard Reset is a wonderful arcade-y shooter game that's focused on obliterating a lot of robots while moving, shooting and running constantly through a very well designed futuristic city.  It's incredibly linear with the occasional small alleyway or fence that hides some bonus points, but this is perfect for how the game is meant to be.  It keeps you going and shooting, and the enemies get varied at the correct times, and they spawn in the perfect places to make for a challenging and fun experience.  I love the world, I love the feel, I love the art (especially the city), and I love the game.Quick note:  The story is extremely weak, but the story shouldn't be the focus of a game of this type anyway.  Solid 8 or 9/10.  There is NO reason to not pick this title up if Steam throws it on sale (which happens quite often).

Posted: December 26, 2014
												TLDR; Excellent run-and-gun game, but I felt let down a bit by the ending, it felt decidedly 'unepic'.Well, OK it was a "Walk cautiously-and-gun" game. I've played this game twice, now. If you play it on  Easy, you'll see an arena type area, and go "here we go again and run in" If you play it on normal, you will see an arena area and go "oh no I'm going to get smashed again and try and sneak past (not gonna happen)"Some of the 'unique' things about this game, You can't crouch (whatdya MEAN I can't get through there)there is limited ammo (slowly recharges over time, but plenty of pickups from fallen bots)BUT there is no reload. all your ammo is in one big clip! it's so great!The Smart Gun on the NRG is OP Forget your rifle, max this as fast as you can, then go for you rifle's rocket launcheryou only get 2 guns, but they get a snotload of alt fire modesRPG elements through choosing what to upgrade... either gun, and choose from a variety of mods, or buff yourself with extra health / armour/ scanner/radar/medkit etc (I suggest getting the money-raqdar ASAP... before you get any gun upgrades)Gameplay tends to be tight corridors that lead into arena style rooms.Annoying thingsYou can't crouchinvisible walls. If they don't want you to go through there yet, you can't parkour it.arena battles, doors auto lock until you finish the fight, even though they work perfectly before and after the fight.the jumping/platforming bits (mostly for secrets) felt wrong. your character's movement through these sections is hard, as you move so fast by default, and no quicksave (it auto saves before every arena, and right before any parkour-to-your-death bits)The story was a huge let down thus far, even though it's open for a sequel, it felt like they finished in the middle of the story. Killing the boss didn't feel like taking down the baddies, merely  getting him out of the way so you could get through the next gate. (compounded the storyline)things i likedSecrets are REALLY worth taking the time to find. that extra cash allows you to build up your weapons much, much faster.without them, you might only have half the stuff unlocked by the end boss fight.on Normal, I was panicking about every corner, setting off the next wave of enemies.Oh, that Smart gun.you have real speed in this game, making a truely run-gun experience. Similar to Shadow Warrior (If you've played that, It's by the same guys, but you'd know that by all the references to HR in SW)the -nomagazine mechanic in the gunsgraphically beautifulThe physics engine feels spot-on most of the time (the way stuff gets thrown / lands / etc)With hints on, you can focus largely on gameplay, especially as some of the 'puzzles' can be otherwise obscure.So, A good looking FPS shooter with no quicksave (not a bad thing), RPG elements,  engaging and tactical combat (different enemy types are wiped out best by different weapon mods), and a few quirks. It took me 15h to clock it on easy (100% secrets), I have only got partway through on Normal so far.

Posted: July 28, 2015
												I got Hard Reset on sale. I purchased it because I liked the Blade Runner vibe in the screenshots and trailers. Having just finished it, I can honestly say I would not have been disappointed even if I had purchased it at full price. Hard Reset is a run and gun that does not reinvent the wheel, but what it does, it does very well. The graphics and level design were great. The difficulty level, while at times frustrating, was neither too easy nor too difficult.  When it seemed like I had died 10 times in the same fight, I would step away from the game, but its fun, and I always came back for more. The weapons system is very simple - two highly upgradable guns. The upgrades were great - some of them more than others (smart gun and RPG were my favorites.) You can also upgrade the health system in a variety of ways. Its not overly complex, but it mixes things up a bit.Some people have complained about the repetitive look of things and the recycling of enemies. I actually really loved the art design of the game (the more human than human signs were a nice touch), especially in the Exile portion of the game, which has a completely different color palette than the main section. I didn't think the number of varying enemies was any less interesting than in say, Doom or Half-Life. I learned, as the game went on, how to handle different kinds of enemies with the weapons at my disposal.Another complaint I have seen is that Hard Reset is "story lite." This is true, but not to the extent I feared. The story/ concept is delivered in a format that mimics a comic book (which I thought was kind of cool), and while it isn't overly deep and doesn't have much in the way of character development, it compliments the game sufficiently to keep my interest. More than anything it serves to break up the "chapters/ levels" of the game and give context to the environment. This is NOT Deus Ex: Human Revolution, but its not just an arcade shoot-em-up either. I clocked about 29 hours before I was done with the main game and Exile DLC, but I went back a few times to try to find the "secrets" and to raise my level scores. These small elements give the game some limited replayability, and the overall length of the game is fantastic for the price. I have seen some say that it seems to drag on, but honestly, for my money, I would rather have a longer game than a shorter one, especially these days. Best of all, I had zero issues with this game - no crashes, no freezes, nothing. It just played right away and worked straight through to the end. When I would get swamped with enemies at times, my frame rate would drop, but given the sheer amount of activity on the screen this never suprised me or inhibited my play. Its relatively rare these days to find a game that isn't half broken on release, but Hard Reset is on that short list for me. So, all in all, kudos to the developers for making a GREAT run and gun game. I was thoroughly entertained and definitely recommend Hard Reset.

Posted: February 5, 2012
												For a game that was made in about 3 months, hard reset is actually pretty good (especially if you can pick it up for dirt cheap during a sale 5$).  The game basically feels like an old school shooter so no running into cover waiting for your shield/health to regen like a little girl.  It feels very old school which is going to either be a good or bad thing depending on your preference in shooters.  How the weapons work is actually pretty well thought out.  You essentially get 2 weapons, BUT those 2 weapons each have 5 different firing modes (so 10 weapons basically...) so switching to one weapon adds the modes to 1,2,3,4,5 on the keyboard and vice versa.  You can upgrade your weapons however you want, so you can make your favorite guns even more powerful and give them new firing modes.  The game also looks extremely pretty since it was developed ONLY for the pc.  No need to worry about the usual console port issues.  The story is pretty bad however, but it is good cheap fun.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Hard Reset is a sumptuous visual feast with massive boss fights.  It is amazing how the imagery surpasses a lot of the big-name titles that I see coming out.  The game has an upgrade system that functions like currency.  There are only two weapons, but each has about six intensive  diverse upgrades.  From rocket launchers, grenade launchers, to plasma cannon, EMP emitters, and a railgun, the weapons are hard hitting with a sound to match.  Most of the environment is explosive, electrocuting, and destructible which helps in dispatching an array of robots.  Cutscenes have a gritty, if not entirely cohesive storyline which was the only detraction.  The level designs are put together well and there is variety so that it doesn’t get repetitive.  The developers took a lot of time.  The gameplay will keep you engaged as it takes what’s right with old-school shooters, and adds faster elements .

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Now this is a very nice science fiction pulp game. It reminded me of some good old science fiction movies of the 80's and 90's like Screamers (somekind of terminator droid sf), Blade Runner etc. The details in the game are quite well worked out and the game looks very beautifull. The add signs on buildings. Flying ships and fancy modern and futuristic looking buildings and roads. The story telling is done cartoon style in the cutscenes. That actually takes a little away from the beauty that the gameplay levels have. It is about a world been partly taken over by renegade terminator style droid. The droids use razor blades to kill their targets. You are a mercenary been orded to take them out. You are actually in for the money. The sounds are good. Graphics and level building are extraordinary done. Although the gaming levels are quite linear. It is no free roaming the world in this game. The single player is worth it. It is a well made low budget game. Like the old movies these memories usually stay the longest. While afterwards you start to realise and appreciate the quality and effort that has been put in this game. There are no multiplayer features in this game. The AI enemies sometimes use little predictable tactics. These are the only two cons I can recall. So if you like to play a single player written story I would most definitely recommend this game.

Posted: December 28, 2012
												Hard Reset, oh boy. Though this game is a bit short, it is a fun (though nonsensical) sci-fi FPS. It is BRUTALLY diifficult: enemies prefer to use ambush tactics, come in big waves, and are quite capable of overwhelming the player. The player themselves has access to 2 weapons with 5 separate modes each, along with a secondary function for each mode. The CLN firearm is an advaned ballistic firearm, spewing bullets, mines, rockets, and grenades. The NRG weapon blasts rapidfire plasma orbs, plasma orbs that zap anything around them, shortrange lightning, tracking spheres, and it has a railgun mode. Ammo can be a bit tight in this game on occasion, however ammo for both guns regen if low enough, though this is rarely practical in combat.In short, it is a brutal game, but a lot of fun, especially after a few weapon upgrades.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												An excellent modern-made throwback to the more arcade-style shooters of the 90s. It looks great (it runs quite well too), it plays better. The developers pulled off the cyberpunk theme very well and fighting the "mutant robots" as I would call has never been this much fun. The design decision on two physical weapons that morph into multiple different functional weapons is an interesting and pleasing approach to the "this dude can carry 20 different weapons" factor. This game, at higher difficulty levels, is also very challenging. Experienced and older fans of the genre will find themselves at home amidst the dystopian city. Definitely recommended, download the demo to see what its all about.

												Hard Reset is SO good.While it is more linear than not, it keeps to the old school open levels, health and shield pickups, fast paced precision shooting and the arsenal in a pocket of first person shooters of old. Add to that some spectacular visuals and you get a triple A looking shooter that provides a serious challenge and hours of running and gunning joy. I found that playing on normal was very fair and well paced up until the Exile DLC (at which point I got my butt served to me on a silver platter) so I’m sure the replayability into the hard, insane and heroic modes is there.If you’re not a fan of the modern military shooter, join the club. But also think about giving Hard Reset a chance. It’s as if they stripped everything that makes Battlefield and COD dull and replaced it with over the top awesomeness.

Posted: April 7, 2015
												I got to say I liked Hard Reset quite a bit. I didn't quite care about the story, but the shooting was satisfying. The game has some nice visuals and futuristic industrial atmosphere. I liked getting back to the game.I've seen some complaints about the use of weapons in this game. At first it was strange how they have arranged the bullet-type weapons and energy-type weapons separately under Q and E buttons. Each type has many weapon variations under the number buttons. Once you get the hang of it, it works out smoothly and in my opinion the system is actually quite neat. I played the game and the Exile DLC through on normal difficulty. The game offered a some more challenging areas and some that I could have tried on hard difficulty. The harder parts did not feel unfair though and I was challenged to try again after getting killed. I also like the upgrade system in which by gathering nano-crates gives you options to upgrade weapons armor etc. Also the statistics after each level were interesting and give a reason to play the missions again.Overall I would recommend the game for fans of sci-fi shooters.

Posted: June 15, 2015
												Hard Reset gets a 8.5/10 from me, it's a good game. The only reason why there are some negative reviews is that this game is oldschool, meaning that you actually need skill and reflexes with a bit of tactic to survive. So if you're a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ casual go back to your cave, if you want a good oldschool shooter that rewards skill rather than grind, hard reset is the game for you.Let's start with the story: You are a cop/merc that has to kill all robots, thats basically it.Graphics:  The levels are colorful and the graphics of this game are awesome, lots of ligth effects, screenshake, uber physics, you can basically destzory everthing that is not attached to another object.Enemies: A bit monotone but require reflexes and the right tactic. Gunplay feels good, with some weapons being less rewarding than others, overall motivation is also good, exploring levels is quite well rewarded and you always look for more upgrades.I picked this game up for 3 bucks and had awesome fun with it, wish there were more games with this palystyle and graphics today, you won't find a better shooter for this price at the moment, devs even gave out a DLC for it.

Posted: December 26, 2014
												TLDR; Excellent run-and-gun game, but I felt let down a bit by the ending, it felt decidedly 'unepic'.Well, OK it was a "Walk cautiously-and-gun" game. I've played this game twice, now. If you play it on  Easy, you'll see an arena type area, and go "here we go again and run in" If you play it on normal, you will see an arena area and go "oh no I'm going to get smashed again and try and sneak past (not gonna happen)"Some of the 'unique' things about this game, You can't crouch (whatdya MEAN I can't get through there)there is limited ammo (slowly recharges over time, but plenty of pickups from fallen bots)BUT there is no reload. all your ammo is in one big clip! it's so great!The Smart Gun on the NRG is OP Forget your rifle, max this as fast as you can, then go for you rifle's rocket launcheryou only get 2 guns, but they get a snotload of alt fire modesRPG elements through choosing what to upgrade... either gun, and choose from a variety of mods, or buff yourself with extra health / armour/ scanner/radar/medkit etc (I suggest getting the money-raqdar ASAP... before you get any gun upgrades)Gameplay tends to be tight corridors that lead into arena style rooms.Annoying thingsYou can't crouchinvisible walls. If they don't want you to go through there yet, you can't parkour it.arena battles, doors auto lock until you finish the fight, even though they work perfectly before and after the fight.the jumping/platforming bits (mostly for secrets) felt wrong. your character's movement through these sections is hard, as you move so fast by default, and no quicksave (it auto saves before every arena, and right before any parkour-to-your-death bits)The story was a huge let down thus far, even though it's open for a sequel, it felt like they finished in the middle of the story. Killing the boss didn't feel like taking down the baddies, merely  getting him out of the way so you could get through the next gate. (compounded the storyline)things i likedSecrets are REALLY worth taking the time to find. that extra cash allows you to build up your weapons much, much faster.without them, you might only have half the stuff unlocked by the end boss fight.on Normal, I was panicking about every corner, setting off the next wave of enemies.Oh, that Smart gun.you have real speed in this game, making a truely run-gun experience. Similar to Shadow Warrior (If you've played that, It's by the same guys, but you'd know that by all the references to HR in SW)the -nomagazine mechanic in the gunsgraphically beautifulThe physics engine feels spot-on most of the time (the way stuff gets thrown / lands / etc)With hints on, you can focus largely on gameplay, especially as some of the 'puzzles' can be otherwise obscure.So, A good looking FPS shooter with no quicksave (not a bad thing), RPG elements,  engaging and tactical combat (different enemy types are wiped out best by different weapon mods), and a few quirks. It took me 15h to clock it on easy (100% secrets), I have only got partway through on Normal so far.

Posted: December 26, 2014
												Hard Reset is definitely an old school style shooter.  The game gets fairly difficult at times so dying repeatedly in certain areas is to be expected.  The story isn't amazing but the cutscenes are done in animated comic book style which is pretty cool.  The original campaign isn't too long, but combined with the Exile DLC, this game becomes a bit lengthier.  Because the DLC adds on more levels without including more weapons/upgrades, the game becomes harder, especially if the upgrades chosen before entering the DLC levels were purely offensive like I did.  The enemies become much tankier so getting upgrades on health, defense, and ammo are definitely needed.  On the other hand, the level design were more varied, which is a plus, and felt better overall.Technically, there are only two weapons, but each gun has multiple modes.  For example, one gun can transform from an assault rifle to a grenade launcher while the other can morph from traps to a rail gun.  Choosing the proper weapon and mode on the fly takes a while to get used to, but becomes fairly satisfying once you get the hang of it.  If your mouse has extra buttons, it's probably a good idea to hotkey the weapon swap to one of them as pressing the keys for it always felt a bit awkward for me.It's got a decent length campaign mode as well as other replayable modes, which I haven't tried.  While the story isn't quite there, I would recommend this if you want to play an old school shooter game.

Posted: May 17, 2015
												A fantastic but short first person shooter if you wish to kill some time. This game adapts some elements from old school first person shooters such as Quake. There's no reloading, no objective markers telling you where to go, no in game scripted cutscenes, and best of all, no regenerating health. I got in game on sale for $1.49 from bundle stars. It was definitely worth it without a doubt. But if you're expecting an fantastic Oscar award winning story from this game, you're not going to get any. Personally, when it comes to fps games, I for one do not care about storytelling aside from Halo and perhaps Bioshock, because when it comes to fps, I want experience whatever action the games deliver, which this game definitely does. There's action in every step of the way. But in case, you're curious, the game storyline honestly makes no sense, but like I said, who cares. You play as Major James Fletcher, some kind of cop, soldier, detective guy who has to fight his way through this futuristic looking city of Japan known as Bezoar through hordes of corrupt machines. To be honest, you're going to fighting the same exact machines over and over to the point where you might be bored of them. But don't worry, after the confusing ending from the 2nd boss fight, you will get to play the Exile Dlc, which will the continue the story. Gameplay wise, like I said, you have to pick up health and ammo, which is what I prefer a lot in first person shooters. There are 2 weapons to carry but you can keep upgrading them to do amazing things such as turning your assault rifle into a shotgun and shoot pellets that stun enemies.Above all, Hard Reset is a nice looking, fast paced first person shooter which you barely see nowadays. It's very short and you can beat in just a day so get it when it's on sale. If you enjoy classic styles in fps games, then pick up this game.

Posted: December 10, 2014
												In Hard Reset, you play a man with a metal eyes and no knees, in his quest to shoot every last robot ever.I would summarise the plot more, but I genuinely can't. I just don't understand it. However, the characters in the game seem to know what's going on, and I'm more than happy to let them handle the major decisions. I'll just shoot the robots, thanks very much.The plot is revealed to the player via cutscenes which have a pretty great animated comic-book style to them, bringing back fond memories of games like Max Payne. Gameplay is fun. The environments are impressive and reward player exploration. They have no shortage of things to blow up, and no shortage of things to blow them up with, because instead of picking up guns along the way, you start the game with both of the guns you will ever need, one gun that fires bullets, and one that fires plasma. When you pick up "nano" (the currency), a bar on your HUD will fill. When you reach 100%, it gives you one unlockable slot at an upgrade point, which gives your guns extra functionality. Buy a shotgun slot, and your gun gains the option to fire like a shotgun, etc. Thus you can scroll through each weapon's abilities like you would in any other FPS.It's a very neat concept, and one that comes in handy during intense firefights - of which there are plenty - switching between the plasma guns and the bullet guns to gain any advantage against the robot swarms.The music is pretty awesome too, and really sets the tone of this cyberpunk futuristic sprawling mega-tropolis. Not being too familiar with this sort of music, some of the tracks that play during combat remind me a bit of Pendulum, which I like.Visually, the game is a treat. The city looks grungy and run down, with worn paint and chipped metal contrasting nicely with garish neon and arcing electric bolts here and there. There's no problem at all telling what's environment and what's enemy, like in some games I've played, so you won't get your health chipped away by something you just can't see.This all sounds pretty great, right? So what's bad about the game?Well in my first sentence, I said that you play a man with no knees. Well that's pretty accurate, as you CANNOT CROUCH in this game. This is pretty irritating when you feel like taking cover might be helpful, or when there's a chest-high gap in a fence that you can't POSSIBLY get past.The most glaring example of this is probably in one of the warehouse levels, when a girder has fallen to approximately face height, blocking off a short path to the level exit. You don't even need to crouch to get past that. Just bend over by like five degrees. But no, you're forced down the other route that has explosions, fire, and angry robots just itching to taste your flesh.Another thing that annoys me is that your guy can - and will - get ganked, usually by enemies called Gorillas, that charge-slam you ever few seconds. It becomes very easy to go from full health to dead, trapped in a corner, being beaten by Gorillas, which is where another one of my niggles joins in:No quicksave/load. This kind of speaks for itself. Fast, frantic shooters like this NEED quicksave. In games like Alien Isolation, where not being able to save is legitmately part of the game, because the survival thing is supposed to be tense. In games like this, where you play a stompy god of hellfire, slowing down the fast-paced fun is irksome.Weapons. I really like the weapon system in this game, but it becomes very obvious quite early on that there is a right choice. That choice is the electric mortar. Area of effect attack instantly blows up the generic foot soldier robots, and saps the others. Switch that out with the grenade launcher, and you can very quickly turn the screen into an orgy of exploded robot parts. I've discovered no other combos of guns (as of yet) that can measure up in terms of fast, widespread, heavy damage.To conclude: Hard Reset is a bloody fun game, that will keep you entertained for as long as you care to play it. It's most assuredly worth the asking price.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												Hard Reset is a game made with old school FPS sensibilities. It comes from the Serious Sam/Painkiller mold, where you have to run around like a maniac to kill baddies that are bigger and faster than you. Plus it's a cyber-punk game, but Deus Ex this ain't.The game has a lot going for it, even with some of its budget title sensibilities. The shooting is intense and satisfying, and the game features a variety of difficulty levels to match your skill level. You're equipped with two guns that can change forms to become 10 different weapons total. Learning the special features of all the weapons is key to surviving the fights that Hard Reset throws at you. Guns can be upgraded and unlocked at numerous kiosks strewn throughout the game, with credits picked up from enemy bots and secret areas. Here's where one of the game's flaws show up; there is no New Game Plus mode where you get to run back through earlier levels of the game with your upgraded guns, which would have been a lot of fun.The game is pretty to look at but short, even with the added DLC they give you for free, and the story never makes any sense. Even then, the price is right for a good, fast and fun shooter experience. These are the same guys responsible for the 2013 revamp of Shadow Warrior, and while the experience here isn't as polished as what you'll find there, it's still got a lot of bang for your buck. Worth it if you catch it on super sale!

Posted: March 7, 2014
												Hard Reset provides a sugary love letter to fans of the no holds barred, 12 gun carrying, wall to wall shooting and explosions shooters of the past; however in doing so it still maintains a modern identity of its own. In a market teeming with ironsight, cover system and squad command based first person shooter games (which are all of very high quality), it's intreresting to see a game chisel away the layers of peripheral gameplay features that have been slowly added one by one to make modern shooters what they are today and deliver a no nonsense fight-to-survive action rollercoaster. There's no aiming down sights, no taking cover or even crouching for that matter, no huge expansive environments, no mediocre plot that's trying to hard. There is a story and some really nice graphic novel-esque FMVs, but it's clear that this is a game all about playing. Imagine anything from the family of original first person shooters like Wolfenstein or Quake, just with high end graphics and a weapon modulation and upgrade system. But the core of the game is just you, your gun and a boatload of mechanical gribblies that want to saw you to pieces. This is a very neat game.

Posted: May 8, 2014
												The people at "Flying Wild Hog" studios set out to make a cyber-punk shooter with fun gun-play mechanics....and they did it! 1)The overall experience: it's fast, action packed and simply fun. A person, who's childhood was based in the 90s, will notice that this game is heavily inspired by the old-school classics like Doom, Quake, Duke Nukem 3D and Shadow Warrior - your health is displayed on your lower left corner along with your ammo and shield capacity. If you are not careful those attributes will get depleted and you'll simply die with no ammo or health.  2)Digging a little deeper into the game - the game's story takes a backseat to it's gameplay. You are equipped with two guns which transform into several types and they can be upgraded throughout the game. This is the only modern mechanic implamented into the game. The game is powered by RoadHog Engine - there are impressive lighting effects, physics and decent textures, but the areas that you will visit are not verried. You'll visit the same industrial cyber-punk vistas, but from different angles. 3) Final Verdict - Hard Reset dosen't set out to re-imagine the genre. It is a familiar shooter, that brings back good memories of the fun I used to have while playing the shooters of the 90s! A great nostalgia trip and challenge for the modern gamer! I give Hard Reset a 8/10! :)

Posted: January 7, 2014
												Hard Reset is one of these things called "Old School Shooters". In other words, the story is not worth mentioning, the enemy AI doesn't deserve the name, and the levels are as linear it gets thanks to our old friend "Mr Invisible Wall".And you know what? It doesn't matter. Because you get to blow up stuff. As in, LOTS of stuff. With numerous different weapons (or rather, one shooty gun and one flashy gun that however can transform into anything ranging from shotguns to rocket launchers to rail guns to tesla guns).So, you run around an kill robots. Again, LOTS of robots (though they sadly come in seven to nine different varieties only). And of course the big sky-scraper sized boss robots, too. The entire thing actually looks pretty damn good while all those bots get torn apart by bombs, bullets and lightning. The Soundtrack helps too, blending in nicely with the dystopian cyberpunk setting of the game in calm moments and turning to pumping electronica once the next wave of buzzsaw-mouth hoppers and fat, tough chargers comes in.TL/DR: If you like to shoot stuff, this game is for you.

Posted: January 18, 2014
Pretty fun little first person shooterOldschool, very linear, corridor and arena battles.  No crouching, lots of invisble fences to stop you from wandering or hopping up to higher ground.   Doors almost always lock behind you.  Lots of enemies, lots of dieing, very exciting action.  Battles can be very difficult but seems to always be an appropriate tactic for each.  Choose the right weapon combo and use environment right and you sail through, choose wrong and you die quickly.  Modern graphics, high detail levels and the enemy models are very good.  Story is alright, voice acting variable, player character's voice acting and dialog a little poor.  Poor use of expletives.Pros:  Really good action. Exciting, fast battles, lots of enemies. Decent variety of enemies.  Good weapon upgrade system with lots of interesting combos to use.  The over charge upgrade on the plasma gun for example is powerful and effective without taking the tiresome old route of exploding if held too long or immediately discharging. Well balanced fun weapon.  All weapons have their place and there is still use for the earlier weapons right up until the end of the game.  Nice looking game, a little dark (very Blade Runner) but overall good visual style. Its cheap too.ConsInvisible fences are annoying, no way to know if you can jump up on or pass something other than trying.  No quick save feature or any user controlled save.  Player character dialogue is littered with pointless poorly used F-bombs and poorly voice acted. Linear, door-locking-behind-you-before-ambush gameplay gets a little tiring.SumaryTruly oldschool style FPS with nice modern graphics and fast exciting action.  If you like oldschool shooters and cut your teeth on Doom you will love it.  If linear, confined gameplay isnt your thing it may not be a good choice.   I really enjoyed it for what it is.

They are not east to do well, just look at the abomination that was Duke Nukem Forever,  and this one has been done well and is fun.If you want great story and character development forget it there isn't either. Posted: January 1, 2014
												Hard Reset is a fun little old school shooter with a great Blade Runner vibe and outstanding atmosphere. The story is simple and forgettable, just enough to provide a little context in between bouts of fighting off hordes of robots with some very fun weapons. From a railgun straight out of Quake to amusing gravity grenades that suck robots up into a nice explodable pile, some of the best fun is in choosing the right weapon for the current situation.Frequent pauses in the form of looking for power ups keeps the action from getting too monotonous, leaving you with nice pacing and a little breather in between hard fights. And there are plenty of those on the higher difficulties. But don't expect to come away from these little pauses without a few surprises, the developers definitely like to keep you on your toes.The game is quite short, though the free DLC almost doubles the number of missions and a survival mode gives it some extra replayability.The way the in game menus are handled is a great touch, you're never taken out of the environment to click through a pop up window and there is no dedicated "use" button. Simply walk up to a terminal and your mouse cursor automatically appears to let you interact with it, very nice!One tip, don't bother upgrading the two starting weapons until later in the game. Some of the unlocks (especially the grenade launcher) are much more useful (and fun).

Posted: October 24, 2014
												This game rocks! The graphics and environments are some of the best I've seen in any game, ever. Weapons upgrades are super-customizable, and the fights can be tough. The original game is rather short, but with the included DLC I think it's well worth $15, and I got it on sale for $5- which is a steal. This game is action packed from the start and you'll be in another fight before you've caught your breath from the last one. Replay value is through the roof, as there is no way to get all the weapons upgrades before the game is over, and they offer a "plus" mode so you can keep all your upgrades for the next playthrough. This game really reminds me of Red Faction: Armageddon... so if you loved that, buy this!!!

Posted: February 16, 2014
												You: I'm a pro gamer and shooter veteran.Game: Show me!If you are looking for a real shooter, a real challenge and want to enjoy a shooter like it was intended to be and a game which really deserves the genre title shooter then Hard Reset is for you. If not then Hard Reset is also for you. It's a damn good looking game and you will enjoy it.Let's start with the pros: - This game is hard. Even on easy difficulty it's a real challenge. In other words we would say it's a shooter which deserves the name old-school shooter. The game is not forgiving. You have to practice a lot to master it on a normal or harder difficulty. While usually this wouldn't be an argument to buy a game this is exactly what makes Hard Reset a gem. It is challenging but never frustrating. That's the big difference to other titles.- Awesome graphics. While not a must-have these days (even for shooters) this game looks awesome on a PC. The engine is very well optimized and it runs also great and low-spec rigs. This is not a poor console port. It was developed for PC and there it performs awesome. - Great level design. While like any other shooter this game is very linear but it doesn't suffer any minute from this. The overall level design let you forget about that. Good placement of power ups and health. Great placement of secrets. If you are a shooter veteran and grew up with the good old titles you will love this one. - Great setting. The game takes place in a cyberpunk future. Everything fits perfectly in there. Graphics, atmosphere, sounds, even the small little things like the funny posters hanging around here and there. If you have the time between the battles take a closer look. You will love it.The "not so" good: - while there was only one point that could be criticized at first was the length of the game. The game was although its moderate/hard difficulty kinda short in playtime. This was fixed with the first DLC which was free. It took the game to the next step and made it a real competitor to the AAA titles out there. So this point isn't a con any more. If you take into consideration:1) the low price2) the quality of this product3) the nostalgia for old school shooter fans4) the replay value (yes I wanted to finish the is game on insane even though I suck in such difficulties)this game is a must have for every shooter fan. It's the champions league of the current shooter genre  and was the biggest surprise the last years. While everyone thought the shooter genre is dead Flying Wild Hog proved em wrong with this one.Get this title. The only category this game fits in would be "most overlooked gem in recent shooter history"

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Almost instantly Hard Reset brought to mind all those great late-90's FPS games. With a modern touch and great attention to detail, especially with the level design and enemy types, this game is truly both a blast from the past and a blast of fresh air. It is a shame that an amazing game like this has gone so unnoticed. I certainly am very glad that I decided to give it a go. Cool noir-ish style in its story, some very intriguing sci-fi concepts, fantastic gunplay and a gun-focused progression system, this game doesn't really lack anything. The gun system is interesting, you have two guns which have multiple modes of firing and you upgrade them as you go, also unlocking more fire modes, I think this system works very well combined with all the different enemies you'll face. I especially liked shooting the bigger enemies with a shotgun or a railgun, and seeing all the armor plating fly away, yet the buggers kept coming - so many thrilling fights! The boss fights are very enjoyable, the levels have lots of destructible environment and last but not least; this game has a lot of secret places - just like good old FPS games used to have. If you are a FPS fan, you should definitely play this one through.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												This is an interesting game with a cool art style. The soundtrack is a cool Techno inspired sound, the graphics are a bit neon sporting bright red, blue, and green. In between fighting the story unfolds through comic book pages, similar to how Max Payne worked. It has a bit of a learning curve with some depth to the upgrade options between your weapons and character. Boss fights are a little tedious as they are the "new, old school" as I call it with a throw back to old console games where you shoot the glowing bit until it falls off. All in all not a bad game, worth $5 or $10 bucks.Tips: Play on Normal, this game is brutal on Hard...I played on Hard and got super frusterated a bunch of times.Upgrade your CLN and NRG weapons. Learn to switch between the CLN #1 (Rifle), CLN #2 (Shotgun), NRG #1 (forget the name) and NRG #3 (Mortar), and CLN #4 (RPG). I found that a combo of CLN #3 and NRG #3 was my best way to take down most things quickly.

Posted: December 25, 2013
												My first review.I bought this game in the Winter Steam sale - only cost a few pounds and the description made the game sound quite good.  I was not disappointed.I've only played about 6 hours of the game at the time of typing but it would be fair to say that the graphics are very good.  I love the fact that a lot of the environment is desctructible and causes a lot of explosions.  Hell, I can simply spen 5 minutes shooting explodable barrels and gas cannisters just to watch the explosion causing barrels to shoot into the air.  It would be fair to say therefore that the physics are top.The storyline is okay.  And that's coming from me who has the attention span of a 5 year old and struggles to follow any story line.  The game is linear but not too restricting.  There are secret areas to find points that allow you to level up your kit.  I'm mainly using the gatling gun type thing.  Add a grenade launcher and mine placer/firer thing and it's a decent weapon.It's quite difficult on normal difficulty and some of the end level bosses are difficult.  Overall, it's a fun game, with good graphics and music score (forgot to mention that).

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Hard Reset is a sumptuous visual feast with massive boss fights.  It is amazing how the imagery surpasses a lot of the big-name titles that I see coming out.  The game has an upgrade system that functions like currency.  There are only two weapons, but each has about six intensive  diverse upgrades.  From rocket launchers, grenade launchers, to plasma cannon, EMP emitters, and a railgun, the weapons are hard hitting with a sound to match.  Most of the environment is explosive, electrocuting, and destructible which helps in dispatching an array of robots.  Cutscenes have a gritty, if not entirely cohesive storyline which was the only detraction.  The level designs are put together well and there is variety so that it doesn’t get repetitive.  The developers took a lot of time.  The gameplay will keep you engaged as it takes what’s right with old-school shooters, and adds faster elements .

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Now this is a very nice science fiction pulp game. It reminded me of some good old science fiction movies of the 80's and 90's like Screamers (somekind of terminator droid sf), Blade Runner etc. The details in the game are quite well worked out and the game looks very beautifull. The add signs on buildings. Flying ships and fancy modern and futuristic looking buildings and roads. The story telling is done cartoon style in the cutscenes. That actually takes a little away from the beauty that the gameplay levels have. It is about a world been partly taken over by renegade terminator style droid. The droids use razor blades to kill their targets. You are a mercenary been orded to take them out. You are actually in for the money. The sounds are good. Graphics and level building are extraordinary done. Although the gaming levels are quite linear. It is no free roaming the world in this game. The single player is worth it. It is a well made low budget game. Like the old movies these memories usually stay the longest. While afterwards you start to realise and appreciate the quality and effort that has been put in this game. There are no multiplayer features in this game. The AI enemies sometimes use little predictable tactics. These are the only two cons I can recall. So if you like to play a single player written story I would most definitely recommend this game.

												The game play really felt like a Quake or Doom shooter, I loved it. For me the best combat system of any FPS I haver played all year. There are multiple weapon combinations with different abilities. 												Hard Reset is an FPS for those who might want to see what one of those more old-fashioned FPS games would be like if they were made today. Posted: January 27, 2016
												A Doom clone for the modern age. Right off the bat, I'm a sucker for these retro games with modern visuals. It plays exactly like the old shooters, but has pretty modern graphics. I absolutely loved this game and hope that this gets a sequel or something. BUT, it is a niche shooter and I think this game is not for everyone. If you grew up playing Doom, Wolfenstein 3D, Quake, or Duke Nukem (and liked them) or you play them now you will probably like this game. However, if you grew up playing more modern shooters like Halo, Call of Duty or Battlefield (or you prefer them) this is not the game for you. Honestly I consider this to be a Doom 4 primer.+Awesome aesthetics, the sci-fi blade runner art works well hereGuns for most play styles (Shotguns Assault rifles, Rocket launchers, etc.)You don't HAVE to use all the guns, find one you like and upgrade that oneNo reloads! One big magazineWeapons mostly use same ammo! NO scrounging for Rifle roundsRPG elements allow you to customize your character-Cheap deaths occasionally, you get hung up on a brick while enemies pummel youA little too linear for it's own goodThe story is pretty lame, but that's par for most shootersEnemies are ruthless and plenty, I died often on normal.8/10

Posted: June 16, 2015
												A hidden gem among indie PC exclusives. This is an underrated game that deserves your attention. Picked it up on sale for $3 thinking it would be some half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ low-optimization time waster. Man was I wrong about that. Hard Rest is easily worth the full $15 price tag. Sure, the voice acting could use some work, but I do love the comic book aesthetic of the cutscenes through which the story is told.Highly recommended for fans of futuristic first-person shooters and cyberpunk games. Hell, you should pick this up even if you aren't into the whole cyberpunk thing. At a regular price of $15, and a discount price of $3, there's really no reason not to buy it. You really don't know what you're missing here. If you aren't convinced yet (or just don't want to believe me), then I suggest you download the demo and see the quality for yourself.

Posted: September 8, 2013
												This game is awesome!  It takes the classic 90's FPS formula and updates it for the modern generation.  Kinda like what Serious Sam did, but takes it in a different direction.  Its constant action, but to survive requires second-to-second strategy, recognizing enemy ai patterns and the perfect weapon to use for each element of an encounter.  During a single battle, i'd switch between 3-4  weapons atleast, and sometimes more to perfect the strategy.  I like how the ammo system works, so you can concentrate on which weapon is the best to do the job instead of constantly rationing the best weapons incase there is an extreme scenario down the line that needs it.  Also, the checkpoint system was tweaked just right so I don't need to save/load spam to beat an area, and gives a good opportunity to think of a new strategy to enter a battle with each time I die, just like classic side scroller games did.

Posted: January 27, 2016
												Before getting into  this game, you need to understand a few basic points:1. This isn't a AAA game.2. This is a "linear" game, and no, it isn't a downside, neither a flaw in design, it's what it was intended to be and what its target wanted.3. No, you don't have -fake- "choices" to make or "waifus" to fulfill your needs of self-worth, it is an "old school" shooter with a half-decent story (with really bad dialog and voice acting) and it is heavily focused on gameplay and FUN.When you play it on the hardest difficulty setting, it is actually HARD and sometimes it can feel unfair, you will get stuck at some parts and feel it is impossible, The game is broken! But when you beat those parts it is very rewarding and you realize that you just had to get out of your comfort zone ( your gameplay style and strategy). The reason I used  quote marks on the "old school" term, it is because this game is old school, but in a 2k FPS style. You aren't a minion jumping around in a big level as you do on Quake and Doom, your mobility is mostly horizontal and although you can jump over some stuff in the map, your mobility is not close to the one you had in 90's FPS tittles, but like Doom 3 instead.The game has a "currency" called N.A.N.O. which helps you to get upgrades and some packs if such currency can be hidden in a variety of places, many of them are hidden  in the fashion some games hide their "collectibles" behind walls you have to destroy, others are just behind a box or a corner and they are very easy to miss of you don't explore a bit (but just a little bit).Although you "technically" use the same two guns through the entire game, the guns change their form with a very nice animation each time you change to another weapon. There are good, feel nice, and aside from the basics, one of them uses energy and the other is a more "classical" projectile based weapon, they have many variances and again: they feel really well to use.Lenght-wise, well, this game isn't an RPG, but after the complaints about its duration when the first edition was released, the game got this free expansion (Extended Edition) that added around 3h reaching  solid 6-7 hours, The game is very replayable and it has some "arcade" characteristics/features:Replayability of each levelSurvival modeFinal screendisplaying completion time, percentage of available nano collected, secrets found (X/Y), etc.Interesting bosses.About the graphics: as you can see by the screenshots, it's very well done and rounded, artists really focused on making the metal look "real" and although ultra-realistic graphics isn't the main focus it  features very good good visuals.Flaws?Yes, it isn't a "perfect" game, although I struggle trying to not find this flaws on almost every TPS/FPS out there:1[/b. Enemy spawn patters are predictable2[/b. As I already mentioned it; it's mobility, it tends to feel very constricted, specially nowadays that people is used to jump off a second floor unharmed with  regular humans, I know the game is meant to be this way (because of budget) but mobility could add a lot to it.3. Enemies are varied, but many designs are recycled in the sense that you see nearly similar robots, which are actually  different, but they seem to be made with the sense of them feeling "realistic" (and because of budget) so you don't have over-the-top and different designs but slightly modified models even though they will do very different things, but I guess a lot of games do this.4. Its story is VERY disconnected from gameplay, you see everything in a comic-style cutscene between loading times. In general, the story has a couple of surprises, but it is bland and it could be done way better.5. Checkpoints tend to be somewhat inconsistent, sometimes you will have to do 3 times what you regularly do to get a checkpoints, more consistency would be good.6. The soundtrack is very basic and it would be epic to have a really well-worked soundtrack, specially for the bossfights.7. Although some people  STILL complaining about duration, it's something you should consider if you feel ripped-off if a game doesn't last 234141049 hours.My rating:7.5/10 (Good+)

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Hard Reset is a fun little old school shooter with a great Blade Runner vibe and outstanding atmosphere. The story is simple and forgettable, just enough to provide a little context in between bouts of fighting off hordes of robots with some very fun weapons. From a railgun straight out of Quake to amusing gravity grenades that suck robots up into a nice explodable pile, some of the best fun is in choosing the right weapon for the current situation.Frequent pauses in the form of looking for power ups keeps the action from getting too monotonous, leaving you with nice pacing and a little breather in between hard fights. And there are plenty of those on the higher difficulties. But don't expect to come away from these little pauses without a few surprises, the developers definitely like to keep you on your toes.The game is quite short, though the free DLC almost doubles the number of missions and a survival mode gives it some extra replayability.The way the in game menus are handled is a great touch, you're never taken out of the environment to click through a pop up window and there is no dedicated "use" button. Simply walk up to a terminal and your mouse cursor automatically appears to let you interact with it, very nice!One tip, don't bother upgrading the two starting weapons until later in the game. Some of the unlocks (especially the grenade launcher) are much more useful (and fun).

Posted: December 5, 2011
												While it's not a Duke3D or Doom 2 sort of "old school" Hard Reset definitely harkens back to Serious Sam, Painkiller, and even Quake 4. Beautiful environments, brutal enemies, and exotic upgradable weaponry system combine to deliver a very solid shooter. Health packs, skippable inbetween-level cutscenes and spawn triggers will bring you back to a different age of PC gaming. Personally, I purchased Hard Reset on sale and after finishing the game, feel guilty I didn't pre-order it. If you are looking for a challenge, play through this on Insane - while it feels impossible at times, the feeling of triumph you have after completing difficult sections of the game is uplifting. Secrets are abound in this game, some tougher to find than others, but each one gives you currency used to upgrade your weapons or unlock new ones.While it ends a bit abruptly, the ride there is full of gunplay. Some of the AI is simplistic, but the volume and strength of the enemies provide difficulty. Loved it.

												The linear but reused level architecture reminds me of the HL2 mod Minerva which is high praise.  It's very pretty too.The actual gameplay is somewhat generic FPS, two guns to alternate (energy/bullets) with a ton of upgrade options to turn them into all sorts of different styles of themselves, from shotguns to tasers, grenade aunchers and energy mortars.The level architure is kind of amazing, they've taken the lessons taught in Minerva and applied them to a commercial game.  Any part of a level you can see that is inaccessible, is somewhere you're going to end up later.  You'll end up seeing the same places from four different angles, again and again. Posted: May 17, 2016
												Hard Reset is a throwback to oldschool FPS where reloading is nonexistent, enemies are numerous and the explosions are more important than the story. This mishmash of fast paced action with spliced in comic book story scenes between levels does a good job of creating an interesting environment but also one you're not going to get too attached to. That's good since the game is actually quite short, although made significantly longer if you own the DLC. The game has only two weapons, but as you progress you can purchase weapon attachments and upgrades, essentially giving you a total of 10 weapons to play with, in addition to a number of armor and utility upgrades. The action is fast, the guns are fun and satisfying to use, and the game is hard. Very hard. In fact even if you're a veteran it may behoove you to start on a lower difficulty until you get used to it because this game is completely unforgiving. There's no regenerating health or ammo, the enemies do a lot of damage, they're relentless, and you will die extremely fast if surrounded.For the low prices this game goes for nowadays there's not really a way I can't recommend this. If you enjoy oldschool FPS like Doom, Quake or Duke Nukem (or even semi-modern ones like Serious Sam) you'll probably enjoy Hard Reset. If not, it's hard to say. Either way you can probably find the game for a couple dollars either in a bundle or on sale and if you do I'd say it's well worth the money.With Hard Reset: Redux out you'll probably want to take a look at that instead.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												You: I'm a pro gamer and shooter veteran.Game: Show me!If you are looking for a real shooter, a real challenge and want to enjoy a shooter like it was intended to be and a game which really deserves the genre title shooter then Hard Reset is for you. If not then Hard Reset is also for you. It's a damn good looking game and you will enjoy it.Let's start with the pros: - This game is hard. Even on easy difficulty it's a real challenge. In other words we would say it's a shooter which deserves the name old-school shooter. The game is not forgiving. You have to practice a lot to master it on a normal or harder difficulty. While usually this wouldn't be an argument to buy a game this is exactly what makes Hard Reset a gem. It is challenging but never frustrating. That's the big difference to other titles.- Awesome graphics. While not a must-have these days (even for shooters) this game looks awesome on a PC. The engine is very well optimized and it runs also great and low-spec rigs. This is not a poor console port. It was developed for PC and there it performs awesome. - Great level design. While like any other shooter this game is very linear but it doesn't suffer any minute from this. The overall level design let you forget about that. Good placement of power ups and health. Great placement of secrets. If you are a shooter veteran and grew up with the good old titles you will love this one. - Great setting. The game takes place in a cyberpunk future. Everything fits perfectly in there. Graphics, atmosphere, sounds, even the small little things like the funny posters hanging around here and there. If you have the time between the battles take a closer look. You will love it.The "not so" good: - while there was only one point that could be criticized at first was the length of the game. The game was although its moderate/hard difficulty kinda short in playtime. This was fixed with the first DLC which was free. It took the game to the next step and made it a real competitor to the AAA titles out there. So this point isn't a con any more. If you take into consideration:1) the low price2) the quality of this product3) the nostalgia for old school shooter fans4) the replay value (yes I wanted to finish the is game on insane even though I suck in such difficulties)this game is a must have for every shooter fan. It's the champions league of the current shooter genre  and was the biggest surprise the last years. While everyone thought the shooter genre is dead Flying Wild Hog proved em wrong with this one.Get this title. The only category this game fits in would be "most overlooked gem in recent shooter history"

Posted: November 18, 2015
												So this is more of a first impression kind of thing I will update this as I play more of the game.  So at first I had trouble getting into the game, it seems as though it doesn't like amd cards.  So what you have to do is go into the AMD Catlyst Control Center and alter the AA to use the applications settings.So with that out of the way,  what I have played so far is very, VERY reminiscent of Painkller, The music, The graphics, it almost seems as though some of the people from the Painkiller team have worked on this project.  It is awesome just the fact that they managed to capture the atmosphere and feeling of Painkiller (just with a Sci-fi setting.) is awesome to me (I am a huge Painkiller fan.)The game looks sharp, the graphics are just really well done, like I had said earlier very reminiscent of Painkiller (more specifically Hell and Damnation.)  The weapons in this game are interesting you have two weapon types N.R.G. and CLN.  The N.R.G. weapons are energy weapons (shocking I know.)  However instead of picking up entirely different weapons you get currency to upgrade the weapon you have (HOLD ON IT GETS COOLER.)  Each of these upgrades makes the weapon take on a different roll (The assault rifle turns into a shotgun and other weapons.)  It is very interesting, however the weapon that you buy shares the ammo for the other weapons (at least from what I have seen so far.)  I can't wait to see what this game has in store for me, I am already in love with it.UPDATE:  I am not a huge fan of the comic bookesque cutscenes.  However that will not affect the score I have given it.  The guns are still awesome I just unlocked a Alternate fire mode for my shotgun, once again very reminiscent of Painkiller,  it fires flak that paralyzes enemies very similar to the shotugun of Painkiller in which the alternate fire mode frezzes enemies.  However it does not kill the enemies instantly like in Painkiller.  Still loving the game.TL:DR It is a really well done classic FPS game and would reccomend grabbing it while it's on sale 8/10

Posted: December 8, 2015
IntroductionI wanted to play a shooter again, it had been a while. And here came Hard Reset on a sale, looking like a shooter with cool weapons, retro-gameplay and fancy graphics in a dark megacity setting. Sounded like something I would enjoy.Gameplay and DifficultyI completed the game on Hard and when this game says Hard, it means HARD. I rarely finished a level with under 2-5 deaths, some arenas cost me close to 10 deaths, because I either didn't choose the right weapon upgrades and consequently struggled, or I simply got overwhelmed by a surprise wave of enemies. Hard Reset is pretty simple in terms of game mechanics, the gameplay could be summarized like this:Enter arena. Run around in circles, relentlessly firing, dodging and switching between your poorly performing weapons, while trying to run from hordes of almost endlessly spawning mobs until you run out of ammo and powerups. Die. Try again. Finally beat arena. Proceed through corridor. Get ambushed. Enter next arena. Repeat. Occasionally you have to press buttons to proceed, that's really all there is to it.I'm usually the type for deep and rich gameplay, thinking up clever solutions, progressing tactically. I like games that make you think. This game is nothing like that and I'm aware this sounds like a full-fledged rant so far, BUT: what it does, it does well. The mechanics in place are well balanced, sprinting, jumping, shooting, environment damage, powerup placement and strength, enemy strength vs. weapon damage. It all was balanced with the grand scheme of gameplay in mind. Some arenas feel a bit overdone, the developers just love to throw in waves and waves of mobs, probably to extend the playtime a little more. However, once you learn what enemy types to expect in which quantities and where the powerups are, things get more manageable. And still, each mob does crazy damage, there is little room for mistakes. Mobs also have tons of health and the big boys take quite a bit ammo to take down. Smaller enemies come in larger quantities regularly and still each have quite a bit of health, so you're often better off using the big calibers with AoE for small enemies as well. Enemies mostly feel like bullet sponges - and that's okay to make the game work as it is designed, given the design of arenas and the circumstances of powerups etc. The problem is that the game just doesn't give you the feeling of real weapon impact which is a big factor of fun in most shooters. Not so much here.What's fun on the other hand is the management of space to run, retreating into the right corners, using the right weapons, dodging in the right moments, leaving powerups on the ground until you actually need them, it's all enough to consider to keep the game interesting.Boss battles are well done as a combination of getting swarmed by waves of distractive mobs and having to hit special zones on the boss's body that need to be destroyed to take the boss down.I like the AI in this game because mobs seem to cooperate to take you down. Mobs often run around you through adjacent corridors in order to attack you from all sides. Other than that, the AI is reasonably predictable once you've observed each mob's behaviour.Level designThe level design overall is pretty linear and one-dimensional. Visually most of the game takes place in a dark Blade Runner'esque megacity, most of which is beautifully built. Unfortunately it gets repetitive after a while and leaves you longing for a change. It's not until the Exile DLC expansion that the overall setting changes to a brighter scrapyard wasteland, which to me was a welcome change at that point.Many level elements return quite often, like forklifts blocking paths, while lifting the fork allows you to progess, or optionally powering up or down button panels to open doors. A little more variety wouldn't have hurt here.Quite often you'd bump into invisible walls blocking progress or keeping you from jumping over obstacles. This can be quite tedious when there's only one supposed way to get to a secret, but there's no way to tell where there's a hole in the invisible wall.VerdictSo how does that add up? Let's take a look at the pros and cons:*Pros*+ Graphics are really good, performance is sublime for the visual quality+ Sound is amazing+ Good soundtrack (with a few exceptions)+ Immersive dark and gritty atmosphere+ Fast-paced non-stop action, bug- and glitch-free+ Smooth user interface+ Motivating upgrade system (at least until midgame, in endgame all the necessary weapons and defensive stats are maxed out and there's no more need to upgrade)+ Interesting and tough boss battles, really gets you on your toes+ Good AI - enemy groups split up and try to attack from all sides, even sometimes taking the longer path around an obstacles to sneak at you from behind*Cons*- Often repetitive and easily predictable level design- Few enemy types- Weak weapons (or too tanky enemies)- Often unnecessarily prolonged battles - too many waves of mobs- Some weapons are useless - I almost exclusively used the RPG, Mortar and Railgun and did just fine. Assault Rifle and Plasma Rifle never got used anymore when other weapons were unlocked- Weapon switch times. This game requires frequent weapon switches and there are a few occasions where you just don't have the time to switch weapons. So if you're not prepared, you getting swarmed and you die.- Less than stellar German translation and synchronization- Some annoying songs in the soundtrack- Invisible walls, often annoying placement of N.A.N.O. (currency) requiring you to make fiddly jumps. I sometimes couldn't be bothered.So, do I recommend this game? Overall, yes! Buy it if you don't mind the simplistic gameplay and if you have a high-ish frustration tolerance. Do not buy it if you don't like arena battles and the circumstance of being constantly ambushed, surrounded and swarmed.Overall rating: 79/100

												Yes, a hundred times yes. I had dismissed this game many times when it was first released, and I really regret that. Posted: February 24, 2016
												One of the best examples of FPS action games out there. Only downside is a flat ending. Great difficulty, nice score system, nice story, I can make some critical judgments aside - but honestly - if you enjoy games like COD or Bioshock - this one is very playable and enjoyable. The weapon system is interesting. Two weapons, four fire mode functions and each of those functions have an auxilory function. All of the weapon modes add to gameplay and that's a big deal. When you unlock new functions and what function are choices you make along the way - which change the gameplay.You are also to 'play into the enviroment' by damaging objects for destruction bonus points and AOE damage on enemy swarms. It's worth at least $15 to someone who can appreciate nuanced FPS action. If you play games from start to finish - that in itself is decent in this title. Scenes move forward, the action makes sense. I recommend playing on an advanced difficulty - but whatever floats your boat.

												I'm a few hours in playing on hard diff, and I think it's a novel and interesting method of utilising weaponry which creates the need to think ahead, it looks nice it plays smoothly and although it's linear and quite restricted in terms of space, it being quite a confined environment the gameplay works and is designed around this small space combat.
