The one tip I would offer is be aware that changing some of your GFX card settings may affect loading and functionality. I changed a few things on Crimson (AMD Card GFX Settings Interface) without thinking and then couldn't see the loading screens or menu screen text at all. If you get that issue just select the "allow program/game to over ride GFX settings" in your GFX interface program. Other than that it's a cracking wee romp...

Posted: September 8, 2013
												This game is awesome!  It takes the classic 90's FPS formula and updates it for the modern generation.  Kinda like what Serious Sam did, but takes it in a different direction.  Its constant action, but to survive requires second-to-second strategy, recognizing enemy ai patterns and the perfect weapon to use for each element of an encounter.  During a single battle, i'd switch between 3-4  weapons atleast, and sometimes more to perfect the strategy.  I like how the ammo system works, so you can concentrate on which weapon is the best to do the job instead of constantly rationing the best weapons incase there is an extreme scenario down the line that needs it.  Also, the checkpoint system was tweaked just right so I don't need to save/load spam to beat an area, and gives a good opportunity to think of a new strategy to enter a battle with each time I die, just like classic side scroller games did.

Posted: March 10, 2016
 Hard Reset combines a new-age look with old-FPS values, creating the most unique looking bullet hell you'll probably ever play.   7.5/10 Calling this game "Flashy" would be an understatement. Every combat situation is a lightshow and you're the conductor. Shooting enemies with both your Ballistic and Energy weapons feels incredibly satisfying, both gun types being different enough to have their own personalities. The destructible environment, while not as satisfying as the gunplay, makes the scenery feel more realistic to the dark and dreary dystopian future. On the downside, the story is nothing to write home about, and though the gunplay is satisfying most of the time, other times it can feel repetitive. Despite this, I would recommend this game to my friends. It sets itself apart from the pack by having a unique look and feel. And in moderation, quite a fun time.

												Kind of like "Serious Sam," only more focused on enclosed battles than  arena fights and a lot shorter (so also a lot less repetitive). It does have its flaws (level design is a bit linear, story is incomprehensible, it uses a checkpoint system rather than quicksaves, the environments get a bit same-ish after the first few levels), but overall I think the positives outweigh the negatives: interesting variety of weapons, an upgrade system which can't be fully maxed out the first go around (so your game will change depending on which load out you take), very well constructed battles which are different enough from each other to hold your interest, and just the right level of difficulty which will have you thinking as the game continually one ups itself with each successive battle, "Holy ♥♥♥♥, there's no way I can get past this area" just minutes before you do, in fact, get past it.Play on "Insane" or don't play at all.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Hard Reset feels like an old school FPS laced with modern graphics and special effects. The game itself is very well made and one can easily see the meticulous effort that went into designing the environments, enemies, and the weapons. Hard Reset offers a superb visual experience, but falls short in presenting an interesting narrative - a prominent issue in most contemporary video games. Is it worth the full retail price? Posted: May 17, 2016
												Hard Reset is a throwback to oldschool FPS where reloading is nonexistent, enemies are numerous and the explosions are more important than the story. This mishmash of fast paced action with spliced in comic book story scenes between levels does a good job of creating an interesting environment but also one you're not going to get too attached to. That's good since the game is actually quite short, although made significantly longer if you own the DLC. The game has only two weapons, but as you progress you can purchase weapon attachments and upgrades, essentially giving you a total of 10 weapons to play with, in addition to a number of armor and utility upgrades. The action is fast, the guns are fun and satisfying to use, and the game is hard. Very hard. In fact even if you're a veteran it may behoove you to start on a lower difficulty until you get used to it because this game is completely unforgiving. There's no regenerating health or ammo, the enemies do a lot of damage, they're relentless, and you will die extremely fast if surrounded.For the low prices this game goes for nowadays there's not really a way I can't recommend this. If you enjoy oldschool FPS like Doom, Quake or Duke Nukem (or even semi-modern ones like Serious Sam) you'll probably enjoy Hard Reset. If not, it's hard to say. Either way you can probably find the game for a couple dollars either in a bundle or on sale and if you do I'd say it's well worth the money.With Hard Reset: Redux out you'll probably want to take a look at that instead.

Posted: June 9, 2016
Buy on saleThis game is pretty fun for what it is. Think Duke Nukem 3D and Serious Sam, minus the wit. Think Dark Forces II, minus the compelling story. Think DOOM, minus horror and viscera. Think Painkiller, minus the creative arsenal.There's a lot to dislike about this gameEverything feels super-generic and samey, and billing this game as a classic run-and-gun FPS I suppose abates any complaint I could have about it being a bare bones, no-frills experience. The bad guys are somewhat dull and limited in variety. The graphics are muddy and vague and can make it hard to tell exactly what you're shooting at. The music is mediocre buttrock that maniacally swings from intense to anemic depending on enemy proximity, The level design takes a page from its predecessors, nonsensical and labyrinthian, not very engaging or immersive.But...That said, this game plays smooth as butter on velvet, getting 75-80 FPS on my mid-grade gaming tower. The weapon assortment while limited and simple feels good. The combat can sometimes be repetitive but feels very satisfying and fluid. The entire world is rife with destructible elements that you can shoot for a rewarding, over-the-top level of destruction. Despite the blandness that surrounds practically every aspect of this game, Hard Reset plays fantastically.Ultimately, if this game is on sale for under $5, and you want to shoot robo-dudes for a couple hours, pick this up. It's worth that price.

Posted: December 7, 2015
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine  PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this game Hard Reset is developed by Flying Wild Hog, the people behind Shadow Warrior and its upcoming sequel. Hard Reset was developed before Shadow Warrior and you can tell that the company did not have as much of a bigger budget as Shadow Warrior didThe story basically follows a dystopian world where robots have taken over by a sophisticated A.I., you play a major known as Fletcher, throughout the story you have to try and find out the reasons why the robots have turned against the humans and stop those who are responsible. The story is very cliche and does follow what many other sci-fi films back in the day managed to achieveThe environments are absolutely stunning, and the lighting effects in particular really make the enviornments come alive. The explosions also play a big role in Hard Reset and really make the game more explosive in its action, however, even though I have a PC that can run it on ultra settings, I did suffer with some minor frame rate drops when there was a lot of action going about. Now, I don't know what the developers where trying to go through the environments, but the game really reminded me of Blade Runner, a sci-fi thriller classic. The high rise buildings, the flying cars and that Chinese/Japanese (sorry can't tell the difference) adevertising on large blimps, I think the developers where heavily inspired by Blade Runner when they were designing Hard ResetTalking about game performance, this game does suffer with poor game performance. Sometimes the game freezes monetarily even in heavy combat areas, this may be due to the high amounts of enemies and explosive effects taking placeThe A.I., the game's difficulty changes drastically, especially in the last bit of the main story and then the rest of the DLC story, I first played on Normal difficulty and it was so annoying that I died so many times that I had to lower it to the Easy difficulty which lowered the amount of times I died and these robots sure do have precision aim shooting, because in Hard Reset they have precision aim shooting!The music and sound effects were okay but what really made me happy was that whilst playing, it did remind me of Blade Runner quite a lot!Like previously said, you will die, a lot, thankfully there is a fair checkpoint system in the game. The voice acting was bad and I mean really bad. You can tell that in Shadow Warrior they had a bigger budget because at least in that game the voice acting was good, in Hard Reset, they were really bad. The only good performance I would say was from the professor, nobody elseThe gunplay is okay, nothing special though. I think the game was also heavily inspired by old shooters like DOOM, as it does try to bring in that same formula to Hard ResetLastly, what really made me not want to continue playing was the re-use of the enemies. I don't know how many times I saw the same enemies over and over again every single time through my whole playthrough. It really made me not want to continue playing... Plus, what is up with the endings!? The main story's ending is really bad and ends on a huge cliffhanger leaving you helpless as to what has just happened and what will happen, thankfully Flying Wild Hog made an extended edition which includes the Exile DLC for free which continues the main game. But even that ending, it has that ending of, "Oh, don't worry, everything will be explained in due time", and just ends like that...I had fun playing Hard Reset, even though it did have its fair share of problems here and there, but on the whole, it was a really good action game. I wouldn't recommend Hard Reset for its full asking price as I feel it does not satisfy me to pay full price, but if it is in a sale, price drop, etc... I would definitely recommend you buying it, if you love sci-fi or Blade Runner or both like me RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: June 15, 2015
												Hard Reset gets a 8.5/10 from me, it's a good game. The only reason why there are some negative reviews is that this game is oldschool, meaning that you actually need skill and reflexes with a bit of tactic to survive. So if you're a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ casual go back to your cave, if you want a good oldschool shooter that rewards skill rather than grind, hard reset is the game for you.Let's start with the story: You are a cop/merc that has to kill all robots, thats basically it.Graphics:  The levels are colorful and the graphics of this game are awesome, lots of ligth effects, screenshake, uber physics, you can basically destzory everthing that is not attached to another object.Enemies: A bit monotone but require reflexes and the right tactic. Gunplay feels good, with some weapons being less rewarding than others, overall motivation is also good, exploring levels is quite well rewarded and you always look for more upgrades.I picked this game up for 3 bucks and had awesome fun with it, wish there were more games with this palystyle and graphics today, you won't find a better shooter for this price at the moment, devs even gave out a DLC for it.

Posted: November 6, 2013
												Warsaw based studio Flying Wild Hog, are no strangers to FPS-games, rather, they are connoisseurs of the genre who know how gamer hearts work. In Hard Reset, they have managed to combine the spirit and feel of the old school shooter with amazing graphics, and it is a wild ride, if not for a lifetime, then for at least 10 - 15 hours if you are an acheivement hunter and if you love action.In the Extended Edition of the game, you get the DLC Exile for free, which is quite generous in these times. Previous Hard Reset-owners can also download the DLC for free, which keeps the action going for at least two more hours.Storywise, there is nothing new here, which is actually something I really liked about the game. You go from one scene to another, knowing exactly what you should do, just like in the old days; so be prepared to use your tiggerfinger alot.POSITIVE:+ Sharp and crisp visuals.+ Fairly lenghty campaign.+ Nice audio.NEGATIVE:- Menu (hard to switch weapons fast sometimes).- Voice acting is OK.- You can’t run and jump at the same time.If you are looking for a nice looking shooter to get you through the day, you need to play Hard Reset.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												A cyberpunk shooter by (some of) the makers of Painkiller, and very much in that style (that is, old-school shoot-em-up).  Looks great, and the levels are well-designed. The upgrade system is a little wonky: you have two guns, which can each be upgraded into other types of guns within that guns' style.  One is an energy weapon, the other a conventional rifle: the energy weapon is upgraded into a rail gun, &c. while the rifle can be upgraded into an RPG, shotgun &c., with about 10 different weapons in total with most all having an alternate firing mode.  These were relatively easy to switch between, but tedious to scroll through (I would advise using the bound keys for specific guns early, as I used the mouse scroll and ended up blowing myself up with the RPG several times intending to use the shotgun).The story is mostly non-existent.  One gets the feeling that they ran out of funding, or something, as the cut scenes are all hand drawn (as though they were still storyboards), and the plot seems half-cocked at best (I could not even begin to tell you what the story is about).  But it, appropriately, goes mostly unnoticed, taking a backseat to the gameplay.tl;dr: Story sucks, but looks good and plays about as well.I'd give it a B

Posted: March 10, 2016
 Hard Reset combines a new-age look with old-FPS values, creating the most unique looking bullet hell you'll probably ever play.   7.5/10 Calling this game "Flashy" would be an understatement. Every combat situation is a lightshow and you're the conductor. Shooting enemies with both your Ballistic and Energy weapons feels incredibly satisfying, both gun types being different enough to have their own personalities. The destructible environment, while not as satisfying as the gunplay, makes the scenery feel more realistic to the dark and dreary dystopian future. On the downside, the story is nothing to write home about, and though the gunplay is satisfying most of the time, other times it can feel repetitive. Despite this, I would recommend this game to my friends. It sets itself apart from the pack by having a unique look and feel. And in moderation, quite a fun time.

Posted: June 28, 2012
												The Good: Excellent visuals, interesting weaponsThe Bad: Frustratingly difficult, broken weapon system, repetitive enemies, very linear, uninteresting story, messy cut scenesHard Reset is a cyberpunk game set in the future about a war between AI machines and humans. You are an agent of the CLN trying to stop this, but the story is kind of just vaguely tossed together and doesn't really make any sense. You also don't get much sense of what's going on in the world. The characters are uninteresting, and the messy comic style cut scenes are uninspired and sloppy. Besides this the game has some solid shooting, but even that has issues of its own.There are only two guns and each one has its own different "add-ons". The energy weapons let you shoot plasma, mortars, a smartgun which shoots through walls, and EMP grenades. The CLN gun has a machine gun, RPG, shotgun, and grenade launcher. This is great and all, but this system is flawed. Switching between two weapons and then to the right attachment is stupid. Not only are the gun switching animations slow, but having to do this costs precious seconds in which you're dying. This also rolls into the biggest problem with the game: It's too damn hard. Sure I like a challenge, but just a few hits and you're dead, but there are tons of enemies thrown at you and they don't go down easy. Expect to restart dozens of times almost during every fight unless you're on easy.Why would a game have a weapon system that works against itself? Who knows. You can buy these attachments and upgrade them by finding XP lying around everywhere, but the progression is slow and by the end of the game you will barely have bought 10 upgrades. My other complaint is that there are only about 6 different types of robots you can shoot and it gets old very fast. The first couple of levels are pretty awesome then that wears out when you get to your first fight where you die about 10 times.There are a couple of boss fights, but they are almost impossible to beat on any difficulty but easy. I haven't played such a hard FPS that I can remember. It actually makes the game not very fun at all, and even the most skilled players will struggle. I can't even believe they put an insane mode in here. One hit and you're dead which makes it impossible to go past the first fight in the game. Go figure. The objectives are all the same with you pressing this button, shut down this thing to go past that thing. There are secret areas you can find to improve your end of level score, but who really cares? You'll be lucky if you can get through the damn game.The game looks pretty damn good with a nice Blade Runner type art style, but it's wasted on linear levels. The overall feeling of the world has lots of potential with kiosks hocking items in robotic/half failing voices, holograms with propaganda and ads everywhere. I like the style, but it sure went to waste. Overall Hard Reset is a decent shooter for a weekend sit down, but the extreme difficulty practically kills it. There's also not multiplayer which is a surprise so after you finish the game once you probably won't go back.~Score: 7/10

Posted: February 15, 2014
												An excellent modern-made throwback to the more arcade-style shooters of the 90s. It looks great (it runs quite well too), it plays better. The developers pulled off the cyberpunk theme very well and fighting the "mutant robots" as I would call has never been this much fun. The design decision on two physical weapons that morph into multiple different functional weapons is an interesting and pleasing approach to the "this dude can carry 20 different weapons" factor. This game, at higher difficulty levels, is also very challenging. Experienced and older fans of the genre will find themselves at home amidst the dystopian city. Definitely recommended, download the demo to see what its all about.

Posted: April 30, 2015
												Hard Reset caught some flack for being a relatively short game with a small variety of enemies that don't do anything more than the one or two actions they make.HOWEVER!  These are the only real problems these reviewers actually have with the title.  To them, I say "Phooey".  Hard Reset is a wonderful arcade-y shooter game that's focused on obliterating a lot of robots while moving, shooting and running constantly through a very well designed futuristic city.  It's incredibly linear with the occasional small alleyway or fence that hides some bonus points, but this is perfect for how the game is meant to be.  It keeps you going and shooting, and the enemies get varied at the correct times, and they spawn in the perfect places to make for a challenging and fun experience.  I love the world, I love the feel, I love the art (especially the city), and I love the game.Quick note:  The story is extremely weak, but the story shouldn't be the focus of a game of this type anyway.  Solid 8 or 9/10.  There is NO reason to not pick this title up if Steam throws it on sale (which happens quite often).

Posted: June 28, 2012
												The Good: Excellent visuals, interesting weaponsThe Bad: Frustratingly difficult, broken weapon system, repetitive enemies, very linear, uninteresting story, messy cut scenesHard Reset is a cyberpunk game set in the future about a war between AI machines and humans. You are an agent of the CLN trying to stop this, but the story is kind of just vaguely tossed together and doesn't really make any sense. You also don't get much sense of what's going on in the world. The characters are uninteresting, and the messy comic style cut scenes are uninspired and sloppy. Besides this the game has some solid shooting, but even that has issues of its own.There are only two guns and each one has its own different "add-ons". The energy weapons let you shoot plasma, mortars, a smartgun which shoots through walls, and EMP grenades. The CLN gun has a machine gun, RPG, shotgun, and grenade launcher. This is great and all, but this system is flawed. Switching between two weapons and then to the right attachment is stupid. Not only are the gun switching animations slow, but having to do this costs precious seconds in which you're dying. This also rolls into the biggest problem with the game: It's too damn hard. Sure I like a challenge, but just a few hits and you're dead, but there are tons of enemies thrown at you and they don't go down easy. Expect to restart dozens of times almost during every fight unless you're on easy.Why would a game have a weapon system that works against itself? Who knows. You can buy these attachments and upgrade them by finding XP lying around everywhere, but the progression is slow and by the end of the game you will barely have bought 10 upgrades. My other complaint is that there are only about 6 different types of robots you can shoot and it gets old very fast. The first couple of levels are pretty awesome then that wears out when you get to your first fight where you die about 10 times.There are a couple of boss fights, but they are almost impossible to beat on any difficulty but easy. I haven't played such a hard FPS that I can remember. It actually makes the game not very fun at all, and even the most skilled players will struggle. I can't even believe they put an insane mode in here. One hit and you're dead which makes it impossible to go past the first fight in the game. Go figure. The objectives are all the same with you pressing this button, shut down this thing to go past that thing. There are secret areas you can find to improve your end of level score, but who really cares? You'll be lucky if you can get through the damn game.The game looks pretty damn good with a nice Blade Runner type art style, but it's wasted on linear levels. The overall feeling of the world has lots of potential with kiosks hocking items in robotic/half failing voices, holograms with propaganda and ads everywhere. I like the style, but it sure went to waste. Overall Hard Reset is a decent shooter for a weekend sit down, but the extreme difficulty practically kills it. There's also not multiplayer which is a surprise so after you finish the game once you probably won't go back.~Score: 7/10

												Got the Extended Edition on Steam sale for €2, after trying the demo. No issues with either in Windows10, so far. First, good that they make a demo, not enough game makers do this. Second, this is a thoroughly enjoyable game. Really nice graphics, good atmosphere (note the floating advertising ships, remind you of anything?), fun combat. Find a combo that works and get to work. Posted: September 2, 2015
												Cyberpunk asthetic, beautiful graphics, and intense gameplay make for a thrilling FPS.Hard Reset sets out to let you slaughter tons of robots in a series of thrilling encounters throughout a gorgeous cyberpunk city, and it does so with style. From the main menu to the upgrade stations, everything carries the futuristic cyberpunk asthetic, which greatly enhances the atmosphere. The city and robot design are gorgeous, and with a great use of color, lighting, and effects. You have two weapons to quickly switch between, and each weapon can morth into upto four different guns, such as an assault rifle, shotgun, grenade launcher, and rocket launcher. As you progress you can unlock additional modes for each gun and upgrades for each mode.The battles are fast, furious, and intense. Circle strafe and keep moving, as standing still will get you killed. I found the normal difficulty perfect, challenging enough to make every fight intense, but I would only die maybe once per level. Additional checkpoints have been added since release to minimize repeating encounters upon death. The game is a good length, wrapping up before it becomes repetitive or outlives its welcome.The main faults I found were the lack of a manual save - I shouldn't have to rely on checkpoints - and that the story was rather confusing and mostly told between levels.

												Il gioco è un FPS old school che piacerà certamente ad un pubblico con qualche anno  di esperienza videoludica. Il motore grafico è molto fluido anche su configurazioni non nuovissime. Il gameplay è ottimo e perfettamente calibrato per mouse e tastiera. Se il gioco fosse stato un po' più lungo e con una storia più appagante, sarebbe stato perfetto. Con l'uscita della versione extended probabilmente molte incertezze verranno eliminate. Durante i saldi piuttosto che acquistare la solita roba di produzione tripla A, tenete presente anche Hard Reset che ha ben poco da invidiare, anzi. Speriamo in altre produzioni di Flying Wild Hog; il team è composto da veterani del settore, il risultato finale è molto buono e promette molto bene anche lo sviluppo di nuovi titoli.

Posted: January 7
												Hard Reset is a simple First Person Shooter with interesting graphics. It's set in a "Terminator" style universe where machines have taken over from humans. The graphics are interesting - sort of cartoon like. I played the single player campaign and the robots tend to attack by ambush and at times in waves.  Winning these fights involves (limited) ammo management, health management (finding medkits) and choosing the right weapon for the job. I found the shotgun to be good for the swarm attacks, with the plasma (NRG) weapon, particularly the railgun and smartgun, good for the larger enemies.On the downside, the dialogue is awful. The designers overused profanity. Some of the cartoon cutscenes are undecipherable scribbles. Some of the plot nuances were a bit lost on me - the protagnist seems to have some ability to absorb multiple personalties?  This wasn't explained very well.Levelling up in this game consists of collecting orange "Nanos" which eventually allow you to select either a weapon, shield or tactical upgrade. That's it.  This makes the game rather one-dimensional. However, if you enjoy a fast paced FPS then you're sure to enjoy this game. It is getting a bit repetitive/monotonous however. Oh, there are bosses which can sometimes be a bit tricky to work out how to defeat.

												Yeah, it's a keeper.  To get this game on sale for a buck fitty, it's worth it.  Fun way to spend some hours if you are feeling the itch for some dark shooter type of game. Lots of robots and cyborgs, fast paced and intense, weapons are pretty neat and you can upgrade them along with some gear upgrades. It runs pretty good on my old laptop on high settings, but will run very well on a modern machine at max settings.  Very good delivery on the theme of the game, the dialogue is set up like a comic strip in parts and is not real in depth which I like.  No boring story with a bunch of dramatic chit-chat, just straight to business and killing robots.  Quality headphones and a dark room will instantly draw you in to the feel of this game.  Would I pay full price for this game?  Nah, but I feel real good about buying it at 90% off and would highly encourage others to do the same while it's still on sale. I'm glad I got it.

Posted: February 11
												Hard Reset is a pretty good time. The design is very old school, much like the Painkiller games. You're dealing with a lot of enemies, coming from all directions, and each is best handled with a different strategy. On the higher difficulties the game is absolutely ruthless, requiring you to take note of and use all environmental damage sources (explosive barrels, etc), which are scattered liberally around the levels.My few gripes include a rather slow movement speed that makes it extremely difficult to dodge certain enemies and projectiles, and an odd damage representation system. The screen becomes difficult to make out after you take damage, leaving your actual health total a mystery. In addition, even after picking up health (and perhaps returning to your maximum) the screen remains difficult to read for a few moments.

Posted: February 12
												Enemy selection is pretty decent. good spread of HP values and attacks. Bosses were so-so.Level design was decent. Lots of exploding barrels everywhere. Kiting to an earlier part of the level and spamming bombs at a chokepoint happened a bit too much for my taste, but getting locked in an arena filled barrels and different enemy types never got old. Art was better than I expected, but always felt pretty generic shootery.Campaign about 10 hours long. About as long as you'd want it to be, considering you're facing souped version of old enemies by then. Plot is nothing to write home about.Gun selection is the big strongpoint. Many unique, very fun weapons to unlock. Had lots of fun getting ricochet kills with the grenade launcher.

												Wreck, Played for a bit.  Game is awesome, really makes you feel the weapon your using, you can barely control it.  It's intense, be prepared, like duke nukem prepared.  Graphics are really nice also.  Controls can be a little wonkey.  I like how the story is told comic book style.  Reminded me of Max Payne.  This game is hard though.  I highly recommend having an energy drink nearby after downing two before playing.

												It is what it looks like. Straight-forward no-brain shooter where you see places, meet different entities and kill them all before they've killed you.Also it has a very good sound track and a cool hard cyberpunk visual style. The only thing I miss is the ability to sweep the level in a Painkiller style after all enemies are dead.

Posted: February 4
												Yeah, it's a keeper.  To get this game on sale for a buck fitty, it's worth it.  Fun way to spend some hours if you are feeling the itch for some dark shooter type of game. Lots of robots and cyborgs, fast paced and intense, weapons are pretty neat and you can upgrade them along with some gear upgrades.  It even came with DLC included for the same price but I have not gotten to that part yet. It runs pretty good on my old laptop on high settings, but will run very well on a modern machine at max settings.  Very good delivery on the theme of the game, the dialogue is set up like a comic strip in parts and is not real in depth which I like. Posted: February 24
												Okay so heavy reset in a nutshell: It is one of those awesome, fun,  action packed, shooters that are a rare joy these days.Set in a future where there are lots of robots that apparently are not nice, you blow them up with either energy based weapons on classic projectiles.The visuals still look good today. The sound is very good and the game play is awesome.The combat is really unique because it mixes classis shooting where you want to keep moving and weapons and enviromnetal items that are used for crowd control. It's not quite old school, but it has the feel too it. I highly reccomend that you download the demo and give it a try.
